q.s: Which of the following conditions most directly led to the establishment of the Regiment of U.S. Colored Troops?

o.l: New legal protections for African American citizenship rights
A labor shortage and the decline of white enlistment in the army
African Americans’ demonstration of bravery on the battlefield
President Lincoln’s orders to desegregate the military

f.c:
“I — A Bureau is established...for the record of all matters relating to the organization of Colored Troops.... 


VI — Colored troops may be accepted by companies, to be afterward consolidated in battalions and regiments.... They will be designated: ‘——Regiment of U. S. Colored Troops.’


VII —  Recruiting stations...will be established...and officers will be detailed to...inspect the troops.


VIII —  The non-commissioned officers of colored troops may be selected and appointed from the best men of their number in the usual mode of appointing non-commissioned officers.”

Source: General Order No. 143, by order of the Secretary of War, United States War Department, 1863

q.s: Based on the passage, which of the following can most directly be inferred about African American troops in the Civil War?

o.l: African American soldiers were mostly people who were formerly enslaved.
African American soldiers agreed to serve in the military to obtain citizenship.
African American troops received the same pay as white soldiers.
African American troops served in segregated units.

f.c:

VI — Colored troops may be accepted by companies, to be afterward consolidated in battalions and regiments.... They will be designated: ‘——Regiment of U. S. Colored Troops.’


VII —  Recruiting stations...will be established...and officers will be detailed to...inspect the troops.


VIII —  The non-commissioned officers of colored troops may be selected and appointed from the best men of their number in the usual mode of appointing non-commissioned officers.”

Source: General Order No. 143, by order of the Secretary of War, United States War Department, 1863

q.s: Which of the following best describes a response by Black soldiers to General Order No. 143?

o.l: They served in the war to ensure equal federal funding for their educational opportunities.
They protested being drafted into a war when they were not yet considered citizens.
They deserted from the Union Army based on having to fight in segregated troops.
They volunteered to enlist and took pride in their contributions to ending enslavement.

q.s: The sentiments in the source most directly reflect which of the following purposes of Harlem Renaissance art?

o.l: The expression of racial separatism that was prominent in the 1920s
The exploration of African Americans’ connection to Africa
The protesting of government actions that marginalized African Americans
The belief in African Americans’ assimilation into white culture

f.c:
Africa 

As gleams the evening star 

Upon the brow of night, 

When light of day has trailed

Its master's sudden flight, 

So shines the motherland— 

An emerald at rest, 

Amid the sapphire splendor 

Of the ocean's surging breast.

Source: B.B. Church, published in the July 1924 edition of the newspaper, The Crisis

o.l: They sought to express the importance of a liberal arts education.
They sought to celebrate the achievements of other Black artists.
They sought to counter negative stereotypes of Africa.
They sought to support the ideas of the Back to Africa movement.

o.l: African American artists were pushing back against the legacies of colonialism and the transatlantic slave trade.
The goal of the New Negro movement was to create a distinctly Black aesthetic.
African American artists used their artwork to advocate for rights during the nadir.
The impact of historically Black colleges and universities on Black culture grew after Reconstruction.

q.s:
Using the excerpt, respond to parts A, B, C, and D.

 

  1. Describe the broader historical context of Wells’s speech.
  2. Describe one piece of evidence Wells provides in her speech to support her claim that Southern states have destroyed the rights of African Americans.
  3. Describe a strategy used by African Americans in the late nineteenth and early twentieth century to promote racial uplift.
  4. Explain how the discriminatory practices described in the excerpt were challenged by African American activists in the second half of the twentieth century.

f.c:
“The right of the Afro-American to vote and hold office remains in the Federal Constitution, but is destroyed in the constitution of the Southern states. Having destroyed the citizenship of the man, they are now trying to destroy the manhood of the citizen. All their laws are shaped to this end, school laws, railroad car regulations, those governing labor liens on crops, every device is adopted to make slaves of free men and rob them of their wages. Whenever a malicious law is violated in any parts, any farmer, any railroad conductor, or merchant can call together a posse of his neighbors and punish even with death the black man who resists, and the legal authorities sanction what is done by failing to prosecute and punish murders. The Repeal of the Civil Rights Law removed their last barrier and the black man’s last bulwark and refuge. The rule of mob is absolute.”

Source: Ida B. Wells, “Lynch Law and All its Phases,” 1893

q.s: Which of the following claims is best supported by the ideas presented in the source?

o.l: The Plessy v. Ferguson decision led to segregated colleges and prevented Black students from entering leadership positions in American society.
Black communities developed businesses and economic opportunities so that higher education would not be wasted amongst their graduates.
African Americans responded to attacks on their freedom and a lack of equality by relying on those in the press who were sympathetic to the cause of equality for African Americans.
Institutions that advocated for industrial training and education provided an efficient means for racial uplift.

f.c:
“We are in perfect accord on the matter of [forming a Negro Baptist Publishing Company].... 

Although we note with pleasure that the Negro...has made wonderful progress in the higher branches of education, it is a lamentableregrettable; unfortunate fact that some of the ablest scholars of the race have been forced to occupy very menial positions, because there is such little organization among our people that they are not willing to [allow us to support] their genius and learning.... If we stop educating, we go backward toward slavery and eternal obscurity.... We must encourage education by creating establishments for the employment of scholarship.... If the large army of Baptist young people...are not encouraged to bookmaking, clerkships, ... and management by us, whitherwhere shall they go as they come forth from the colleges and universities...?

If the scholars and workers of our race find that they are the sponsors of a great concern like [the Negro Baptist Publishing Company], nothing else will so inspire them to make master strokes for the race.... 

The solution of the so-called race problem will depend in a large measure upon what we prove able to do for ourselves.”

Source: Speech by Reverend Elias Camp Morris, president of the National Baptist Convention, an association of Black churches, at a meeting of the Convention in Washington, D.C., 1893

q.s: Based on the source, which of the following claims could most accurately be made?

o.l: The forced separation of the Black community from the wider American society led African Americans to create their own organizations.
Jim Crow laws limited the Black church’s ability to effectively mobilize and organize Black leaders throughout the country.
The funding from local Black state officials enabled the Black church to create scholarship opportunities for young Black leaders.
The Black church worked effectively with Black women leaders and activists to promote economic independence.

Source: Speech by Reverend Elias Camp Morris, president of the National Baptist Convention, an association of Black churches, at a meeting of the Convention in Washington, D.C., 1893

o.l: African American participation in Christian religious services was not widespread until after the Civil War.

African Americans continued to use churches to resist oppression and to build community.

o.l: Presidential executive orders focused on equal economic opportunity rather than the segregation of public facilities.
The Supreme Court ruled in Plessy v. Ferguson that segregated facilities created by state laws were constitutional.
The Supreme Court ruling in Brown v. Board of Education addressed segregation in education but not in transportation.
Amendments to the United States Constitution gave the states broad powers to manage public infrastructure.

f.c:
• The black-and-white photograph shows a few Black people waiting to board a bus at a bus station.

  • A second bus is shown parked in the background

q.s: Which of the following best describes the broader historical context of events such as the Combahee River uprising?

o.l: Enslaved persons’ uprisings strengthened Confederate control over Southern states such as South Carolina.
The Union Army’s strategy during the Civil War was unaffected by the persistence of slavery in the South.
Both before and during the Civil War, abolitionists helped enslaved African Americans flee the South.
The increased demand for labor during the Civil War led to an improvement in conditions for enslaved people in the South.

f.c:
“In 1863, Black Moses (also known as Harriet Tubman) achieved the first U.S. military victory organized and led by a woman, a decisive blow to a Confederacy that was at that time dominating and draining the Union. Most important, the Combahee River uprising—during which almost 800 enslaved people of African descent stole themselves to freedom, burned down thirty-two plantation buildings, and flooded the rice plantations that were the center of South Carolina’s confederate economy—could be called the most successful uprising against slavery in the U.S. The Combahee River uprising had the triple impact of achieving freedom for hundreds of enslaved Africans, causing irreparable damage to South Carolina rice plantations, and adding hundreds of black troops to the Union army’s campaign in the South Carolina stronghold of the Confederacy at a major turning point of the Civil War. It would not be excessive to say the 800 people of multiple genders and ages who enacted the Combahee Uprising, after a full year of intelligence and organizing by Tubman and eight of her trusted scouts, achieved freedom for themselves and played a key role in ending chattel slavery as a legal institutional practice in the United States."

Source: Alexis Pauline Gumbs, African American Studies scholar, “Prophecy in the Present Tense: Harriet Tubman, the Combahee Pilgrimage, and Dreams Coming True,” article published in 2014

q.s: Which of the following claims is best supported by the source?

o.l: Harriet Tubman’s actions in the Combahee River uprising served as an inspiration for Nat Turner and Denmark Vesey’s rebellions.
Harriet Tubman participated in the Combahee River uprising primarily by providing advice to Union Army commanders.
Harriet Tubman’s leadership in the Combahee River raid significantly influenced the overall outcome of the Civil War.
Harriet Tubman’s role as a conductor of the Underground Railroad was more important than her role in the Combahee River uprising.

f.c:
“In 1863, Black Moses (also known as Harriet Tubman) achieved the first U.S. military victory organized and led by a woman, a decisive blow to a Confederacy that was at that time dominating and draining the Union. Source: Alexis Pauline Gumbs, African American Studies scholar, “Prophecy in the Present Tense: Harriet Tubman, the Combahee Pilgrimage, and Dreams Coming True,” article published in 2014

q.s: Which of the following pieces of evidence from the source best supports the claim that Harriet Tubman leveraged the social connections she had acquired in her previous anti-slavery work?

o.l: Harriet Tubman was known as “Black Moses” by the United States military.
The Combahee River uprising caused “irreparable damage to South Carolina rice plantations.”
Tubman gathered “a full year of intelligence" and used “eight of her trusted scouts” in planning the military operation.
Tubman’s success in the Combahee River uprising was the “first U.S. military victory organized and led by a woman.”

f.c:
“In 1863, Black Moses (also known as Harriet Tubman) achieved the first U.S. military victory organized and led by a woman, a decisive blow to a Confederacy that was at that time dominating and draining the Union. Most important, the Combahee River uprising—during which almost 800 enslaved people of African descent stole themselves to freedom, burned down thirty-two plantation buildings, and flooded the rice plantations that were the center of South Carolina’s confederate economy—could be called the most successful uprising against slavery in the U.S. The Combahee River uprising had the triple impact of achieving freedom for hundreds of enslaved Africans, causing irreparable damage to South Carolina rice plantations, and adding hundreds of black troops to the Union army’s campaign in the South Carolina stronghold of the Confederacy at a major turning point of the Civil War. It would not be excessive to say the 800 people of multiple genders and ages who enacted the Combahee Uprising, after a full year of intelligence and organizing by Tubman and eight of her trusted scouts, achieved freedom for themselves and played a key role in ending chattel slavery as a legal institutional practice in the United States."

q.s: Which of the following best describes the primary purpose of this excerpt?

o.l: To demonstrate that before the nineteenth century, more enslaved Africans arrived in the Americas than people from any other region
To highlight the cruel treatment white enslavers demonstrated toward their African captives during the Middle Passage
To show how the Atlantic slave trade affected the distribution of various African ethnic groups throughout the American South
To convey enslaved Africans’ suffering as they were being forcibly separated from their communities and subjected to inhumane conditions

f.c:
“Esi had been in the women's dungeon of the Cape Coast Castle for two weeks. She spent her fifteenth birthday there. On her fourteenth birthday, she was in the heart of Asanteland, in her father's...compound. He was the best warrior in the village, so everyone had come to pay their respects to the daughter who grew more beautiful with each passing day. Kwasi Nnuro [one of the men wishing to marry Esi] brought sixty yamsYams were an essential agricultural crop in West and Central Africa. They were often brought to community celebrations and rituals. [as a gift]. More yams than any other suitor had ever brought before. Esi would have married him in the summer, when the sun stretched long and high, when the palm trees could be tapped for winePalm wine is made of the sap of some palm trees., climbed by the spriest children, their arms holding the trunk in a hug as they shinnied to the top....
 

When she wanted to forget the Castle, she thought of these things, but she did not expect joy. Hell was a place of remembering, each beautiful moment passed through the mind's eye until it fell to the ground like a rotten mango, perfectly useless, uselessly perfect.
 

A [white] soldier came into the dungeon and began to speak. He had to hold his nose to keep from vomiting. The women did not understand him. His voice didn't seem angry, but they had learned to back away at the sight of that uniform, that skin the color of coconut meat.” 
 

Source: Yaa Gyasi, Ghanaian-American writer, Homegoing, historical fiction novel, published in 2016

q.s: Which of the following best describes the part of the enslaved journey that Esi is experiencing in the passage?

o.l: The initial capture and enslavement before being forced to march to the Atlantic coast
The wait on the Atlantic coast before being boarded onto a ship
The Middle Passage, in which enslaved Africans were transported across the Atlantic
The final part of the journey, including being resold and shipped to plantations or other places of servitude

q.s: The inclusion in the passage of Esi’s memory that she “would have married him in the summer...” best supports which claim about how the transatlantic slave trade affected West African societies?

o.l: The ethnic warfare associated with the transatlantic slave trade politically destabilized many states located in the interior of West Africa.
Increased contacts with Europe led to the creation of new cultural traditions in West African coastal states that participated in the transatlantic slave trade.
Some West African societies experienced significant demographic and cultural disruption and loss of kin as a result of the transatlantic slave trade.
West African societies were generally less affected by the transatlantic slave trade than were societies in South and East Africa, such as Great Zimbabwe.

q.s: The statements in the excerpt about “other Persons” and a “Person held to Service or Labour” reflect the fact that the Constitution

o.l: enacted restrictions to prevent free Black men from voting
defined chattel slavery as a race-based, inheritable, lifelong condition
abolished slavery as being inconsistent with the ideals of the American Revolution
protected the institution of slavery without referring directly to enslaved people

f.c:
“Article I, Section 2

Representatives [in the United States Congress] and direct Taxes shall be apportioned among the several States which may be included within this Union, according to their respective Numbers, which shall be determined by adding to the whole Number of free Persons, including those bound to Service for a Term of Years, and excluding Indians not taxed, three fifths of all other Persons....

Article IV, Section 2

...No Person held to Service or Labour in one State, under the Laws thereof, escaping into another, shall, in Consequence of any Law or Regulation therein, be discharged from such Service or Labour, but shall be delivered up on Claim of the Party to whom such Service or Labour may be due.”

Source: The United States Constitution, 1787

q.s: Prior to the ratification of the United States Constitution, slave codes enforced in colonial America included provisions that

o.l: increased the overcrowding of slave ships with enslaved persons
provided a pathway to freedom for certain enslaved persons
denied enslaved Black people opportunities for upward mobility
allowed enslaved Black people to claim multiracial or multiethnic heritage

f.c:
“Article I, Section 2

Representatives [in the United States Congress] and direct Taxes shall be apportioned among the several States which may be included within this Union, according to their respective Numbers, which shall be determined by adding to the whole Number of free Persons, including those bound to Service for a Term of Years, and excluding Indians not taxed, three fifths of all other Persons....

Article IV, Section 2

...No Person held to Service or Labour in one State, under the Laws thereof, escaping into another, shall, in Consequence of any Law or Regulation therein, be discharged from such Service or Labour, but shall be delivered up on Claim of the Party to whom such Service or Labour may be due.”

Source: The United States Constitution, 1787

q.s: Which of the following developments could best be used as evidence to support the claim that resistance by enslaved people directly influenced how slavery was regulated in the Americas?

o.l: The United States government enforced a ban on the transatlantic slave trade.
South Carolina banned enslaved people from learning to read.
Free states barred the entry of some Black people.
Wisconsin granted Black men the right to vote.

f.c:
“Article I, Section 2

Representatives [in the United States Congress] and direct Taxes shall be apportioned among the several States which may be included within this Union, according to their respective Numbers, which shall be determined by adding to the whole Number of free Persons, including those bound to Service for a Term of Years, and excluding Indians not taxed, three fifths of all other Persons....

Article IV, Section 2

...No Person held to Service or Labour in one State, under the Laws thereof, escaping into another, shall, in Consequence of any Law or Regulation therein, be discharged from such Service or Labour, but shall be delivered up on Claim of the Party to whom such Service or Labour may be due.”

Source: The United States Constitution, 1787

q.s: Which of the following historical developments best identifies the letter’s significance to early generations of the African diaspora in the Americas ?

o.l: Many West Central Africans were Christians before their forced transport to the Americas.
The rulers of the Kingdom of Kongo were unable to limit the enslavement of West Central Africans.
The complexity of Africa’s ancient societies supported Africans’ independence from European colonialism.
Technological and agricultural innovations propelled the population growth of West Central African peoples.

f.c:
“We...sent to your Royal Highness a letter.... In it we recounted the great victory which Our Lord had granted us. We explained that our kingdom was already Christian and we asked your Royal Highness to send us several clerics or brothers to teach us and to help us spread the faith. We also sent...our son and...our nephew, so that your Royal Highness may have them educated....”

Source: Letter from Nzinga Mbemba (Afonso I), King of Kongo, to Manuel I, King of Portugal, 1514

q.s: Which of the following helps explain the process depicted in the excerpt?

o.l: African leaders primarily enslaved individuals from their own ethnic groups to maintain political dominance.
Interior states in Africa became wealthier as they provided captives for the slave trade.
Societies in Africa became more stable during warfare as new leaders rose to power.
The slave trade increased monetary incentives to use violence against neighboring societies in Africa.

f.c:
“[After a slaving raid in West Africa] the invaders then pinionedshackled the prisoners of all ages and sexes indiscriminately, took their flocksherd of animals and all their effects, and moved on their way towards the sea [on the West African coast].... Having come to the next tribe, the enemy laid siege and immediately took men, women, children, flocks, and all their valuable effects. They then went on to the next district which was contiguous to the sea, called in Africa, Anamaboo. The enemies’ provisions were then almost spent, as well as their strength. The inhabitants [of Anamaboo] knowing what conduct they had pursued, and what were their present intentions, improved the favorable opportunity, attacked them, and took [the] enemy, prisoners, flocks and all their effects. I was then taken a second time. All of us were then put into the castle [by the people of Anamaboo], and kept for market. On a certain time I and other prisoners were put on board a canoe, under our master, and rowed away to a vessel belonging to Rhode Island [in British North America], commanded by Captain Collingwood, and the mate Thomas Mumford. While we were going to the vessel, our master told us all to appear to the best possible advantage for sale. I was bought on board by one Robert Mumford, steward of said vessel, for four gallons of rum, and a piece of calicocotton cloth, and called Venture, on account of his having purchased me with his own private ventureinvestment. Thus I came by my name. All the slaves that were bought for that vessel's cargo, were two hundred and sixty.”

Source: Venture Smith, formerly enslaved African, A Narrative of the Life and Adventures of Venture, a Native of Africa, 1798

q.s: Which of the following claims does the author make about women in West and West Central African societies?

o.l: Women engaged in the transport of goods between West African kingdoms.
Women presided over the affairs of groups outside of their kingdoms.
Women actively participated in the political functions of their communities.
Women focused on the religious conversion of the subjects in their kingdoms.

f.c:
“Queen mothers often exercised considerable power. They helped enthrone and depose1 rulers...presided over court systems, and exercised state power in other ways....

A main avenue through which individual women exercised state power was by ruling, although most rulers of the period were men. Among the Mossi people of West Africa there was a legendary warrior queen, Iyennegi, who...is reported to have led a strong army in defense of Mossi lands....

During the early seventeenth century, a royal woman, Njinga...consolidated her power in the 1620s in the area of present-day Angola but was forced, due to Portuguese incursions, to move further eastward to Matamba. There she created woman-based rituals of state power and was able...to bequeath power to her sister. Njinga is heralded as a strong woman ruler and a heroine....

Women also exercised power through various roles in the state and community...they often held political offices that corresponded with those of men in a dual-sex political system.... In addition...women...were appointed to committees that provided checks and balances on the rulers’ power in centralized states or adjudicated2 important societal disputes among decentralized groups.”

Source: Cheryl Johnson-Odim, Women and Gender in the History of Sub-Saharan Africa, 2007

1:to remove↩
2:to make a formal judgment or decision about a problem↩

q.s: Which of the following best explains why the artist may have incorporated the image of Queen Idia’s mask into their artwork?

o.l: To honor and celebrate the connection between Africa and Portugal
To reconnect members of the Great Migration to their southern culture
To create artwork that connects modern African Americans to Africa
To create artwork that combines American feminism with traditional African subjects

f.c:
• The collage consists of 3 main elements:
    • On the left is a highly stylized profile view of a face.
      • The face is created from smaller photographs generally showing Black people involved in protests.
      • The face features a large oval eye looking up and a prominent mouth and chin.
    • In the center is a large hand holding a paintbrush.
    • On the right is half of an African mask of Queen Idia’s face.
      • The mask appears to be carved from ivory.
      • The mask features an empty eye topped by scars, a strong nose and mouth, and elaborately carved curling hair.

© Romare Bearden Foundation / Licensed by VAGA at Artists Rights Society (ARS), NY; Courtesy of Michael Rosenfeld Gallery LLC, New York, NY

q.s: The host’s assurance to Charles Ball’s enslaver that “at this time slaves were much in demand” most directly refers to which of the following developments in the early nineteenth century?

o.l: The economy of the southern United States was becoming more dependent on cash crops such as cotton, produced largely by enslaved African Americans.
The invention of the cotton gin resulted in the intensification of the transatlantic slave trade.
Some enslaved African Americans performed skilled nonagricultural work for their enslavers, working as blacksmiths, carpenters, tanners, and other similar occupations.
Enslaved people used religious beliefs and practices to resist the dehumanizing conditions and injustices of enslavement.

f.c:
[Charles Ball, recalling a journey from Maryland to South Carolina that he and other enslaved African Americans were forced to make with their enslaver, circa 1805]

 

“It was after dark when we arrived at our lodging place, which proved to be the house of a small cotton planter.... This man and my master had known each other before, and seemed to be well acquainted.... As they kept up a very free conversation, through the course of the evening, and the house in which they were, was only separated from the kitchen, in which we [the enslaved African Americans] were lodged, by a space of a few feet, I had an opportunity of hearing much that was highly interesting to me.... I here learned, that so many of us as could be sold for a good price, were to be disposed of in Columbia [South Carolina], on our arrival at that place, and that the [rest] would be driven to Augusta [Georgia] and sold there.

The landlord assured my master that at this time slaves were much in demand, both in Columbia and Augusta; that purchasers were numerous and prices good; and that the best plan of effecting good sales would be to put up each [of us] separately at auction, after giving a few days’ notice, by an advertisement, in the neighboring country.

Cotton, he said, had not been higher for many years, and as a great many persons, especially young men, were moving [to settle] in Georgia, prime handsEnslaved workers were in high demand, for the purpose of clearing the land in the new country; that the boys and girls, under twenty, would bring almost any price, at present, in Columbia, for the purpose of picking the growing crop of cotton, which promised to be very heavy; and as most persons had planted more than their hands would be able to pick, young [workers], who would soon learn to pick cotton, were prime articles in the market.”
 

Source: Charles Ball, Slavery in the United States: A Narrative of the Life and Adventures of Charles Ball, a Black Man, Who Lived Forty Years in Maryland, South Carolina and Georgia, as a Slave Under Various Masters, autobiography published in 1837

q.s: The journey described in the excerpt is best understood as part of which of the following broader historical developments?

o.l: The internal slave trade within the United States forcibly displaced over a million enslaved persons, often by moving them from the upper South to the lower South and the Gulf states.
The abolition of the slave trade in 1808 resulted in a decline in the enslaved population in the United States.
The economies of the North and the South became more interdependent as they both benefitted from the African slave trade.
Enslaved African Americans in different regions of the United States constructed a range of distinct local identities in addition to their shared identity grounded in the experience of enslavement.

f.c:
[Charles Ball, recalling a journey from Maryland to South Carolina that he and other enslaved African Americans were forced to make with their enslaver, circa 1805]

The landlord assured my master that at this time slaves were much in demand, both in Columbia and Augusta; that purchasers were numerous and prices good; and that the best plan of effecting good sales would be to put up each [of us] separately at auction, after giving a few days’ notice, by an advertisement, in the neighboring country.

Cotton, he said, had not been higher for many years, and as a great many persons, especially young men, were moving [to settle] in Georgia, prime handsEnslaved workers were in high demand, for the purpose of clearing the land in the new country; that the boys and girls, under twenty, would bring almost any price, at present, in Columbia, for the purpose of picking the growing crop of cotton, which promised to be very heavy; and as most persons had planted more than their hands would be able to pick, young [workers], who would soon learn to pick cotton, were prime articles in the market.”
 

Source: Charles Ball, Slavery in the United States: A Narrative of the Life and Adventures of Charles Ball, a Black Man, Who Lived Forty Years in Maryland, South Carolina and Georgia, as a Slave Under Various Masters, autobiography published in 1837

o.l: Family instability because of the constant danger of being bought or sold at auction.
The development of distinct African American creole languages such as Gullah.
The divergent ways slavery affected enslaved workers in different roles.
Resistance to enslavement through violent and nonviolent means.

q.s: The first paragraph of the excerpt best supports which of the following conclusions about Timbuktu?

o.l: It served as a center of learning in West Africa for many years.
Gender roles were important in maintaining the society’s history and cultural practices.
The Songhai empire was the earliest society to develop in West Africa.
The arrival of the Moroccans was part of the original Bantu linguistic expansion.

f.c:
“The Qadisjudge who interprets and administers the law and jurists of Timbuktu sent the Muezzinman who calls Muslims to prayer Yahma to greet the pasha, man of high rank or officebut...the Yahma did not offer the pasha the least hospitality. The pasha was extremely annoyed by his reception.... 

The Moroccans entered the city of Timbuktu on Thursday, May 30, 1591. They covered the city in all directions.... 

When the Moroccan army arrived...it found one of the countries that God had favored most in wealth and fertility. Peace and security reigned everywhere in all the provinces.... 

Everything changed at that moment. Danger took the place of security, misery replaced opulence.... People destroyed each other on all sides, in all places, and in all directions. There was...war....

These troubles endlessly continued and increased. [However, in the past, when the Songhai emperor was on the throne], no chief of any region dared attack the sovereigns of the land (Songhai), because God had dispensed so much vigor, audacity, courage, and majesty to their force...as has been seen in the recitationaction of repeating something aloud from memory of the history of Songhai.” 

Source: Abd-Al-Rahman Al-Sadi, description of the invasion of Songhai by Moroccans from northern Africa during the decline of the empire in the late 1500s

[However, in the past, when the Songhai emperor was on the throne], no chief of any region dared attack the sovereigns of the land (Songhai), because God had dispensed so much vigor, audacity, courage, and majesty to their force...as has been seen in the recitationaction of repeating something aloud from memory of the history of Songhai.” 

Source: Abd-Al-Rahman Al-Sadi, description of the invasion of Songhai by Moroccans from northern Africa during the decline of the empire in the late 1500s

q.s: Which of the following best describes the context in which these sources were created?

o.l: The period when formerly enslaved people were attempting to adjust to life as American citizens
Following the passage of the Fifteenth Amendment, which granted voting rights to African American men
Following Lincoln’s issuing of the Emancipation Proclamation during the Civil War
The era known as the "nadir,” when racial relations in the United States were at their lowest

f.c:
Source 1

“Of my son, Daniel, 15 or 16 years of age, who formerly belonged to Clinton Williams, Marshal county, Tenn., and subsequently to Harvey McRory. When last heard from was living in Memphis, Tenn. I am at present living at Unionville, Bedford county, Tenn., where I can be addressed, or the desired information can be sent to the Colored Tennessean, Box 1150, Nashville, Tenn....

ROBERT WILLIAMS.”

Source: Advertisement placed in The Colored Tennessean, an African American newspaper, 1866

 

Source 2

“Marriage Rules 

Section 5 

First Marriages and Re-Unions 

1. The marriage of all parties being together as husband and wife at the time of obtaining their freedom, or solemnized since obtaining it, will be acknowledged as legal and binding. 

2. All parties whose marriage was only a mutual agreement between themselves, with no public form of ceremony, are required to have their marriage confirmed by a Minister or Magistrate, and obtain a certificate of the same.

 3. No parties having agreed to enter the marriage relation will be allowed to live together as husband and wife until their marriage has been legally solemnized. 

4. All parties claiming to have been married but separated by the War or other causes and having no certificate of their marriage must obtain from some ordained Minister or Magistrate a permit for their reunion before they will be allowed to live together as husband and wife.”

Source: Freedmen’s Bureau General Order No. 14 issued in South Carolina, 1866

q.s: Which of the following best describes a reason population centers emerged in the Sahel and the savannah grassland regions on the map?

o.l: The Sahel and the savannah grasslands connected trade between communities in the Sahara to the north and in the tropical regions to the south.
The land in the Sahel and the savannah grassland regions was not fertile, so they relied on regional trade for agricultural products.
These regions were forced to expand agriculture to be self-sufficient because trade was not possible.
A lack of water routes through these regions protected population centers in the Sahel and the savannah grasslands from attacks by neighboring civilizations.

f.c:
• The map shows:

    • The northern half of the African continent and the following bodies of water:

      • Atlantic Ocean to the west

      • the Mediterranean Sea to the north

      • the Red Sea to the east

      • the Gulf of Guinea to the south

    • The Mali Empire, which extends from the Atlantic Ocean in the west inland across central West Africa.

    • The following geographic features:

      • Sahel in northwest Africa, and north Africa, and east Africa

      • Sahara in north Africa

      • Grasslands in central and east Africa

      • The Nile River in northeast Africa

      • The Niger river in central west Africa

    • Numerous settlements:

      • Most settlements are in west Africa within and around the Mali empire.

      • Some settlements are in north Africa, both along the Mediterranean Sea and inland.

  • Trade routes cross the western and northern portion of the continent as follows:

    • Trade included:

      • Craft goods: breads, ceramics, glass, silk, oil lamps

      • Enslaved people

      • Ivory

      • Metals: gold, copper

      • Foodstuff: spices, kola, food, salt

    • Select trade routes are described as follows:

      • A long-distance route between the Mali Empire and the settlement Fes in north Africa crosses Sahel and the Sahara and trades craft goods, foodstuffs, metals, and enslaved people.

      • A long-distance route between the Mali Empire and the settlement Ghat in north Africa crosses the Sahara and trades ivory, enslaved people, and metals.

      • A near-distance network of routes in west Africa between the Mali Empire and settlements like Benin City, Kano, and Takedda crosses the Niger River multiple times and trades craft goods, enslaved people, metals, and foodstuffs.

q.s: The main argument made in the excerpt is that

o.l: the institution of slavery is wrong and should be opposed
Northerners are mainly responsible for the spread of slavery
men are the primary victims of the inhumane conditions of slavery
slavery could not exist without the support of elite Southerners

f.c:
“There is a broad hall, situated in one of the most frequented streets of a large and well-known city in the South.... There are many gentlemen entering, and soon is gathered a large assemblage, by whom the chairs are occupied.... Four ladies, splendidly dressed...are [also] entering the hall....

“But, you will ask, for what reason is all this going on?... A SLAVE AUCTION! Great God in heaven! a SLAVE AUCTION! And that man upon the platform is the auctioneer!... 

“...The doors [are] re-opened, and...a large number of people...[enter] the hall. There are men, women and children, and some babies upon their mothers’ arms. Their color differs from that of the ladies and gentlemen sitting upon the chairs. Some are black..., some brown, some yellow.... Not one among all of these poor [people] will raise his or her head and eyes, to take a glance at the sitting assemblage. Some poor girls are weeping audibly, and all are looking sad—sad—sad! Reader, if you should happen to be of a gentle nature, take a glance at the little babies upon the arms of their poor and distressed mothers! Can babies feel their misery? Yes, indeed, they can. Every mother will endorse my words.... You, who have human feelings—you, who are no figures of cold marble—contemplate each of these one hundred and forty-nine descendants of Africa’s sons and daughters! Will you be still indifferent towards that ‘institution’ which degrades men to beasts, which is the deepest pit of barbarity?”

Source: John Theophilus Kramer, The Slave-Auction, published in Boston, Massachusetts, 1859

q.s: Based on the excerpt, Kramer would most likely support which of the following claims?

o.l: Antislavery efforts should focus on preventing the spread of slavery to new territories.
Slavery is not a benign institution but rather assaults the spirit of enslaved people.
The unique culture of the South requires the institution of slavery.
The principles of Christianity justify the existence of slavery.

Shaming readers by showing how goods that they purchase are produced by enslaved laborers
Appealing to readers’ emotions by showing the effect of slavery on enslaved women and children
Influencing readers’ beliefs with a fictionalized story about a character who is a formerly enslaved person

q.s: Which of the following best explains how the metaphor of the “color line” can be a helpful context for understanding Johnson’s argument?

o.l: The metaphor symbolizes the internal conflict experienced by Black authors; Johnson’s reference to the absurdness of African American characters highlights this conflict among Black writers.
The color line refers to racial discrimination; Johnson’s argument about the difficulty of moving away from comedic stereotypes of Black characters is an example of the rigidness of the color line.

The metaphor refers to the way African Americans viewed themselves and how they were viewed by white society; Johnson’s argument about the difficulty of developing serious Black characters is an example of the power of these perceptions.

The color line symbolizes the period in American history when race relations were at their lowest; Johnson’s hopelessness in the excerpt is an example of the impact of the difficulties African Americans faced in this period.

f.c:
“[The] generally accepted literary ideal of the American Negro constitutes what is really an obstacle in the way of the thoughtful and progressive element of the race. His character has been established as a happy-go-lucky, laughing, shuffling, banjo-picking being, and the reading public has not yet been prevailed upon to take him seriously. His efforts to elevate himself socially are looked upon as a sort of absurd caricature of ‘white civilization.’ A novel dealing with colored people who lived in respectable homes and amidst a fair degree of culture and who naturally acted ‘just like white folks’ would be taken in a comic-opera sense.... No matter how well he may portray the deeper passions, the public is loath to give him up in his old character; they even conspire to make him a failure in serious work, in order to force him back into comedy.... However, this very fact constitutes the opportunity of the future Negro novelist and poet to give the country something new and unknown, in depicting the life, the ambitions, the struggles, and the passions of those of their race who are striving to break the narrow limits of traditions.”

Source: James Weldon Johnson, The Autobiography of an Ex-Colored Man, 1912

q.s: How is Johnson’s perspective in this source similar to that of Paul Laurence Dunbar’s in “We Wear the Mask?”

o.l: Both authors discuss the role of Christianity in shaping perceptions of African Americans by white society.
Both authors discuss how African American characters in literature are depicted as comedic.
Both authors discuss African Americans’ separation from full participation in American society.
Both authors discuss the continuity and change in the representation of African Americans in literature.

Source: James Weldon Johnson, The Autobiography of an Ex-Colored Man, 1912

q.s: Which of the following claims can best be made based on information from the source?

o.l: The portrayal of African Americans in literature as happy-go-lucky individuals undermines racist assumptions about African Americans’ dissatisfaction with American society.
The portrayals in literature of African American characters who reflect white cultural norms are taken seriously, undermining society’s efforts to associate them with comedy.
The stereotypical depictions of African Americans in literature impede the progress of the race, hindering the reality of their genuine struggles and aspirations.
The focus of African American literature has primarily been on serious themes, leading to acceptance of the complexities of the African American experience.

f.c:

q.s: The status of the children described in the petition can best be understood in the context of which of the following?

o.l: Some enslaved people were bound to institutions, such as churches, factories, and colleges, rather than to an individual person.
To escape enslavement, many African Americans fled to territories controlled by Indigenous nations.
Like white enslavers, the Cherokee followed laws and customs that classified mixed-race offspring as property.
Enslaved mothers in the South were routinely separated from their children during slave auctions.

f.c:
“To your excellencies the Chiefs in council...my friends and brothers...


Being in possession of a few Black people...I debased myself and took one of my black women by the name of Daull, by her I have had these children named as follows, the oldest Elizabeth about the age of seventeen, the next John about the age of eleven, the next Polly about the age of even years. These [are] the only Children I have...and as the time I may be called on to die is uncertain, my desire is to have them as free citizens of this nationCherokee citizenship was traditionally inherited from the mother, so Tuskingo’s children were not automatically eligible to receive it.. Knowing what property I may have, is to be divided amongst the best of my friends [after I die], how can I think [of my children, the] bone of my bone and flesh of my flesh to be called their property...and for them and their offspring for generations yet unborn, is a thought of too great a magnitude for me to remain silent any longer. I therefore humbly petition... for their freedom.”
 

Source: Tuskingo “Shoe Boots,” military commander from the Cherokee Nation, petition to the General Council of the Cherokee, 1824

q.s: Which of the following statements best explains the fate of individuals such as Tuskingo’s children during the forcible removal of the Cherokee west of the Mississippi during the Trail of Tears?

o.l: They were removed along with the rest of the Cherokee while remaining enslaved.
They gained their freedom through volunteering to fight for the Union against the Confederacy.
They were declared free by the federal government because Indian Territory would be free of slavery.
They were emancipated by an amendment to the United States Constitution.

f.c:

Being in possession of a few Black people...I debased myself and took one of my black women by the name of Daull, by her I have had these children named as follows, the oldest Elizabeth about the age of seventeen, the next John about the age of eleven, the next Polly about the age of even years. These [are] the only Children I have...and as the time I may be called on to die is uncertain, my desire is to have them as free citizens of this nationCherokee citizenship was traditionally inherited from the mother, so Tuskingo’s children were not automatically eligible to receive it.. Knowing what property I may have, is to be divided amongst the best of my friends [after I die], how can I think [of my children, the] bone of my bone and flesh of my flesh to be called their property...and for them and their offspring for generations yet unborn, is a thought of too great a magnitude for me to remain silent any longer. I therefore humbly petition... for their freedom.”
 

Source: Tuskingo “Shoe Boots,” military commander from the Cherokee Nation, petition to the General Council of the Cherokee, 1824

q.s: Which of the following best summarizes the argument of the source?

o.l: The author should not be punished for fathering mixed-race children.
The Cherokee Nation must abolish slavery entirely.
The author’s enslaved children should be freed.
Chattel slavery is beneficial to society.

q.s: Which of the following statements best summarizes the author’s claim in the passage?

o.l: Abolitionists continued to fight against the system of enslavement despite pro-slavery legislation.
The passage of the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850 helped create the abolitionist movement in Northern states.
Escaped slaves who made it to Northern states were protected from re-enslavement by federal legislation.
The Fugitive Slave Act of 1850 had little effect on African Americans living in states that prohibited slavery.

f.c:
“The Fugitive Slave Law of 1850 inspired among many northerners a newfound sympathy for abolitionism.... 

Although masters used the law to recapture hundreds of runaways, many northern communities resisted it. In Buffalo, abolitionists challenged officials who captured an alleged fugitive named Daniel in the summer of 1851. Arguing that he was a free man, a large group—led by blacks—gathered at the courthouse and tried to liberate Daniel. After abolitionists filed a writ of habeas corpus, Daniel was released and fled to Canada. In Syracuse, the so-called Jerry Rescue again found local citizens openly defying authorities. The case centered on William Henry, an escaped slave from Kentucky who lived under the alias ‘Jerry’ before being seized by slave catchers in October 1851. Led by blacks, abolitionists stormed the prison and spirited Jerry away to Canada. For the next several years, local abolitionists celebrated Jerry's liberation day.

In 1860, still another high-profile case occurred in Troy, New York, where officials claimed Charles Nalle was a fugitive slave from Virginia. A throng of activists demanded Nalle’s freedom, including Harriet Tubman, a former slave from Maryland who was already a noted figure on the Underground Railroad. On her way to an antislavery meeting in Boston, she heard about the Nalle case and literally threw her body in the way of slave catchers twice to foil Nalle’s return to bondage.”
 

Source: Richard Newman, historian, Abolitionism: A Very Short Introduction, book published in 2018

q.s: Which of the following statements supports the claim that the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850 encouraged abolitionist sympathies in the North?

o.l: Most Northern states continued to restrict the rights of African American residents, including barring them from voting in elections.
Free African Americans living in Northern cities formed mutual-aid societies and Black churches to help them build stronger communities.
Northern state governments usually complied with southerners’ legal requests for the arrest and return of formerly enslaved persons under the Fugitive Slave Act.
Underground Railroad activists such as Harriet Tubman, who relied on northerners’ support, continued and often expanded their operations after 1850.

f.c:
“The Fugitive Slave Law of 1850 inspired among many northerners a newfound sympathy for abolitionism.... 

Although masters used the law to recapture hundreds of runaways, many northern communities resisted it. In Buffalo, abolitionists challenged officials who captured an alleged fugitive named Daniel in the summer of 1851. Arguing that he was a free man, a large group—led by blacks—gathered at the courthouse and tried to liberate Daniel. After abolitionists filed a writ of habeas corpus, Daniel was released and fled to Canada. In Syracuse, the so-called Jerry Rescue again found local citizens openly defying authorities. The case centered on William Henry, an escaped slave from Kentucky who lived under the alias ‘Jerry’ before being seized by slave catchers in October 1851. Led by blacks, abolitionists stormed the prison and spirited Jerry away to Canada. For the next several years, local abolitionists celebrated Jerry's liberation day.

In 1860, still another high-profile case occurred in Troy, New York, where officials claimed Charles Nalle was a fugitive slave from Virginia. A throng of activists demanded Nalle’s freedom, including Harriet Tubman, a former slave from Maryland who was already a noted figure on the Underground Railroad. On her way to an antislavery meeting in Boston, she heard about the Nalle case and literally threw her body in the way of slave catchers twice to foil Nalle’s return to bondage.”
 

Source: Richard Newman, historian, Abolitionism: A Very Short Introduction, book published in 2018

q.s: Which of the following statements most directly highlights the contributions made by free African Americans to the abolition movement?

o.l: Abolitionists filed a writ of habeas corpus to challenge the arrest of Daniel.
Groups who attempted to free Daniel and successfully liberated “Jerry” were led by Black people.
Southern fugitives from slavery had settled in Northern towns before being recaptured.
Abolitionists in Syracuse celebrated the anniversary of “Jerry’s” escape to Canada for several years.

f.c:
“The Fugitive Slave Law of 1850 inspired among many northerners a newfound sympathy for abolitionism.... 

Although masters used the law to recapture hundreds of runaways, many northern communities resisted it. In Buffalo, abolitionists challenged officials who captured an alleged fugitive named Daniel in the summer of 1851. Arguing that he was a free man, a large group—led by blacks—gathered at the courthouse and tried to liberate Daniel. After abolitionists filed a writ of habeas corpus, Daniel was released and fled to Canada. In Syracuse, the so-called Jerry Rescue again found local citizens openly defying authorities. The case centered on William Henry, an escaped slave from Kentucky who lived under the alias ‘Jerry’ before being seized by slave catchers in October 1851. Led by blacks, abolitionists stormed the prison and spirited Jerry away to Canada. For the next several years, local abolitionists celebrated Jerry's liberation day.

In 1860, still another high-profile case occurred in Troy, New York, where officials claimed Charles Nalle was a fugitive slave from Virginia. A throng of activists demanded Nalle’s freedom, including Harriet Tubman, a former slave from Maryland who was already a noted figure on the Underground Railroad. On her way to an antislavery meeting in Boston, she heard about the Nalle case and literally threw her body in the way of slave catchers twice to foil Nalle’s return to bondage.”
 

Source: Richard Newman, historian, Abolitionism: A Very Short Introduction, book published in 2018

q.s: Which of the following statements accurately describes one religious context of the Songhai Empire?

o.l: The conversion to Islam by leaders of some African societies often resulted in their subjects blending aspects of this introduced faith with Indigenous spiritual beliefs and cosmologies.
The conversion to introduced faiths like Christianity and Islam was generally forced on the African population by colonizers from regions outside of Africa.
While Islam was widespread in North Africa, Christianity was more common in West Africa, leading to long-term conflict between the two regions.
Syncretic religious and cultural practices were largely rejected by African leaders, resulting in near-universal acceptance of the non-African traditions in Islam and Christianity.

f.c:
“The Prince of the Believers, Askiya Muhammad, then asked the sayyidArabic title of respect to be his messenger to the Sultan of Mossiregion of West Africa near present-day Burkina Faso. The sayyid accepted this mission. He went to the land of Mossi and submitted the letter of his master, summoning the sultan to embrace Islam.

The Sultan of Mossi unwittingly declared that he first wanted to consult his ancestors in the other world. Consequently, accompanied by his ministers, he went to the temple of the idolimage or representation of a god of the land. The sayyid went along in order to see how one went about consulting the dead. First, the customary offerings were made. Then a very old man appeared. At the sight of him everyone lay prostrateflat on the ground and face down, and the sultan announced the object of his journey. Answering in the name of the ancestors, the old man said, ‘I will never accept such a thing for you. On the contrary, you must fight to the last man until either you or they have fallen.’

Then the Sultan answered the blessed sayyid. ‘Return to your master and tell him that between him and us there can never be other than struggles and war.’” 

Source: Abd-Al-Rahman Al-Sadi, Muslim historian from Timbuktu, “Songhai and the Moroccan Invasion,” Circa 1650

q.s: Which of the following best describes developments like those depicted in the sources?

o.l: Maroons attacked interior states to gain captives for their armies.
Revolts by enslaved people were often led by maroons.
People living in maroon communities rarely faced the threat of capture by enslavers.
Maroon communities carried out planned wars to protect their collective freedom.

f.c:
Source 1

Painting titled The Maroons in Ambush on the Dromilly Estate in the Parish of Trelawney, Jamaica. The maroons are armed and shown hiding behind trees in a forest preparing to ambush British soldiers who are marching toward them.

 

Slavery Images: A Visual Record of the African Slave Trade and Slave Life in the Early African Diaspora

 

Source 2

“[By the 1820s] maroons had kept the Dismal Swamp region [in Virginia and North Carolina] in a state of near-constant rebellion for decades. There was no question in many enslavers’ minds that their escaping property was endeavoring to reach the Great Dismal Swamp. Their fears were widely published in runaway ads. An understanding developed that some maroons sought scissionseparation from the outside world, while others were engaged in guerrilla warfare. Even those maroons who were not actively engaging with enslavers were doing comparable damage to the proslavery gospel that held African Americans incapable of survival outside of white oversight and as benefiting from and appreciative of their enslavement. That growing numbers of maroons were doing just fine on their own in the most inaccessible wilderness in America, arming themselves and even stockpiling weapons to turn against those who would enslave them, inspired terror.”

Source: J. Brent Morris, historian, Dismal Freedom : A History of the Maroons of the Great Dismal Swamp, 2022

q.s: Based on the excerpt, which of the following claims could best be made about the impact of the Haitian Revolution in the United States?

o.l: Laws put in place after the Haitian Revolution prevented armed resistance attempts.
The ideals of the Haitian Revolution inspired similar resistance efforts.
The success of the Haitian Revolution led to diplomatic recognition of Haiti.
Enslavers were inspired by the Haitian Revolution to loosen restrictions on the people they enslaved.

f.c:
“Among the [French colonists] who fled the colony [of Saint-Domingue during the Haitian Revolution]...were French slaveholders who were often accompanied by some of their human property....

Together, bondservantsenslaved people, masters, and mistresses boarded ships that dropped them on the shores of Cuba and various Caribbean islands as well as the Caribbean coast of South America and the United States. US planters rightly suspected that the political sensibilities of their own slaves, and of freedmen, would be affected.... For example, in 1800 an enslaved blacksmith, Gabriel Prosser, plotted a rebellion in Richmond, inspired in part by the example of Haiti. More troubles followed in 1811, as Haitian-born slave Charles Deslondes led a large band of enslaved rebels marching toward New Orleans in a failed attempt to conquer the city and overthrow the slavocracy. Then came Denmark Vesey, a free Black carpenter from Charleston, South Carolina who plotted a failed rebellion that inspired South Carolina’s Negro Seamen Act of 1822, which restricted the land movements of Black sailors for fear that they would spread ideas inspired by Haiti....

...It appeared that no locales could enjoy tranquility that had not respected the humanity of the enslaved or the full rights of the citizenship of free people of color.” 

Source: Westenley Alcenat, scholar, study of the Haitian Revolution, 2018

q.s: Which of the following claims best summarizes the significance of the pilgrimage described in the excerpt?

o.l: The display of wealth encouraged merchants to seek out trading opportunities with the Mali Empire.
The visit to Egypt led to its conquest and the inclusion of Northeast Africa in the Sudanic empires.
The pilgrimage caused the trade routes to immediately shift from the Sahara Desert to the Atlantic Ocean.
The pilgrimage marked the fall of the Empire of Ghana and the rise of the Mali Empire.

f.c:
“When Ibn Battutaa North African traveler first visited Cairo in 1326, he undoubtedly heard about the visit of Mansa Musa (King of Mali from 1307 to 1332). Mansa Musa had passed through the city two years earlier making his pilgrimage to Mecca with thousands of slaves and soldiers, wives and officials. One hundred camels each carried one hundred pounds of gold. Mansa Musa performed many acts of charity and ‘flooded Cairo with his kindness.’ So much gold spent in the markets of Cairo actually upset the gold market well into the next century. Mali's gold was important all over the world. In the later Medieval period, West Africa may have been producing almost two-thirds of the world's supply of gold! Mali also supplied other trade items—ivory, ostrich feathers, kola nuts, hides, and slaves. No wonder there was talk about the Kingdom of Mali and its riches! And no wonder Ibn Battuta, still restless after his trip to Al-Andaluspresent-day Spain and Portugal, set his mind on visiting the sub-Saharan kingdom.”

Source: Nick Bartel, “Journey to Mali: 1350-1351,” Office of Resources for International and Area Studies, University of California, Berkeley, 1999

q.s: Which of the following best describes a significance of spirituals such as “Steal Away to Jesus”?

o.l: They represent a blending of Christian and Islamic ideas to encourage resistance to slavery.
They reflect a combination of music and faith to express the hardships and hopes of enslaved people.
They serve to secretly teach literacy to enslaved people through the use of song lyrics.
They recount the memories and experiences of enslaved Africans transported to Brazil.

f.c:
Steal Away to Jesus

Steal away, steal away, steal away to Jesus!
     Steal away, steal away home,
     I ain’t got long to stay here....

My Lord, He calls me, He calls me by the thunder,
     The trumpet sounds within-a my soul,
     I ain’t got long to stay here....

Green trees are a-bending, po’ sinner stand a-trembling,
    The trumpet sounds within-a my soul,
    I ain’t got long to stay here,

    Oh, Lord, I ain’t got long to stay here. 

 

Source: Spiritual composed by Wallace Willis, an African American freedman formerly enslaved by the Choctaw Nation, mid-nineteenth century

q.s: Which statement best explains the significance of the author’s purpose in writing this article?

o.l: By attributing the unrest in northern urban areas to political corruption and economic competition, the author is dismissing white racism as a cause of violence.
By recounting the violent events in Chicago during the summer of 1919, the publisher is marking the official end of the era of the Civil War and Reconstruction.
By highlighting the role of the Great Migration in the rise of racial violence in the North, the author is blaming the African American community for the unrest.
By identifying the causes of the racial violence in Chicago, the author is resisting white supremacy through political activism and by publishing accounts of violence.

f.c:
“Many causes have been assigned for the three days of race rioting, from July 27 to 30 in Chicago, each touching some particular phase of the general condition that led up to the outbreak.... A background of strained race relations brought to a head more rapidly through political corruption, economic competition and clashes due to the overflow of the greatly increased colored population into sections outside of the so-called ‘Black Belt,’...where only a spark was needed to ignite the flames of racial antagonism. That spark was contributed by a white youth when he knocked a colored lad off a raft at the 29th Street bathing beach and the colored boy was drowned.

Four weeks spent in studying the situation in Chicago...seem to show at least eight general causes for the riots, and the same conditions, to a greater or less degree, can be found in almost every large city with an appreciable Negro population. These causes, taken after a careful study in order of their prominence, are:

  1. Race Prejudice. 

  2. Economic Competition. 

  3. Political Corruption and Exploitation of Negro Voters. 

  4. Police Inefficiency. 

  5. Newspaper Lies about Negro Crime. 

  6. Unpunished Crimes Against Negroes. 

  7. Housing. 

  8. Reaction of Whites and Negroes from War.”

Source: Walter White, assistant executive secretary of the NAACP, “Chicago and Its Eight Reasons," article published by the NAACP, a civil rights organization headquartered in New York, in their magazine The Crisis, 1919

q.s: The author’s eighth point, “Reaction of Whites and Negroes from War,” is best understood in the context of which of the following developments?

o.l: Many Black and white neighborhoods erupted into violence as a result of the fighting which occurred during the First World War.
After serving as soldiers in the First World War, many Black veterans returned home expecting to be treated with greater equality.
African Americans were largely unwilling to fight for a country that failed to protect their rights as citizens.
Newspapers in white and Black communities engaged in what could be characterized as a “war of words” during this period.

f.c:
“Many causes have been assigned for the three days of race rioting, from July 27 to 30 in Chicago, each touching some particular phase of the general condition that led up to the outbreak.... Source: Walter White, assistant executive secretary of the NAACP, “Chicago and Its Eight Reasons," article published by the NAACP, a civil rights organization headquartered in New York, in their magazine The Crisis, 1919

As an article authored by the leader of a civil rights organization discussing migration, this is an example of the anti-emigration ideas that emerged in the nineteenth century.
As an article published by a civil rights organization about white supremacist violence, this is an example of how African Americans defended their communities.
As an article published in a Black newspaper about racial discrimination, this is an example of the impact of Jim Crow laws on northern African American communities.

q.s: Based on Source 1 and Source 2, which of the following statements best exemplifies a goal of Harlem Renaissance artists?

o.l: The artists wanted to counteract negative stereotypes.
The artists wanted to create works of art that were accepted by white society.
The artists wanted to highlight the struggle African Americans face.
The artists wanted to show the conformity of Harlem Renaissance art.

f.c:
Source 1

“Women promoted self-respect through their organizations and clubs, churches, political movements, modeling agencies, beauty shops, and fashion shows. Photographs of women involved in civic and social clubs were also popular during this time and many were published on the society pages of black newspapers and magazines, as were advertising images for black hair and skin care companies. The result was a new visualization of the black woman. No longer seen only as laborers, black women were depicted as they wanted to be seen—as church leaders, educators, businesswomen, and models. Photographs of women during this time offer a vision of self-expression, self-determination, and assertiveness.”

Source: Deborah Willis, essay titled “Harlem Seen” in Harlem: A Century in Images, 2010

 

Source 2

Library of Congress

q.s: Which of the following statements best describes the purpose of photographs like Source 2?

o.l: To embrace the beauty in everyday Black life
To reinforce the notion of separatism
To advocate for legislation to create lasting change
To highlight suffering faced during the nadir

f.c:
Source 1

“Women promoted self-respect through their organizations and clubs, churches, political movements, modeling agencies, beauty shops, and fashion shows. Photographs of women involved in civic and social clubs were also popular during this time and many were published on the society pages of black newspapers and magazines, as were advertising images for black hair and skin care companies. The result was a new visualization of the black woman. No longer seen only as laborers, black women were depicted as they wanted to be seen—as church leaders, educators, businesswomen, and models. Photographs of women during this time offer a vision of self-expression, self-determination, and assertiveness.”

Source: Deborah Willis, essay titled “Harlem Seen” in Harlem: A Century in Images, 2010

 

Source 2

Library of Congress

o.l: Showing an all-Black team was a response to anti-Black violence during the nadir.
Celebrating Black achievement demonstrated the lack of need for further change in terms of civil rights.
Conveying Black athletes’ prominence exemplified their lack of opportunities in academic settings.
Highlighting the dignity of African Americans changed negative perceptions about their abilities.

q.s: Woodson set the foundation for which of the following future developments?

o.l: The establishment of historically Black colleges and universities
The creation of the field of African American Studies in the late 1960s
The emergence of schools for formerly enslaved children
The start of African Americans’ connection to Africa through art and literature

f.c:
“This book is an adaptation of The Negro in Our History...[for] children in the elementary schools.... 

The aim here is to facilitate the teacher’s task of preparing children.... The teacher must hold up before them the examples of their own people, who have done things worth while. Those who have no record of what their forbears have accomplished lose the inspiration which comes from the teaching of biography and history. 

With these things in mind the author has not only presented the essentials of this history but also extensive sketches of those who have done these significant things. In almost every chapter, then, will be found the story of some prominent figure set forth as a maker of history.... 

The teacher...should [also] keep on hand certain important books for reference. The most useful for this course are Kerlin’s Negro Poets and Their Poems and the author’s Negro Orators and Their Orations. In these two works are found most of the best speeches and poems of the large majority of the characters treated in this book. Both teachers and pupils will be interested in extending their knowledge of these persons by reading their productions.”

Source: Carter G. Woodson, Preface of Negro Makers of History, Washington, D.C., September, 1928.

o.l: Reconstruction, where many Black artists and writers exposed the horrors of racism through their works and writings.
the nadir, where Black Americans entered into new professions, such as in the field of education, after the abolition of slavery.
the Great Migration, where artists participated in a variety of new artistic styles of cultural expression in the Black community.
the New Negro movement, where Black educators sought to expand educational resources about Black leaders and innovators to people of all ages.

q.s: Explain how developments in the twentieth century influenced the field of Black Studies in colleges and universities in the United States.
Which of the following best describes the significance of Juan Garrido as a historical figure in African American Studies?

o.l: He was the first free African to leave what is modern-day Angola and journey to North America on his own.
He was the first free African to participate in the political decision-making of the Portuguese royal court.
As a free African, he explored what is today the United States before the first enslaved Africans arrived in North America.
As a free African, he protested the conditions in which slave traders began forcibly transporting enslaved Africans to Spanish America.

f.c:
Source 1

“I, Juan Garrido, black resident...of this city...appear before Your Mercy and state that I am in need of making a [petition]...a report on how I served Your Majesty in the conquest and pacification of this New Spain, from the time when the Marqués del Valle [Cortés] entered it; and in his company I was present at all the invasions and conquests and pacifications which were carried out, always with the said Marqués, all of which I did at my own expense without being given either salary or allotment of natives...or anything else. As I am married and a resident of this city, where I have always lived; and also as I went with the Marqués...[Cortés] to discover the islands which are in that part of the southern sea [the Pacific] where there was much hunger and privationthe act of depriving someone of something; and also as I went to discover and pacify the islands of...Puerto Rico; and also as I went on the pacification and conquest of the island of Cuba with...Diego Velázquez; in all these ways for thirty years have I served and continue to serve Your Majesty—for these reasons stated above do I petition Your Mercy. And also because I was the first to have the inspiration to sow maize here in New Spain and to see if it took; I did this and experimented at my own expense.”

Source: Juan Garrido, Petition to Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain, 1538

 

 

Source 2

“Other sources produce a similar litany of incidents that add up to overwhelming evidence of the black presence in the Peruvian Conquest. The first four non-natives to see the Inca capital of Cuzco in 1533 included a black man.... During Manco Inca’s [Incan ruler] 1536 siege of Cuzco, blacks labored to extinguish the fires on the roof of the royal palace.... A force sent from [the island of] Hispaniola to relieve the defenders included 200 Africans with military experience—a veritable squadron of black conquistadors.”

Source: Matthew Restall, historian, Seven Myths of the Spanish Conquest, 2003

q.s: Which of the following is a claim made by Holt and Brown in the source?

o.l: African Americans living in the South were the primary supporters of the abolitionist cause.
In the North, free African Americans developed institutions intended to enhance opportunities for all Black people.
Most African Americans chose to support emigration to Africa rather than advocating for their rights in the United States.
Free African Americans in the North were recognized as United States citizens while African Americans in the South were not.

f.c:
“Being a free Negro [in the 1800s] in a society organized to support racial slavery was an anomalous status, in the North as well as in the South. Free [African Americans] were legally free but not accorded full civil rights and freedom of movement. They were natives of American soil but not fully accepted as American citizens. The fact that most [African Americans] were held in bondage and that bondage was defended as their ‘natural’ condition undercut any claims to respect or equal treatment that [African Americans] who were legally free might make.... 

Racially yoked to their enslaved brothers and sisters, free [African Americans] alternated between struggles to abolish slavery and the impulse to emigrate to a more hospitable place [in Africa].... [Some] rejected this course [of emigration] as a betrayal of an American destiny for African Americans as well as of the members of their race who were still enslaved.... 

Despite the oppression they faced, free [African Americans] managed to build viable communities and institutions, such as newspapers, churches, and mutual aid societies.... Most devoted their energies and fortunes to the abolitionist cause and to ‘uplifting’ the race.... In their speeches and behavior began a tradition that would reach well into [the future]: the idea that moral respectability, noteworthy achievements, and material success of each individual member of the race enhanced the opportunities and recognition accorded to all members of the race.”

Source: Thomas C. Holt and Elsa Barkley Brown, historians, “Free Blacks Confront the ‘Slave Power’: The Meaning of Freedom in a Slave Society,” 2000

q.s: Which of the following is a piece of evidence used to support Holt and Brown’s argument about the ability of African Americans to “build viable communities and institutions”?

o.l: Free African Americans lived in a society organized around racial slavery.
Many free African Americans faced oppression in the United States.
Some free African Americans desired to emigrate to a more hospitable place.
Most African Americans devoted their energies to advancing the race.

When some free African Americans became wealthy, it made it more likely that white Americans would see them as equals.
The movement to encourage Black emigration to Africa was controversial among many African Americans.
Free African Americans promoted a form of Black nationalism that emphasized separation from white society.
