q.s: The presence of the building shown in Source 1 is a legacy of which of the following features of the Mali Empire?

o.l: Its role as a powerful military empire focused on widespread expansion of its territory
Its position as an imperial power facilitating the spread of learning and culture in the region
Its position as a West African leader in the trade of enslaved people
Its involvement in influencing East African architectural designs

f.c:
Source 1

Ellen Mack / Getty

One of Timbuktu's three great mosques, Sankoré Mosque, associated with Sankoré University, helped establish Timbuktu as the world center of Islamic learning from the thirteenth century to the seventeenth century.

 

Source 2

 

“Timbuktu...was an intellectual and spiritual capital and a centre for the propagation of Islam throughout Africa in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. Its three great mosques, Djingareyber, Sankoré and Sidi Yahia, recall Timbuktu's golden age.... 

Founded in the fifth century, the economic and cultural apogee1 of Timbuktu came about during the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. It was an important centre for the diffusion of Islamic culture with the University of Sankoré, with...25,000 students. It was also a crossroads and an important market place where the trading of manuscripts was negotiated, and...gold was sold.... 

The mosques and holy places of Timbuktu have played an essential role in the spread of Islam in Africa at an early period; the three great mosques of Timbuktu...bear witness to the golden age of the intellectual and spiritual capital at the end of the Askia dynasty; and the three mosques and mausoleums are outstanding witnesses to the urban establishment of Timbuktu, its important role of commercial, spiritual and cultural centre on the southern trans-Saharan trading route, and its traditional characteristic construction techniques.”

Source: “Timbuktu: Home of Sankoré University,” Africology: The Journal of Pan African Studies, published in 2016

1:highest point↩

q.s: Which of the following claims could be made about African American celebrations of Freedom Days based on the two sources?

o.l: African American communities refused to celebrate Freedom Days until those enslaved by Indigenous nations were also freed.

f.c:
Source 1

“The recent picnic which was held by the freedmen, last Saturday, the anniversary of the emancipation proclamation at the San Pedro Springs, was quite a grand affair, so we hear from different sources. Several hundred blacks were present on the occasion, besides a number of officers and soldiers of the army, and a few other citizens as spectators. A good deal of dancing was done by the freedmen, and a good deal...was drunk by the whole gathering, [and] some speeches were made.”

q.s: Which of the following claims about Juneteenth Day celebrations could best be supported by evidence from Source 1?

o.l: Juneteenth Day celebrations were held annually in African American communities across the United States.
Juneteenth Day celebrations mark the passage of the first document to mention “absolute equality of personal rights...between former masters and slaves.”
Juneteenth Day celebrations marked the ongoing struggle by formerly enslaved individuals to achieve the economic equality they had been promised.
Juneteenth Day celebrations in African American communities often included singing spirituals, feasting, and dancing.

f.c:
Source 1

“The recent picnic which was held by the freedmen, last Saturday, the anniversary of the emancipation proclamation at the San Pedro Springs, was quite a grand affair, so we hear from different sources. Several hundred blacks were present on the occasion, besides a number of officers and soldiers of the army, and a few other citizens as spectators. A good deal of dancing was done by the freedmen, and a good deal...was drunk by the whole gathering, [and] some speeches were made.” 

Article in the Southern Intelligencer, a newspaper published in Austin, Texas, June 21, 1866 

 

Source 2

MSS0281-PH037, MSS 0281 Reverend Jack Yates Family and Antioch Baptist Church Collection 1872-1986, African American History Research Center, Houston Public Library

q.s: Which of the following is a feature of African American Studies?

o.l: It analyzes the history, culture, and contributions of members of the African diaspora.
It focuses exclusively on Afro-descendants in the United States.
It is a subfield within the discipline of history.
It is a relatively new field that rejects the rigors of scholarly inquiry.

f.c:
“PERSPECTIVES

Black Studies is fundamentally transdisciplinaryrelating to more than one branch of knowledge. It is grounded in a range of traditional disciplines within the social sciences, humanities research, and natural and physical sciences. It exists not as a negotiation between or at the intersection of multiple coexisting disciplines, but as a separate yet integrated discipline concerned with questions that both encompassinclude and transcendgo beyond the individual fields, yielding areas of discoveries that offer unique research models, fresh synthesescombinations of ideas, theoretical frameworks, methods, and insights applied to rigorous interrogation of all of human existence. It is an expansive, inclusive field of study.

Further, Black scholars have defined, articulated, and elaborated legitimate areas of scholarship, circumventinggoing around the restrictions of narrowly defined disciplines. The innovations of Black Studies research provide distinctive angles and critical perspectives from which facts and experiences are analyzed, presented, and written about.”

Source: Jacqueline Bobo, Cynthia Hudley, and Claudine Michel, The Black Studies Reader, 2004

African American Studies cannot include the study of early African history because most early African history was not documented and is therefore unknowable to modern scholars.
African history is essential to African American Studies only as it relates to the transatlantic slave trade in forming African American experiences and identities.
African history is a critical theme of African American Studies so that scholars can correct misconceptions about early African history.

[Joel] Light agrees to furnish the land [for farming] and horses and tools...[and supplies to farm and to give Tom and his wife] one third of the crop they...cultivate. q.s:
Respond to parts A, B, C, and D.

 

  1. Describe one claim made in the source. 

  2. Describe a broader historical context of the source. 

  3. Using one specific example, explain how a development described in the source influenced Black culture. 

  4. Briefly explain how a development described in the source influenced the development of African American Studies.

f.c:
“The literature speaks to the tension within, say, the family; or it deals with the nature of black manhood. At other times, [it] seems directed against an unseen white enemy; it is, in fact, an attack on the Uncle Tomism of the older generation. 

The tension, or double-consciousness, is most often resolved in violence, simply because the nature of our existence in America has been one of violence. In some cases, the tension resolves in recognizing the beauty and love within Black America itself. No, not a new ‘Negritude,’ but a profound sense of a unique and beautiful culture; and a sense that there are many spiritual areas to explore within this culture. This is a kind of separation but there is no tension about it. There is a kind of peace in the separation. This peace may be threatened by the realities of the beast-world, but yet, it is lived as fully as life can be lived. This sense of a haven in blackness is found most often in the poetry selections.”

Source: Larry Neal, scholar of African American theater and contributor to the Black Arts movement, Black Fire: An Anthology of Afro-American Writing, 1968

q.s: Which of the following most contributed to the success of the “counterrevolution” described in the excerpt?

o.l: Special Field Orders No. 15
The Freedmen’s Bureau
Violence and intimidation
The Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution

f.c:
“One of the most shocking things to realize about Reconstruction is how painfully short it was, compared to the dreadfully long duration of slavery.... It was clearly on the road to ending by [1873]...and suffered a devastating political blow...with the Compromise of 1877.... 

The process of Reconstruction involved nothing less than the monumental effort to create a biracial democracy out of the wreckage of the rebellion. Though that effort ultimately was thwarted, Reconstruction saw the passage of a vast array of legislation aimed at transforming the status of the formerly enslaved....

Over time, the federal military occupation that enabled the nation’s bold experiment...lost support among the cost-conscious and war-weary parts of the political and economic leadership in the North.... Year after year, election after election, the counterrevolution led by white Southern Democrats only intensified.... Eventually [Southern state] governments...would bring the African American people to...‘the nadir’—the rock-bottom lowest point in American race relations.”

Source: Henry Louis Gates, Jr., scholar, Stony the Road: Reconstruction, White Supremacy, and the Rise of Jim Crow, 2019

On Juneteenth, enslaved people in Galveston, Texas were informed about their freedom and the end of slavery.
The American Colonization Society began to advocate for the relocation of formerly enslaved people to West Africa.

q.s: Which of the following best describes the author’s characterization of Baker’s perspective on the Black Freedom movement?

o.l: Activism is most effective when oppressed societal groups form alliances and implement change from the top down.
Change can only happen when leaders focus on solving the problems of African Americans before trying to solve other problems.
Activism requires exploiting flaws and forcing political leaders to advocate for fair treatment of African American citizens.
Change involves correcting a set of societal problems that could limit people’s ability to participate as equal citizens.

f.c:
“For Ella Baker...her activism within the black freedom struggle was not simply a matter of identity but rather a part of a political analysis that recognized...racism as the cornerstone of an unjust social and economic order in the United States extending back to slavery. A movement for black freedom...would inevitably be a movement against economic exploitation and the oppressive conditions faced by other groups within American society as well.... African Americans and...other peoples of color were excluded from basic access to the political process, marginalized socially, and super-exploited economically for the better part of the twentieth century. If this contradiction could not be confronted, Baker felt, there was no hope for American society as a whole. More precisely, she felt that to push and challenge political and economic leaders on this question would expose some of the society’s fundamental flaws and serve as an impetus for transformative social change.”

Source: Barbara Ransby, Ella Baker and the Black Freedom Movement: A Radical Democratic Vision, 2003

African Americans experienced “double consciousness” in an oppressive society with unequal realities.
African Americans fought in the First and Second World Wars as volunteers for no pay.

f.c:
“For Ella Baker...her activism within the black freedom struggle was not simply a matter of identity but rather a part of a political analysis that recognized...racism as the cornerstone of an unjust social and economic order in the United States extending back to slavery. A movement for black freedom...would inevitably be a movement against economic exploitation and the oppressive conditions faced by other groups within American society as well.... q.s: Which of the following claims about Baker’s activism is supported by the source?

o.l: It was met with backlash from other civil rights groups.
It would reach beyond the immediate goal of African American empowerment.
It led to the creation of other activism groups such as the UNIA.
It was inspired by the tenets of the developing Afrofuturist movement.

f.c:
“For Ella Baker...her activism within the black freedom struggle was not simply a matter of identity but rather a part of a political analysis that recognized...racism as the cornerstone of an unjust social and economic order in the United States extending back to slavery. A movement for black freedom...would inevitably be a movement against economic exploitation and the oppressive conditions faced by other groups within American society as well.... African Americans and...other peoples of color were excluded from basic access to the political process, marginalized socially, and super-exploited economically for the better part of the twentieth century. If this contradiction could not be confronted, Baker felt, there was no hope for American society as a whole. More precisely, she felt that to push and challenge political and economic leaders on this question would expose some of the society’s fundamental flaws and serve as an impetus for transformative social change.”

Source: Barbara Ransby, Ella Baker and the Black Freedom Movement: A Radical Democratic Vision, 2003

q.s: Which of the following best describes the sentiments expressed in Source 1 regarding emigration?

o.l: African Americans would achieve liberation if they emigrated to a nation that provided equality to all.
African Americans should support the opportunity presented by the colonization efforts of the United States government.
African Americans believed that emigration was an attempt to prevent access to citizenship in the United States.
African Americans’ support of emigration would prevent them from retaining their ethnic identity.

f.c:
Source 1

“Mr. Editor—I am happy to learn that the sentiments of some of my...brethren are in accordance with my own....

The government of these United States is not the only one in this hemisphere that offers equal rights to men; but there are others under whose protection we may safely reside...and where our rights will not be continually trampled upon.... We profess to be republicans...but wherein do we show our republican spirit, by sitting still and sighing for that liberty...or in hoping that in some fifty or a hundred years...our children’s children will be made free? I...believe that the time has arrived when we...ought to manifest that spirit of independence...by leaving the land of oppression and emigrating where we may be received and treated as brothers...we may acquire education, wealth, and respectability....

Some of your readers may inquire, where is that country to which we may remove, and thus become free and equal? I believe that country to be Mexico. [Mexico] is an independent nation, where indeed ‘all men are born free and equal,’ possessing those inalienable rights which our constitution guarantees...whereas in this country we...cannot aspire to anything more than what we always have been.” 

Source: “Emigration to Mexico” by “A Colored Female of Philadelphia,” letter to The Liberator, 1832 

 

Source 2

“Frederick Douglass...briefly contemplated emigration.... As he explained, ‘We propose to act in view of the settled fact that many...[African Americans] are already resolved to look for homes beyond the boundaries of the United States, and that most of their minds are turned towards Haiti.’ Yet, in a powerful stroke of fate, Douglass never made the journey to Haiti; before they had a chance to embark, shots were fired at Fort Sumter and the Civil War commenced. The war prompted Douglass and many other Black leaders to relinquish their emigration schemes...in hopes that slavery might be vanquished and the battle for suffrage might eventually succeed. As Douglass explained, ‘This is no time for us to leave the country.... We shall stay here and watch the current of events, and serve the cause of freedom and mankind.’ In July of 1861, Frederick Douglass simply declared bluntly and unequivocally: ‘I am not an Emigrationist.’”

Source: Leslie M. Alexander, historian, “‘The Black Republic’: The Influence of the Haitian Revolution on Northern Black Political Consciousness, 1816–1862,” 2010

q.s: According to Source 2, which of the following best explains why Frederick Douglass abandoned his support for emigration?

o.l: The ratification of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution secured citizenship rights for African Americans.
The Civil War created an opportunity to abolish slavery and achieve full integration for African Americans in the United States.
The federal government overturned Black Codes that prevented African Americans from accessing their suffrage rights.
The Fugitive Slave Act made movement within and outside of the United States too dangerous to encourage African Americans to attempt to emigrate elsewhere.

q.s: Which of the following contexts is most helpful for understanding the development described in the excerpt?

o.l: Under the task system on plantations, enslaved people were able to maintain some of their cultural practices.
Enslaved people participated in Spanish expansion in the Americas as conquistadores in hopes of gaining their freedom.
Many enslaved people had to learn new specialized trades and worked as painters, carpenters, and tailors in the Americas.
Due to the demand for enslaved labor, many enslaved people were forcibly relocated from the upper South to the lower South.

f.c:
“The conventional interpretation of rice history in the [colonial] Americas assigns Europeans the role of ingeniously adapting a crop of Asian origin to New World conditions. This perspective, however, ignores the role of Africans in establishing a preferred food staple under slavery. The development of rice culture marked not simply the movement of a crop across the Atlantic but also the transfer of an entire cultural system, from production to consumption....

...[Rice cultivation was] a knowledge system long practiced in West Africa [that] was brought with slaves across the Atlantic....Its diffusion has been misunderstood and misinterpreted in ways that diminished the significance of the African origins of the crop and of the people who grew the rice, processed the grain, and prepared the food. Recovery of this African knowledge system promotes our understanding of rice history in the Atlantic basin and the African contribution to the Americas.”

Source: Judith Carney, historian, Black Rice: The African Origins of Rice Cultivation in the Americas, 2001

q.s: Which of the following was a long-term result of the historical process described in the excerpt?

o.l: African ladinos increasingly became important intermediaries contributing to the growth of the United States domestic slave trade.
The southern United States moved from an economy based on cotton production to one based on rice production.
In the United States, the South and not the North benefited from enslaved people’s labor.
The labor of enslaved people came to be foundational to the United States economy.

Recovery of this African knowledge system promotes our understanding of rice history in the Atlantic basin and the African contribution to the Americas.”

q.s: Which of the following describes Carney’s primary argument in the excerpt?

o.l: Europeans had been growing rice in southern Europe for many centuries before they later taught West Africans how to cultivate it.
Rice cultivation originated in Asia, and Europeans learned how to cultivate this new crop and modify it for rice plantations in the Carolinas.
Enslaved Africans successfully adapted skills, knowledge, and cultural practices of West African rice production to New World conditions.
The introduction of rice cultivation to the Americas from Africa was notable only because it represented the movement of a crop across the Atlantic.

q.s: Respond to parts A, B, and C.

f.c:
1. African Americans are part of the larger African diaspora. While African Americans define their experiences as distinct from those of Africans, the idea of an African diaspora has influenced Afro-descended communities in the Americas. Describe one specific example of a freedom movement or practice that has been influenced by the idea of an African diaspora. 
  2. Using a specific example of a work of art, literature, or music, explain how African American artistic expression emerged in response to, or to celebrate, the idea of an African diaspora. 
  3. Explain how connections to the African diaspora shaped the lives of Afro-descended communities.

q.s: Which of the following most likely describes Thompson’s perspective?

o.l: As an African American born free in the North, he celebrates examples of successful self-emancipation.
As an enslaved person living in Maryland, he is angry about the spread of slavery to the North
As a self-emancipated person, he emphasizes the injustice and cruelty of slavery.
As a white abolitionist, he is encouraged by enslaved people resisting enslavement.

f.c:
“On the plantation was a slave named Ben, who was highly prized...[for] being...the best and most faithful servant on the farm.... 

One day...the overseer thought [Ben] did not drive his oxen fast enough....Ben attempted to comply, by urging his [oxen] to their utmost speed. But [it did not work]. As soon as they met, the overseer struck Ben upon the head with the butt of his whip, felling him to the ground.... Before he could repeat the blow, Ben sprang from the ground, seized his [attacker and started] choking and beating him.... 

When [the overseer]...recovered...he [went inside and told the slave owner what had happened].... Ben...fled to the woods, where he remained about three weeks.

[When he was captured] Ben was soon bound in hemprope...[and] led to the place of torture, where he was whipped.... Poor Ben! his crime, according to the laws of Maryland, was punishable with death; a penalty far more merciful than the one he received....

Ben was a brave fellow, nor did this flogging lessen his bravery in the least. Nor is Ben the only brave slave at the South; there are many there who would rather be shot than whipped by any man.”  

Source: John Thompson, The Life of John Thompson, a Fugitive Slave; Containing His History of 25 Years in Bondage, and His Providential Escape. Written by Himself,  1856

q.s: This source is significant because it provides an example of

o.l: enslaved people bringing skills to the Americas, including blacksmithing and basket weaving
the increased anxiety about revolts of enslaved people caused by the influx of Black refugees from Haiti
resistance by enslaved people including slowing work and self-emancipating
resistance that led to the well-organized rebellion by enslaved people at Stono

f.c:

Source: John Thompson, The Life of John Thompson, a Fugitive Slave; Containing His History of 25 Years in Bondage, and His Providential Escape. Written by Himself,  1856

q.s: Which of the following claims best explains why John Thompson included examples of violence in the source?

o.l: The acts of violence directed toward enslaved people in Maryland were unique and deserved to be recorded.
A strong sense of unity often developed among enslaved populations that routinely experienced violence.
Exposing readers to acts of violence endured by enslaved people was crucial to strengthening the abolitionist movement.
Highlighting the violence experienced by many enslaved people encouraged overseers to treat them more humanely.

f.c:
“On the plantation was a slave named Ben, who was highly prized...[for] being...the best and most faithful servant on the farm....

q.s: Which of the following best describes the way African American Studies scholars view the period between the end of Reconstruction and the beginning of World War II?

o.l: Freedom Days
The era of radical resistance
Second Middle Passage
The nadir

f.c:
Crusade for Justice

“The [Associated Press] article stated that...a committee of leading citizens had gone to the office of the Free Speech..., run the business manager...out of town, destroyed the type and furnishings of the office, and left a note saying that anyone trying to publish the paper again would be punished with death. The article went on to say that the paper was owned by Ida B. Wells...who was traveling in the North. 

Although I had been warned repeatedly by my own people that something would happen if I did not cease harping on the lynching of three months before, I had expected that happening to come when I was at home.... But fate decided that the blow should fall when I was away.... 

My friends declared that the trains and my home were being watched by white men who promised to kill me on sight. They also told me that colored men were organized to protect me if I should return. They said it would mean more bloodshed, more widows and orphans if I came back, and now that I was out of it all, to stay away where I would be safe from harm. 

Because I saw the chance to be of more service to the cause by staying in New York than by returning to Memphis, I accepted their advice, took a position on the New York Age, and continued my fight against lynching and lynchers. They had destroyed my paper, in which every dollar I had in the world was invested. They had made me an exile and threatened my life for hinting at the truth. I felt that I owed it to myself and my race to tell the whole truth.”

Source: Ida B. Wells, co-owner of The Free Speech and Headlight, describing events in 1892, from her autobiography Crusade for Justice

q.s: Which of the following best describes Wells’s and other African American writers’ responses to the violence described in the excerpt?

o.l: They advocated for the expansion of Black Codes as a means to protect African Americans from violence perpetrated by white people.
They worked to highlight the racism at the core of Southern lynching laws and protest the killing of Black people.
They used moral appeals to call on the Freedmen’s Bureau to protect African Americans from racially motivated violence.
They used the shock value of lynching to sell papers to white audiences and build economic success in Black communities.

f.c:
Crusade for Justice

“The [Associated Press] article stated that...a committee of leading citizens had gone to the office of the Free Speech..., run the business manager...out of town, destroyed the type and furnishings of the office, and left a note saying that anyone trying to publish the paper again would be punished with death. The article went on to say that the paper was owned by Ida B. Wells...who was traveling in the North. 

Although I had been warned repeatedly by my own people that something would happen if I did not cease harping on the lynching of three months before, I had expected that happening to come when I was at home.... But fate decided that the blow should fall when I was away.... 

My friends declared that the trains and my home were being watched by white men who promised to kill me on sight. They also told me that colored men were organized to protect me if I should return. They said it would mean more bloodshed, more widows and orphans if I came back, and now that I was out of it all, to stay away where I would be safe from harm. 

Because I saw the chance to be of more service to the cause by staying in New York than by returning to Memphis, I accepted their advice, took a position on the New York Age, and continued my fight against lynching and lynchers. They had destroyed my paper, in which every dollar I had in the world was invested. They had made me an exile and threatened my life for hinting at the truth. I felt that I owed it to myself and my race to tell the whole truth.”

Source: Ida B. Wells, co-owner of The Free Speech and Headlight, describing events in 1892, from her autobiography Crusade for Justice

q.s: Which of the following best describes a historical context for the excerpt?

o.l: Jim Crow laws enforced racial segregation in the United States, which caused white people in the South to feel more justified in racial attacks.
The election of 1876 ended Reconstruction but increased legal protections for recently freed African Americans, contributing to anger among white Southerners.
The Supreme Court’s ruling in Plessy v. Ferguson introduced the doctrine of “separate but equal” allowing Black businesses to challenge their white counterparts.
Union Army field orders provided so many southern Black people with land and education that white Southerners felt disinherited.

f.c:
Crusade for Justice

“The [Associated Press] article stated that...a committee of leading citizens had gone to the office of the Free Speech..., run the business manager...out of town, destroyed the type and furnishings of the office, and left a note saying that anyone trying to publish the paper again would be punished with death. The article went on to say that the paper was owned by Ida B. Wells...who was traveling in the North. 

Although I had been warned repeatedly by my own people that something would happen if I did not cease harping on the lynching of three months before, I had expected that happening to come when I was at home.... But fate decided that the blow should fall when I was away.... 

My friends declared that the trains and my home were being watched by white men who promised to kill me on sight. They also told me that colored men were organized to protect me if I should return. They said it would mean more bloodshed, more widows and orphans if I came back, and now that I was out of it all, to stay away where I would be safe from harm. 

Because I saw the chance to be of more service to the cause by staying in New York than by returning to Memphis, I accepted their advice, took a position on the New York Age, and continued my fight against lynching and lynchers. They had destroyed my paper, in which every dollar I had in the world was invested. They had made me an exile and threatened my life for hinting at the truth. I felt that I owed it to myself and my race to tell the whole truth.”

Source: Ida B. Wells, co-owner of The Free Speech and Headlight, describing events in 1892, from her autobiography Crusade for Justice

q.s: Which of the following best explains the overall purpose of Frances Ellen Watkins Harper’s poem?

o.l: To convey the physical and emotional harm experienced by those sold at slave auction, thus supporting the cause of abolition
To document the full scope of abuses inflicted on enslaved African Americans by their enslavers, thus undermining justifications for slavery
To analyze the economic impact of the slave auctions on the economy of the American South, thus promoting economic change
To advocate for the replacement of slave auctions with a system of selling enslaved workers at fixed prices, thus encouraging better treatment

f.c:
The Slave Auction

The sale began—young girls were there,

Defenseless in their wretchedness,

Whose stifled sobs of deep despair

Revealed their anguish and distress.

 

And mothers stood with streaming eyes,

And saw their dearest children sold;

Unheeded rose their bitter cries,

While tyrants bartered them for gold.

 

And woman, with her love and truth—

For these in sableblack forms may dwell—

Gaz'd on the husband of her youth,

With anguish none may paint or tell.

 

And men, whose sole crime was their hue,

The impress of their maker's hand,

And frail and shrinking children, too,

Were gathered in that mournful band.

 

Ye who have laid your love to rest,

And wept above their lifeless claybody,

Know not the anguish of that breast,

Whose lov'd are rudely torn away.

 

Ye may not know how desolate

Are bosoms rudely forced to part,

And how a dull and heavy weight

Will press the life-drops from the heart.

 

Frances Ellen Watkins Harper, free African American poet and social activist, poem published in 1854

o.l: celebrate the resilience of enslaved African Americans by focusing on individuals fighting against slave auctions
highlight important age- and gender-specific differences in the experiences of enslaved African Americans by examining the treatment of young girls, mothers, and men
advance the cause of abolition by emphasizing the shared humanity of enslaved African Americans
argue that the experience of losing a family member by being separated from them through enslavement was much better than experiencing the death of a family member

q.s: According to the source, which of the following is a reason given by Simmons for the call to action?

o.l: To celebrate the success of manumission societies in elevating African Americans
To increase moral behavior among African Americans in Northern communities
To stop the ongoing oppression of future generations of African Americans
To prevent the expansion of plantation agriculture in Northern states

f.c:
“The basis of the manumission society was to elevate Africans by morals, and this has been formed upwards of a half century, and what has been done? Our people were slaves then and are the same today; this northern freedom is nothing but a nickname for northern slavery, and it was but a speculative policy in making us the free slaves of the north, being the climate would not suffer a sugar plantation, a coffee or a rice field, the master found it to be a good speculation in making us the free slaves of the north.... 

Is it possible that this foolish thought of moral elevation suffers us to remain inactive? If so, then remain inactive, and you but raise another generation of slaves, and your children’s children to the last posterity will spend their lives in as bitter oppression as we do now today....

Remain inactive, and the almighty himself will spurn you, for lack of courage and not using properly your agency. No, we must show ACTION! ACTION! ACTION! and our will to be, or not to be; this we study, this we must physically practice, and we will be in truth an independent people.”

Source: Peter Paul Simmons African American abolitionist, “We Must Remain Active,” speech delivered to African Clarkson Association of New York City, 1839

Afro-descendant women embraced Queen Idia as a symbol of resistance and leadership.

Many in the African diaspora came to believe that ending enslavement by appealing to ethics had failed.

As a resident of the North in the early 1800s, Simmons may not have known many details about the extent of slavery or the treatment of enslaved people in the South.

q.s: Which of the following explains a reason scholars began to produce “radical reinterpretations” of Black history?

o.l: To educate people on the common history that most African countries share
To challenge prevailing myths about the lack of contributions of Afro-descendants
To develop volumes of work on the enduring connections between Africa and Europe
To highlight early explorations of Africa by mainstream scholars

f.c:
“Black Studies, as a socially engaged field of scholarly inquiry, is the progeny1 of centuries of research that seeks to redress long-standing misconceptions of Black inferiority, African heritage, and cultural significance. As early as the nineteenth century, groundbreaking volumes containing radical reinterpretations of Black history were published....  

Historic social justice movements...led to fundamental alterations in...institutions of higher learning. The first contemporary initiatives toward the establishment of Black Studies programs on college campuses were ignited at Merritt Junior College in Oakland, California, in 1963.... Between 1968 and 1975 over five hundred academic units (programs and departments) offering Black Studies courses were in place across the country.... Black students and other students of color...challenged mainstream scholarly discourse.”

Source: Jacqueline Bobo, Cynthia Hudley, and Claudine Michel, editors, “Introduction,” The Black Studies Reader, 2004

q.s: Which of the following claims can most accurately be made based on the two sources?

o.l: Despite enslavement, African Americans were able to maintain constant contact with family members.
Traditional marriages were uncommon among African Americans in the period after the Civil War.
After the Civil War, African Americans worked to build family bonds that had been disrupted by enslavement.
Enslavers typically encouraged the development of strong family ties among the people they enslaved.

f.c:
Source 1

Collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, Gift of Louis Moran and Douglas Van Dine

 

Source 2

“WANTED.

Information of the present whereabouts of my two children Albert and Margaret Carpenter, who were sold away from me in the town of Madison Court House, Va., and taken by slave-traders to the Cotton States, several years before the breaking out of the late rebellion. 

At the time the boy was only nine and the girl eight years of age. I was told that one Dick Mulhundro sold my daughter to a Georgian planter. I never knew what became of my son; I trust in God that this notice may in some way restore these dear ones to my arms again. A letter addressed to me in the care of my son William Stewart, Hamilton, Ohio would reach my hands by my last marriage. My name was changed to Lucinda Keys, Hamilton Ohio.”

Source: Advertisement placed by Lucinda Keys in The Christian Recorder, a periodical published by the African Methodist Episcopal (AME) Church,  1877.

q.s: Which of the following claims can be supported by Source 2?

o.l: Indigenous nations enslaved people but only for domestic work inside of their homes.
Indigenous nations practiced slavery that was more brutal than that of white enslavers.
Indigenous nations enslaved people using many of the same justifications as white enslavers.
Indigenous nations did not allow their enslaved laborers to buy their freedom.

f.c:
Source 1

Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, Manuscripts, Archives and Rare Books Division, The New York Public Library.

 

Source 2

“From the late eighteenth century through the end of the U.S. Civil War, Choctaw and ChickasawTwo of the five large Indigenous nations men and women held people of African descent in slavery. Like their white southern counterparts, Indians bought, sold, owned, and exploited black people’s labor and reproduction for economic and social gain. Choctaws and Chickasaws purchased slaves—men, women, and children—to work on their Mississippi farms and plantations and to serve in their homes. Slaveholders and those who did not own slaves embraced a racial ideology that affirmed black people’s inherent difference and inferiority and thus justified their enslavement.... Enslaved people cleared and plowed fields, hauled logs, drained swamps, planted and harvested crops, drove wagons, built homes, wove fabric, sewed clothes, cooked meals, and cared for Indian children, all for their masters’ benefit.”

From BLACK SLAVES, INDIAN MASTERS: SLAVERY, EMANCIPATION, AND CITIZENSHIP IN THE NATIVE AMERICAN SOUTH by Barbara Krauthamer. Copyright © 2013 by the University of North Carolina Press. Used by permission of the publisher. www.uncpress.org

Slaveholders and those who did not own slaves embraced a racial ideology that affirmed black people’s inherent difference and inferiority and thus justified their enslavement.... Enslaved people cleared and plowed fields, hauled logs, drained swamps, planted and harvested crops, drove wagons, built homes, wove fabric, sewed clothes, cooked meals, and cared for Indian children, all for their masters’ benefit.”

From BLACK SLAVES, INDIAN MASTERS: SLAVERY, EMANCIPATION, AND CITIZENSHIP IN THE NATIVE AMERICAN SOUTH by Barbara Krauthamer. Copyright © 2013 by the University of North Carolina Press. Used by permission of the publisher. www.uncpress.org

q.s: The treatment of African Americans by Indigenous communities, as shown in Source 2, most directly led to which of the following developments?

o.l: Indigenous people became more welcome in southern society after their embrace of slavery.
African Americans began to create their own maroon societies separate from Indigenous communities.
Indigenous societies made it difficult for mixed-race people to be fully accepted.
Indigenous communities refused to allow African Americans to fight alongside them in resisting American expansion.

f.c:
Source 1

Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, Manuscripts, Archives and Rare Books Division, The New York Public Library.

 

Source 2

“From the late eighteenth century through the end of the U.S. Civil War, Choctaw and ChickasawTwo of the five large Indigenous nations men and women held people of African descent in slavery. Like their white southern counterparts, Indians bought, sold, owned, and exploited black people’s labor and reproduction for economic and social gain. Choctaws and Chickasaws purchased slaves—men, women, and children—to work on their Mississippi farms and plantations and to serve in their homes. Slaveholders and those who did not own slaves embraced a racial ideology that affirmed black people’s inherent difference and inferiority and thus justified their enslavement.... Enslaved people cleared and plowed fields, hauled logs, drained swamps, planted and harvested crops, drove wagons, built homes, wove fabric, sewed clothes, cooked meals, and cared for Indian children, all for their masters’ benefit.”

From BLACK SLAVES, INDIAN MASTERS: SLAVERY, EMANCIPATION, AND CITIZENSHIP IN THE NATIVE AMERICAN SOUTH by Barbara Krauthamer. Copyright © 2013 by the University of North Carolina Press. Used by permission of the publisher. www.uncpress.org

q.s: Which of the following was a likely purpose of Stewart in the source?

o.l: To promote violent resistance against slavery by Black Americans
To encourage activism by Black Americans for their rights
To recruit Black Americans to join maroon communities
To advocate colonization by Black Americans in Africa

f.c:
“Never will the chains of slavery and ignorance burst till we become united as one and cultivate among ourselves the pure principles of piety, morality, and virtue.... I am sensible of exposing myself to calumnymisrepresentation and reproach; but shall I, for fear of feeble man,...hold my peace? Shall I, for fear of scoffs and frowns, refrain my tongue? Ah, no!.... O ye daughters of Africa, awake! awake! arise! no longer sleep nor slumber, but distinguish yourselves..... What examples have ye set before the rising generation?.... O, woman, woman, would thou only strive to excel in merit and virtue; would thou only store thy mind with useful knowledge, great would be thine influence.... You are not too far advanced [in age] to instill these principles into the minds of your tender infants....

How long shall the fair daughters of Africa be compelled to bury their minds and talents beneath a load of iron pots and kettles?.... We have never had an opportunity of displaying our talents; therefore the world thinks we know nothing.... Do you ask the dispositioncharacter I would have you possess? Possess the spirit of independence. The Americans do, and why should not you? Possess the spirit of men, bold and enterprising, fearless and undaunted. Sue for your rights and privileges.”

Source: Maria W. Stewart, Religion and the Pure Principles of Morality, the Sure Foundation on Which We Must Build, 1831

q.s:
Using the source, respond to parts A, B, C, and D.

 

  1. Describe one claim the King of Kongo makes in his letter.

  2. Describe one similarity or difference between the Kingdom of Kongo and another Sudanic empire between the thirteenth and sixteenth centuries.

  3. Explain how interactions with Portugal affected the Kingdom of Kongo in the sixteenth through eighteenth centuries.

  4. Explain how religious traditions of Afro-descendants in the Americas were affected by interactions with other cultures in the eighteenth through twentieth centuries.

f.c:
“Sir, Your Highness should know how our Kingdom is being lost in so many ways that it is convenient to provide for the necessary remedy.... 

Many of our people, keenly desirous as they are of the wares and things of your Kingdoms, which are brought here by your people, and in order to satisfy their voracious appetite, seize many of our people, freed and exempt men, and very often it happens that they kidnap even noblemen and the sons of noblemen, and our relatives, and take them to be sold to the white men who are in our Kingdoms...and others are brought during the night so that they might not be recognized.

And as soon as they are taken...they are immediately ironed and branded with fire, and when they are carried to be embarked, if they are caught by our guards’ men the whites allege that they have bought them but they cannot say from whom, so that it is our duty to do justice and to restore to the freemen their freedom.”

Source: Letter from King Nzinga Mbemba of Kongo to King João III of Portugal, 1526

q.s: Which of the following best explains the reason for the establishment of historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs)?

o.l: African Americans continued to face segregation and discrimination when applying to both public and private white colleges and universities.
The federal government and Jim Crow laws limited access to Black Greek-letter organizations in traditionally white colleges and universities.
African Americans believed advanced education could train them in resistance strategies, such as political activism and trolley boycotts.
The federal government sought to establish a system to promote African American involvement in the activities of the Freedmen’s Bureau.

q.s: Which of the following data would provide the strongest evidence to support the assertion that HBCUs allowed many African Americans to rise out of poverty?

o.l: The data regarding students joining community service clubs at HBCUs
The data regarding scholarship recipients by gender at HBCUs
The data regarding students’ access to education and training at HBCUs
The data regarding racial makeup of student populations at HBCUs

q.s: Which of the following conclusions can be made about HBCUs’ contributions to racial equity through the twentieth century?

o.l: By the end of the twentieth century, the Black Campus movement had encouraged stronger enrollment in HBCUs.
In the early part of the twentieth century, most African American women graduating from HBCUs served in political leadership roles.
By the end of the twentieth century, enrollment in HBCUs continued to offer African Americans opportunities to overcome gaps in racial equity.
Throughout the twentieth century, arts programs at HBCUs promoted global recognition for all students through international tours.

q.s: The political position illustrated by the authors emerged in response to which of the following?

o.l: The adoption of the legal doctrine of partus sequitur ventrem by most of the states in the South
The growing popularity of the ideas of emigrationists and plans to establish African American communities outside the United States
The emergence of cotton as the major cash crop produced by enslaved workers on southern plantations
The increasing importance of the domestic slave trade and the resulting migration of enslaved Africans to the lower South

f.c:
“If the plan of colonizing [Africa] is intended for our benefit...we humbly and respectfully urge that it is not asked for by us....

If this plan of colonization now proposed is intended to provide a refuge and a dwelling for a portion of our brethren, who are now held in slavery in the South, we have stronger objections to it.... 

The ultimate and final abolition of slavery in the United States is, under the guidance and protection of a just God, progressing. Every year [that passes]...affords new and safe assurances that the freedom of all will...be accomplished.... 

But, if this plan of colonization shall go into effect...[the] cords, which now connect [those enslaved] with us shall be stretched...until they break; and all the sources of...affection and connection which [shared] blood bestow, will...be no more. 

To those of our brethren who shall be left behind, there will be assured perpetual slavery [and] augmented sufferings.... The southern masters will colonize only those whom [they see as dangerous].... 

[As a result of colonization parents] will be torn from their children—husbands from their wives—brothers from brothers.... The shores of America will like the sands of Africa be watered by the tears of those who will be left behind. Those who shall be carried away will roam childless, widowed, and alone, over the burning plains of Guinea....

We humbly, respectfully, and fervently entreat and beseech your disapprobation of the plan of colonization.”

Source: James Forten and Russell Perrott, African American activists, “Address to the Humane and Benevolent Inhabitants of the City and County of Philadelphia,” 1817

o.l: The spread of abolition in Latin America and the continuation of slavery and racial discrimination in the United States
The expansion of European colonial control in Africa’s interior and the founding of white settler colonies in South Africa
The gradual codification of racial slavery in Indian Territory and the weakening of Black-Indigenous kinship and solidarity ties
The increased success of African Americans escaping enslavement and the establishment of maroon communities in the Upper South

o.l: The exclusion of African ambassadors from the painting demonstrates the increasing economic isolation of Africa in the sixteenth century.
The musicians in the background indicate that European empires relied heavily on the Atlantic slave trade as a source of plantation labor.

q.s: The source is an example of which of the following historical continuities following the Civil War?

o.l: New agencies, such as the Freedmen’s Bureau, were created at the state level.
African Americans were increasingly able to impact the policies of southern states.
Laws were still in place limiting the political power of African Americans.
Actions were taken by the Supreme Court to limit discrimination.

f.c:
“An Act to define and declare the rights of persons lately known as Slaves, and Free Persons of Color.

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That all persons heretofore known as slaves, and free persons of color, shall have the right to make and enforce contracts, to sue and be sued, to inherit, purchase, lease, hold, sell, and convey real, personal and mixed estate; to make wills and testaments, and to have and enjoy the rights of personal security, liberty, and private property, and all remedies and proceedings for the protection and enforcement of the same; and there shall be no discrimination against such persons in the administration of the criminal laws of this State. 

Sec. 2. That all laws and parts of laws relating to persons lately held as slaves, or free persons of color, contrary to, or in conflict with the provisions of this act, be and the same are hereby repealed: Provided, nevertheless, that nothing herein shall be so construed as to repeal any law prohibiting the inter- marriage of the white and black races, nor to permit any other than white men to serve on juries, hold office, or vote at any election. State, county, or municipal: Provided, further, that nothing herein contained shall be so construed as to allow them to testify, except in such cases and manner as prescribed in the Constitution of the State. 

Approved November 10, 1866”

Source: Chapter CXXVII, Sections 1 and 2, from Texas’s Black Codes, 1866

q.s: Respond to parts A, B, C, and D.

f.c:
1. Describe one feature of Afrofuturism.

  2. Describe one context that shaped the development of Afrofuturism. 

  3. Formulate a claim that summarizes the significance of Afrofuturism.

  4. Explain how the discipline of African American Studies differs from more traditional academic disciplines.

q.s: Explain why African Americans had limited opportunities to advance in society after the abolition of slavery.
Which of the following cultural practices provides the most useful context for understanding the development described by the author?

o.l: Migration triggered by population growth contributed to cultural change.
Linguistic diversity caused by trade led to the exchange of cultural traditions.
Religious change and continuity fostered syncretism through cultural blending.
Enslavement contributed to the diasporic process, which spread culture globally.

f.c:
“The first to receive baptism in the country were the Count of Soyo [uncle of the King of Kongo] and his son, who were baptized on Christmas Day of the year 1491.... A great many people...followed the example of their princes...[b]ut even though the majority of these [Africans] outwardly profess to be Christians, the greater number are still idolatrousworship of a physical object as a god in their hearts and secretly worship false gods, tigers, leopards, and wolves, imagining that in this way they will escape feeling the effects of their fury....[T]hey all have two strings in their bows—the Catholic religion and paganismnon-Christian spiritual beliefs, and when the saints do not answer their prayers, they invoke the fetishesobjects believed to have supernatural power. Yet to see them all covered with crosses and rosariesa string of beads used in Roman Catholic prayer one would take them for sanctimonioushypocritically devout people. When the Count of Soyo goes to mass, he dresses himself superbly and wears golden chains and collars of coral. He marches pompously to the sound of drums and horns, surrounded by guards among whom there are five or six musketeers who fire from time to time and others who carry flags and are followed by a great crowd of people.” 

Source: Olfert Dapper, Dutch geographer, “The Kingdom of Congo,” Description of Africa, published in Amsterdam, Netherlands, 1686

q.s: Which of the following best describes the perspective of the author?

o.l: As a Dutch missionary, he is proud of the successful conversion of West Central Africa to Christianity.
As a European Christian, he objects to the continuation of Indigenous religious traditions.
As an Indigenous religious leader, he rejects the spread of foreign cultural influences.
As an African geographer, he is pleased with the growing prosperity of West Central Africa.

q.s: According to Woodson, which of the following best explains racial biases in education?

o.l: The ways in which studies of Africa have been designed to justify the exploitation of African people and resources
A privileging of information about Europe and the marginalization of subjects pertaining to Africa
Condescension toward African American students that correlates to the condescension toward studies of African American heritage
The legacy of slavery negatively affecting African Americans’ expectations of themselves in educational pursuits

f.c:
“Until the students of the white race give the same attention to the study of Africa which they have given to the study of the history of Europe and Asia, they will be unprepared to reach any conclusions as to the sort of civilization which the Negro race has produced and its relative value. The fact is that the white man is still ignorant as to what has taken place in Africa.... Because the whites of modern times succeeded in finding in Africa slaves for exploitation at the time when the country was torn to pieces by wars of migrating hordes, they have concluded that these weak captives in war, whom they enslaved and debased, must be taken as a sample of what the Negro is capable of. Yet if the Negroes of this country are to serve as an indication of the capabilities of the race, it is both unscientific and unjust to expect the Negroes to pass through two hundred and fifty years of slavery and in three generations achieve as much as the whites have during many centuries. If they could, instead of thereby showing that they are equal to the whites, they would demonstrate their superiority.

To disabuse the public mind of this slander proceeding from ill-designing investigators, C. G. Woodson organized the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History in Chicago in 1915, hoping to save and publish the records of the Negro, that the race may not become a negligible factor in the thought of the world. The work of this Association is to collect sociological and historical data, to publish books on Negro life and history, to promote studies in this field through schools and clubs with a view to bringing about harmony between the races by interpreting the one to the other.”

Source: Carter G. Woodson, The Negro in Our History, 1922

q.s: According to the source, which of the following best explains the purpose in founding the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History?

o.l: To help document the history and contributions of people of African descent and therefore improve how they are perceived and treated
To serve as a meeting place for African American intellectuals to work on their research free from the discriminatory and racially charged gazes of people of other races
To inspire other African American leaders to create avenues for creative and artistic expression that are comparable to the association Woodson founded
To help inform research at historically Black colleges and universities so that they can compete for grants and other funding with predominantly white institutions of higher education

Different races have many unique intellectual standards.
One legacy of the institution of slavery was African Americans’ struggles in educational settings.
Some cultures value education more than others.

q.s: Which of the following best describes the perspective of the source?

o.l: As African American Freedman’s Bureau agents in Tennessee, the petitioners believe in equal rights for all of the citizens of the state.
As citizens of a southern slave state, the petitioners favor the reunification of the nation after the end of the war.
As former Union soldiers from Tennessee, the petitioners are concerned about financial compensation for their service in the army.
As African Americans loyal to the United States, the petitioners desire the right to participate in the political process.

f.c:
“Devoted as we are to the principles of justice, of love to all men, and of equal rights on which our Government is based, and which make it the hope of the world. We know the burdens of citizenship, and are ready to bear them. We know the duties of the good citizen, and are ready to perform them cheerfully, and would ask to be put in a position in which we can discharge them more effectually. We do not ask for the privilege of citizenship, wishing to shun the obligations imposed by it.... 

The Government has asked the colored man to fight for its preservation and gladly has he done it. It can afford to trust him with a vote as safely as it trusted him with a bayoneta weapon used in war. How boundless would be the love of the colored citizen, how intense and passionate his zeal and devotion to the government, how enthusiastic and how lasting would be his gratitude, if his white brethren were to take him by the hand and say, ‘You have been ever loyal to our government; henceforward be voters.’ Again, the granting of this privilege would stimulate the colored man to greater exertion to make himself an intelligent, respected, useful citizen.”

Source: Petition from 59 African American inhabitants of Nashville, Tennessee to state leaders, January, 1865

q.s: Which of the following statements best describes the purpose of the authors’ petition?

o.l: To encourage the ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment
To help overturn the Plessy v. Ferguson decision
To support the issuing of the Emancipation Proclamation
To encourage the ratification of the Fourteenth Amendment

q.s: Which of the following best describes the role of the Haitian Revolution in the history of the African diaspora?

o.l: It failed and discouraged additional resistance movements by enslaved people.
It was the only resistance movement by enslaved people that successfully overturned a colonial government.
It was inspirational to the successful German Coast Uprising led by Charles Deslondes.
It was successful and marked the beginning of a long period of prosperity in Haiti.

f.c:
“We need first to seize Le CapCap Haitien, a coastal town in Haiti in a spontaneous attack. By not giving them a chance to realize what is happening, we will surprise them with the help of the mulattoes and blacks, free and slave, on our side. And as Le Cap is the heart of the colony and its stronghold, once it is taken, the rest of the colony will be easy for us.... [Slaves from neighboring regions] will set fire to the plantations on their way to Le Cap. They will burn the big houses, kill the [enslavers], and seize their arms and ammunition, and then join their comrades...who will already be in front of Le Cap. This plot is known to all the slaves in the colony, it involves everyone, and the object is to take over the country.”

Source: François and Dechaussée, planning the start of the Haitian Revolution in a meeting at Lenormand Plantation, 1791

q.s: Which of the following best explains how the Haitian Revolution provides useful context for understanding the territorial expansion of slavery in the United States?

o.l: The cost of fighting the Haitian revolutionaries motivated France to sell its territory in North America to the United States.
With the end of slavery in Haiti, the United States increased cotton production to offset the decline of cotton production in Haiti.
Sympathy motivated the United States government to encourage the immigration of white planters from Haiti.
The failure of the Haitian Revolution encouraged supporters of slavery in the United States to expand the institution to the West.

This plot is known to all the slaves in the colony, it involves everyone, and the object is to take over the country.”

Source: François and Dechaussée, planning the start of the Haitian Revolution in a meeting at Lenormand Plantation, 1791

q.s: Which of the following best describes a connection between the Haitian Revolution and the United States?

o.l: For American abolitionists, revolution created widespread anxiety and deep fear about the growth of slavery.
For white Americans in the South, the defeat of a large-scale slave rebellion created a sense of security.
For some African Americans, Haiti’s independence highlighted the unfulfilled promises of the American Revolution.
For many plantation owners in the South, the fear of a similar conflict increased their support for the abolitionist movement.

o.l: Women played many key roles in West and Central African societies, including serving as spiritual leaders, teachers, market traders, political advisors, and farmers.
The adoption of Islam by leaders often resulted in their subjects blending aspects of these introduced faiths with Indigenous spiritual beliefs.

q.s: What evidence do the authors provide to show their opposition to the American Colonization Society?

o.l: The American Colonization Society needed more input from white abolitionists in order to be taken seriously.
The American Colonization Society needed more support from independent African states to be successful.
The American Colonization Society was created by enslavers to force Blacks out of the United States.
The American Colonization Society was founded before there was a law that abolished slavery in the United States.

f.c:
“The...Colored citizens and Ministers [of New York City]...have not been inattentive to the course of the Colonization meetings [here].... The sole object of these meetings was to act on the interests of the colored people.... [But] none of that class were invited to take part in them, and they have been carried on without any reference whatever to their wishes or opinions....

The Colonization scheme was set on foot...by Slaveholders, with the view...of perpetuating their system of Slavery, undisturbed. From the first, no very high expectations seem to have been entertained, that an enterprise, so unnecessary, so unnatural,...bearing about it so little of hope, so much of despair, would [re]commend itself strongly to that class of the community to which it purported solely to be addressed. But little reliance appears to have been placed on obtaining their voluntary consent to exchange for...Africa, this, the country of their fathers for generations, and of their own nativity...where, notwithstanding they were called to suffer many ills brought on them by others, they might yet live in hope, that the dark cloud of Slavery which had so long obscured the free principles asserted by our governments, would one day pass away and permit these principles to shine in all their warmth and effulgence, if not on themselves, on a not very distant generation of their descendants....

We ask you...whether you ought longer...to press on us an enterprise that we have unremittingly rejected from the first?”

Source: Samuel E. Cornish and Theodore S. Wright, African American ministers, public letter to political leaders in New York City and New Jersey regarding the American Colonization Society, 1840

q.s: The source could best be used as evidence to support which of the following claims?

o.l: Some African Americans expressed optimism for their future in the United States.
Free African Americans felt a strong kinship with Africans because of their common heritage.
Free African Americans in the North were disconnected from the issue of slavery in the South.
Some African Americans worked with state governments in the colonization scheme.

The American Colonization Society promoted a vision of American culture that was inclusive of Black people.

q.s: Which of the following conclusions can be made regarding maroon communities being located in areas that were ’naturally difficult [to] access’?

o.l: They were situated along the colony’s coastal regions.
They were located in remote environments beyond the control of enslavers.
They were guarded by former soldiers enslaved during the civil wars in the Kingdom of Kongo.
They were given protection as a result of treaties made with colonial governments.

f.c:
“There have been known to exist, for several years, settlements of runaway negroes...amongst the mountains and swamps [of Brazil].... 

The sites of these encampments appear to be carefully chosen to guard against a surprise attack.

The fugitives are said to be industrious in the cultivation of rice..and Indian corn, and in the manufacture of charcoal. They make canoes and...small sailing vessels, which are used for the interior trade. They carry on a traffic with the inferior class of tradesmen in the neighboring towns, exchanging the produce of their labour for certain necessaries, such as gunpowder and shot, cloth and soap.... Some of them are frequently known to venture into [Belém] at night, where they have occasionally been taken and claimed by their owners, who endeavor to sell them, but find generally much difficulty in doing so, the freedom of their wandering life unfitting them for slavery.

The situation of these encampments being naturally difficult of access, and the connivanceassistance afforded the fugitives by parties trading with them, have rendered the repeated attempts to capture them abortiveunsuccessful.”

Source: Report to the British government by a British diplomatic representative in Belém, a city in northern Brazil, 1854

q.s: Which of the following describes a context of the maroon communities described in the source?

f.c:
“There have been known to exist, for several years, settlements of runaway negroes...amongst the mountains and swamps [of Brazil].... 

The sites of these encampments appear to be carefully chosen to guard against a surprise attack.

The fugitives are said to be industrious in the cultivation of rice..and Indian corn, and in the manufacture of charcoal. They make canoes and...small sailing vessels, which are used for the interior trade. q.s: Which of the following best explains the development of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs)?

o.l: Government support for racially equal education led to the creation of universities using public funding.
Educational discrimination after the American Civil War led African Americans to found their own colleges rather than attending white universities.
Racial tensions in post-Civil War America required African Americans to fund the creation of HBCUs with little help from white citizens.
Religious concerns about Black education led to the development of HBCUs as entirely secular schools for Black students.

f.c:
Source 1

“After consultation with the citizens of Tuskegee, I set July 4, 1881, as the day for the opening of the school in the little shanty and church which had been secured for its accommodation. The white people, as well as the coloured, were greatly interested in the starting of the new school, and the opening day was looked forward to with much earnest discussion. There were not a few white people in the vicinity of Tuskegee who looked with some disfavour upon the project. They questioned its value to the coloured people, and had a fear that it might result in bringing about trouble between the races. Some had the feeling that in proportion as the Negro received education, in the same proportion would his value decrease as an economic factor in the state. These people feared the result of education would be that the Negroes would leave the farms, and that it would be difficult to secure them for domestic service.
 

The white people who questioned the wisdom of starting this new school had in their minds pictures of what was called an educated Negro, with a high hat, imitation gold eye-glasses, a showy walking-stick, kid gloves, fancy boots, and what not—in a word, a man who was determined to live by his wits. It was difficult for these people to see how education would produce any other kind of a coloured man.”

Source: Chapter VIII, “Teaching School in a Stable and a Hen-House” from Up From Slavery: An Autobiography by Booker T. Washington, 1900

 

Source 2

  • The men are dressed in dark suits, white shirts, and bow ties.

q.s: Explain how African American athletes used their status to advocate for equality in the twentieth century.
Which of the following best explains why the Universal Negro Improvement Association (UNIA) developed?

o.l: To unite all people of African descent
To encourage people of African descent to migrate to urban areas
To create a Black aesthetic reflected in the arts and broader Black culture
To provide postsecondary education to Black people in the United States

f.c:
“The Universal Negro Improvement Association and African Communities’ League is a social, friendly, humanitarian, charitable, educational, institutional, constructive and expansive society, and is founded by persons desiring to the utmost to work for the general uplift of the Negro peoples of the world. And the members pledge themselves to all in their power to conserve the rights of their noble race and to respect the rights of all mankind, believing always in the Brotherhood of Man and the Fatherhood of God. The motto of the organization is ‘One God! One Aim! One Destiny!’ Therefore, let justice be done to all mankind, realizing that if the strong oppresses the weak confusion and discontent will ever mark the path of man, but with love, faith and charity towards all the reign of peace and plenty will be heralded into the world and the generations of men shall be called Blessed.... 

 

Objects and Aims 

Section 3. The objects of the Universal Negro Improvement Association and African Communities’ League shall be: to establish a Universal Confraternity among the race; to promote the spirit of pride and love; to reclaim the fallen; to administer to and assist the needy; to assist in civilizing the backward tribes of Africa; to assist in the development of Independent Negro Nations and Communities; to establish Commissionaires or Agencies in the principal countries and cities of the world for the representation and protection of all Negroes, irrespective of nationality; to promote a conscientious Spiritual worship among the native tribes of Africa; to establish Universities, Colleges, Academies and Schools for the racial education and culture of the people; to conduct a world-wide Commercial and Industrial Intercourse for the good of the people; to work for better conditions in all Negro communities.”

Source: Constitution of the Universal Negro Improvement Association, 1918

Garvey suggests that people of African descent must be compensated for the injustices they experienced during slavery.

q.s: As noted in the passage, the concept of partus sequitur ventrem was used to justify which of the following practices?

o.l: Determining a child’s citizenship by the state in which they were born
Determining a child’s ability to be free from enslavement by their father’s wealth
Determining a child’s enslaved status based on the status of the child’s mother
Determining a child’s educational opportunities based on the occupation of their father

f.c:
“If any thing has ever been proved and demonstrated again and again, it is THE LAWFULNESS OF SLAVERY....

It has been proved that the [Latin] maxim, ‘partus sequitur ventrem’ – or that the offspring inherits the status of the parent, is a law of nature, reason, religion, and providence, and that no man has any rights but those to which he is born, or which belong to that condition in which God places him by the hand of his providence....

He that is born a slave, therefore, has no right to liberty, and can acquire none, so long as the right of his master to his service stands in the way.”

Source: Elwood Fisher, Virginia-born, white resident of Cincinnati, Ohio, “Lecture on the North and the South,” delivered in Cincinnati, January 1849

o.l: It supported enslavers’ claims that legal rights should be based on one’s outward appearance.
It perpetuated slavery over generations and determined the social position of racially mixed offspring.
It enabled enslavers to prohibit the enslaved from gathering and learning to read.
It led enslavers to embrace the notion that race is a social construct.

f.c:

q.s: Based on the passage, which of the following describes an outcome of escaping to freedom in the North for formerly enslaved people?

o.l: They returned to the South to be with their families because of the harsh climate in the North.
They found it difficult to remain in the North because of the limited economic opportunities.
They were often forced to leave their loved ones behind in the South.
They returned from the North to their native lands in the South because of their limited social mobility.

f.c:
“I grew up like a neglected weed,—ignorant of liberty, having no experience of it. Then I was not happy or contented: every time I saw a white man I was afraid of being carried away. I had two sisters carried away in a chain-gang,—one of them left two children. We were always uneasy. Now I've been free, I know what a dreadful condition slavery is. I have seen hundreds of escaped slaves, but I never saw one who was willing to go back and be a slave. I have no opportunity to see my friends in my native land“Native land” refers to Maryland in the United States, where Harriet Tubman was formerly enslaved.. We would rather stay [there], if we could be as free there as we are here. I think slavery is the next thing to hell.” 

Source: Harriet Tubman, testimony as compiled in Benjamin Drew's A North-Side View of Slavery, 1856

q.s: Which of the following broader historical contexts best explains Tubman’s fear of “being carried away”?

o.l: Enslaved African Americans were being sent to Africa by the American Colonization Society to build overseas colonies.
Enslaved African Americans believed that resisting slavery would lead to a delay in gaining freedom through the Underground Railroad.
Enslaved African Americans were taken from plantations to fight for the Union army during the Civil War.
Enslaved African Americans were often forcibly sold by plantation owners as a part of the domestic slave trade.

f.c:
“I grew up like a neglected weed,—ignorant of liberty, having no experience of it. Then I was not happy or contented: every time I saw a white man I was afraid of being carried away. I had two sisters carried away in a chain-gang,—one of them left two children. We were always uneasy. Now I've been free, I know what a dreadful condition slavery is. I have seen hundreds of escaped slaves, but I never saw one who was willing to go back and be a slave. I have no opportunity to see my friends in my native land“Native land” refers to Maryland in the United States, where Harriet Tubman was formerly enslaved.. We would rather stay [there], if we could be as free there as we are here. I think slavery is the next thing to hell.” 

Source: Harriet Tubman, testimony as compiled in Benjamin Drew's A North-Side View of Slavery, 1856

o.l: The challenges of life for Black women during segregation
