f.c:
“I grew up like a neglected weed,—ignorant of liberty, having no experience of it. Then I was not happy or contented: every time I saw a white man I was afraid of being carried away. I had two sisters carried away in a chain-gang,—one of them left two children. We were always uneasy. Now I've been free, I know what a dreadful condition slavery is. I have seen hundreds of escaped slaves, but I never saw one who was willing to go back and be a slave. I have no opportunity to see my friends in my native land“Native land” refers to Maryland in the United States, where Harriet Tubman was formerly enslaved.. We would rather stay [there], if we could be as free there as we are here. I think slavery is the next thing to hell.” 

Source: Harriet Tubman, testimony as compiled in Benjamin Drew's A North-Side View of Slavery, 1856

q.s: Which of the following best summarizes the authors’ argument in the excerpt?

o.l: The small size of Spain’s Black African population led to its history being largely forgotten, and little textual evidence of the population remains available today.
The large population of Black Africans in sixteenth- and seventeenth-century Spain left an enduring legacy that is widely celebrated by modern Spaniards.
The role of Black Africans in Spanish history has not been adequately recognized despite the significant historical presence of Africans in Spain.
Black Africans were largely omitted from Spanish literature despite the sizable population of Africans living in Spain in the sixteenth century.

f.c:
“The frequency of black African characters playing songs and dancing who appear in Golden Age SpanishThe period of Spanish literature extending from the early 1500s to the late 1600s. comedies and short plays, as well as their mention in sociohistorical sources, is astonishing. In the light of this, the lack of awareness of present-day Spaniards about the presence of Africans in Spanish history is remarkable, particularly as Spain most probably had the largest black population in Renaissance Europe (Martín Casares 2005). Regardless of the fact that black Africans have been a significant element in the Spanish population for centuries, their importance has never been recognized.”

Source: Aurelia Martín-Casares and Marga G. Barranco, “The musical legacy of black Africans in Spain: A review of our sources,” Anthropological Notebooks, 2009

q.s: Which of the following best identifies evidence used by the authors to support their claim about the size of the African population in Spain?

o.l: Spanish literary works
European musical trends
African dance techniques
Kongolese census data

f.c:
“The frequency of black African characters playing songs and dancing who appear in Golden Age SpanishThe period of Spanish literature extending from the early 1500s to the late 1600s. comedies and short plays, as well as their mention in sociohistorical sources, is astonishing. Regardless of the fact that black Africans have been a significant element in the Spanish population for centuries, their importance has never been recognized.”

Source: Aurelia Martín-Casares and Marga G. Barranco, “The musical legacy of black Africans in Spain: A review of our sources,” Anthropological Notebooks, 2009

q.s: Which of the following contexts is most helpful for understanding the historical development discussed in the excerpt?

o.l: The Red Sea connected the Aksumite Empire to maritime trade in the Mediterranean around 100 BCE.
Trade between the Portuguese and West Africa increased significantly in the late 1400s.
Commerce across the Sahara Desert connected societies in North and West Africa in the 1300s.
Societies in Southern Africa grew wealth by exporting goods to the Swahili Coast in the 1100s.

f.c:

q.s: Which of the following best explains the author’s reference in the excerpt to his mother giving birth to enslaved children?

o.l: The Supreme Court’s ruling in Dred Scott v. Sandford, which stated that African Americans are not citizens of the United States
The legal doctrine of partus sequitur ventrem, which prohibited the children of enslaved Black women and free white men from inheriting the free status of their fathers
Legislation enacted by free states that denied African Americans living there the right to vote, hold political office, or testify in court
Slave codes that prohibited or severely restricted enslaved African Americans’ freedom of movement, congregation, and speech

f.c:
“I was born May 1815, of a slave mother, in Shelby County, Kentucky, and was claimed as the property of David White Esq. He came into possession of my mother long before I was born....

My mother was known by the name of Milldred Jackson. She is the mother of seven slaves only, all being sons, of whom I am the eldest. She was also so fortunate or unfortunate, as to have some of what is called the slaveholding blood flowing in her veins. I know not how much; but not enough to prevent her children though fathered by slaveholders, from being bought and sold in the slave markets of the South. It is almost impossible for slaves to give a correct account of their male parentage. All that I know about it is, that my mother informed me that my father’s name was James Bibb. He was doubtless one of the present Bibb family of Kentucky;The Bibb family was a prominent white family in nineteenth century Kentucky, whose members included James Bibb (the author’s father), a Kentucky state senator, and George Bibb, a United States senator from Kentucky. but I have no personal knowledge of him at all, for he, died before my recollection.”
 

Henry Bibb, Narrative of the Life and Adventures of Henry Bibb, An American Slave, Written by Himself, book published in 1849.

q.s: Which of the following was a direct consequence of selling enslaved children fathered by enslavers, as described in the excerpt?

o.l: Enslavers established the system of selling enslaved persons at auction.
Large numbers of enslaved African Americans were displaced from the upper South to the lower South.
Enslaved women had great commercial value to their enslavers.
Enslaved women were treated better by their enslavers than were enslaved men.

f.c:
“I was born May 1815, of a slave mother, in Shelby County, Kentucky, and was claimed as the property of David White Esq. He came into possession of my mother long before I was born....

My mother was known by the name of Milldred Jackson. She is the mother of seven slaves only, all being sons, of whom I am the eldest. q.s: Which of the following was a legal principle that governed race classification throughout the United States before the Civil War?

o.l: Race was legally determined based on hypodescent, the principle that racially mixed persons were assigned the lower racial status, making them legally inferior to white people.
Race was legally determined based on the notion that race is a socially constructed concept, thus giving legal consideration to individuals’ own racial self-identification.

Race was legally determined based on people’s phenotype, meaning observable traits such as hair type and skin color made darker-skinned persons automatically deemed inferior to lighter-skinned persons, regardless of ancestry.
Race was legally determined based on the “one-drop rule," meaning that people who had any African ancestry were legally considered fully Black regardless of their observable appearance.

f.c:
“I was born May 1815, of a slave mother, in Shelby County, Kentucky, and was claimed as the property of David White Esq. He came into possession of my mother long before I was born....

My mother was known by the name of Milldred Jackson. She is the mother of seven slaves only, all being sons, of whom I am the eldest. She was also so fortunate or unfortunate, as to have some of what is called the slaveholding blood flowing in her veins. I know not how much; but not enough to prevent her children though fathered by slaveholders, from being bought and sold in the slave markets of the South. He was doubtless one of the present Bibb family of Kentucky;The Bibb family was a prominent white family in nineteenth century Kentucky, whose members included James Bibb (the author’s father), a Kentucky state senator, and George Bibb, a United States senator from Kentucky. but I have no personal knowledge of him at all, for he, died before my recollection.”

q.s: Explain how the African American experience has shaped Black spirituality and/or faith traditions.
Which of the following developments in the African American community does the image best reflect?

o.l: The efforts to achieve racial uplift through improved opportunities in education
The use of artistic creations by African Americans to promote cultural pride
The use of Black organizations to protest racial discrimination
The efforts of Black churches to transform Christian worship in the United States

f.c: Photo by Afro American Newspapers/Gado/Getty Images

q.s: Which of the following best explains the significance of the image in the context of United States society in the 1930s?

o.l: The image shows the emergence of African American businesses as a response to racial segregation and exclusion.
The image showcases how Black newspapers provided spaces that gave Black women equal access to careers in response to gender inequality in society.
The image shows how Black organizations primarily focused on individual advancement rather than community empowerment in an effort to achieve uplift.
The image showcases increasing mainstream acceptance of African American occupations during a period of racial inequality.

f.c: Photo by Afro American Newspapers/Gado/Getty Images

q.s: Which of the following claims could most accurately be made about the Black press in the early twentieth century?

o.l: The Black press focused solely on local news stories due to their community importance.
The Black press expanded throughout the nation and promoted the economic stability of communities.
The Black press focused primarily on racial violence and discrimination to enact change.
The Black press discouraged political protests in print for fear of white retaliation.

f.c: Photo by Afro American Newspapers/Gado/Getty Images

q.s: Which of the following best describes Du Bois’s point of view on the concept of double consciousness?

o.l: Double consciousness reflected the hopelessness of many African Americans’ position in society.
Double consciousness had positive and negative impacts on African American society.
The term double consciousness reflected the unique ability of African Americans to advance politically.
The idea of double consciousness was limited to a specific time and had little long-term impact.

f.c:
“Not only do white men but also colored men forget the facts of the Negro’s double environment. The Negro American has for his environment not only the white surrounding world, but also, and touching him usually much more nearly and compellingly, is the environment furnished by his own colored group. There are exceptions, of course, but this is the rule. The American Negro, therefore, is surrounded and conditioned by the concept which he has of white people and he is treated in accordance with the concept they have of him. On the other hand, so far as his own people are concerned, he is in direct contact with individuals and facts.”

Source: W.E.B. Du Bois, Dusk of Dawn; an Essay Toward an Autobiography of a Race Concept, 1940

q.s: Which of the following best explains the historical context in which Du Bois wrote about double consciousness?

o.l: Du Bois’s writing is a modern interpretation of the color line in the post-civil rights South.
Du Bois’s writing about the color line gives voice to those fighting for an end to slavery during the period before the Civil War.
Du Bois’s writing reflects the color line’s elimination during the protections of the Reconstruction era.
Du Bois’s writing reflects the ongoing struggle of the color line after the abolition of slavery.

f.c:
“Not only do white men but also colored men forget the facts of the Negro’s double environment. The Negro American has for his environment not only the white surrounding world, but also, and touching him usually much more nearly and compellingly, is the environment furnished by his own colored group. On the other hand, so far as his own people are concerned, he is in direct contact with individuals and facts.”

Source: W.E.B. Du Bois, Dusk of Dawn; an Essay Toward an Autobiography of a Race Concept, 1940

o.l: To acknowledge the complicated lives of African Americans.
To directly challenge white supremacy groups
To expand and energize the anti-slavery movement
To rile his audience up for immediate action

f.c:

q.s: Explain how you determined that one of your sources is reliable.
Based on Ibn Battuta's description, which of the following claims can be made about the Swahili Coast?

o.l: Islam was commonly practiced in the city-states located in this region.
Bantu languages were widely spoken along the entire east coast of Africa.
Portuguese merchants consistently controlled the Indian Ocean trade.
Great Zimbabwe was the primary supplier of grain to the villages located in this region.

f.c:
“...We sailed for fifteen days and came to Mogadishu, which is an enormous town. Its inhabitants are merchants...When a ship reaches the port, it is met by...small boats, in each of which are a number of young men, each carrying a [gift]. He presents this to one of the merchants on the ship saying "This is my guest," and all the others do the same. Each merchant on disembarking goes only to the house of the young man who is his host...The host then sells his goods for him and buys for him...

We stayed there three days...on the fourth day...we went to the mosquea Muslim place of worship and prayed...

We left Mogadishu...with the object of visiting the town of Kilwa in the land of the Zanj.

[Along the way,] we came to Mombasa, a large island...They have fruit trees on the island, but no cereals, which have to be brought to them...Their food consists chiefly of bananas and fish. The inhabitants are pious, honorable, and upright, and they have well-built wooden mosques.

We stayed one night in Mombasa, and then continued to Kilwa, which is a large town on the coast. The majority of its inhabitants are Zanj, jet-black in color, and with tattoo marks on their faces... 

The sultana title for a ruler...was noted for his gifts and generosity...as is prescribed in the Koranthe sacred book of Islam...” 

 

Source: Description of the Swahili Coast of Africa from Ibn Battuta’s travel journal, 1355. Ibn Battuta was a Muslim scholar and traveler from North Africa who wrote of his thirty-year journey around Africa and Asia.

q.s: Which of the following claims about the Swahili Coast could best be supported by Ibn Battuta's description?

o.l: Trade was an important part of the economy.
A Mediterranean climate was widespread in the region.
Christianity had a significant impact on the culture.
Timbuktu unified the region under one government.

f.c:
“...We sailed for fifteen days and came to Mogadishu, which is an enormous town. Its inhabitants are merchants...When a ship reaches the port, it is met by...small boats, in each of which are a number of young men, each carrying a [gift]. He presents this to one of the merchants on the ship saying "This is my guest," and all the others do the same. Each merchant on disembarking goes only to the house of the young man who is his host...The host then sells his goods for him and buys for him...

We stayed there three days...on the fourth day...we went to the mosquea Muslim place of worship and prayed...

We left Mogadishu...with the object of visiting the town of Kilwa in the land of the Zanj.

[Along the way,] we came to Mombasa, a large island...They have fruit trees on the island, but no cereals, which have to be brought to them...Their food consists chiefly of bananas and fish. The inhabitants are pious, honorable, and upright, and they have well-built wooden mosques.

We stayed one night in Mombasa, and then continued to Kilwa, which is a large town on the coast. The majority of its inhabitants are Zanj, jet-black in color, and with tattoo marks on their faces... 

The sultana title for a ruler...was noted for his gifts and generosity...as is prescribed in the Koranthe sacred book of Islam...” 

 

Source: Description of the Swahili Coast of Africa from Ibn Battuta’s travel journal, 1355. Ibn Battuta was a Muslim scholar and traveler from North Africa who wrote of his thirty-year journey around Africa and Asia.

q.s: Which of the following best describes how the French Code Noir of 1685 relates to the practice of slavery in American societies in the period circa 1600–1900?

o.l: The French Code Noir was an early example of the regulations that restricted enslaved persons’ freedoms which were adopted across a wide variety of enslaving societies in the Americas.
The French Code Noir was the original source of slave laws and regulations used in British North American colonies, many of which adopted the Code Noir in its entirety.
The French Code Noir was a unique legal document, which did not have any parallels in British or Spanish colonies, or in individual US states and jurisdictions.
The French Code Noir, unlike other slave codes, used race as one of the main factors defining a person’s free or enslaved status.

f.c:
“[Article 15]. We forbid slaves to carry any weapon, or large sticks, on pain of whipping and of confiscation of the weapon to the profit of those who seize them; with the sole exception of those who are sent hunting by their master.

[Article 16]. We forbid slaves belonging to different masters to gather during the day or at night whether claiming [to do so] for a wedding or otherwise, whether on their master's property or elsewhere, and still less in the main roads or in faraway places, on pain of corporal punishment, which will not be less than the whip and the fleur de lysA reference to the practice of branding criminals with a hot iron in the shape of a lily flower, the royal emblem of the kings of France; this was a punishment for deserters and habitual criminals in France. and which in cases of frequent violations and other aggravating circumstances may be punished with death: this we leave to the decision of judges. We [authorize] all our subjects, even those who are not officers of the state, to approach the offenders, to arrest them, and to take them to prison, even if there is not yet any decree against them.

[Article 17]. Masters who are convicted of having permitted or tolerated such assemblies composed of slaves other than those belonging to them will be condemned... to pay for all the damage that will have been done to their neighbors by these said assemblies and a fine of 10 ecusFrench unit of currency for the first time and double for repeat offenses.”
 

Source: Law issued by King Louis XIV of France referred to as Code Noir, which regulated the practice of slavery in French colonies, 1685

q.s: Which of the following most directly influenced the creation of policies such as those in the excerpt?

o.l: Worry among enslavers that slavery was becoming less profitable.
Fear among enslavers of slave uprisings and other forms of resistance to slavery.
Enslavers’ concern for the safety and well-being of the enslaved persons under their control.
Enslavers’ claims that slavery was a morally benign and economically necessary institution.

q.s: Which of the following best describes how laws and regulations regarding African Americans developed during the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries?

o.l: African Americans gradually gained more citizenship rights and legal protections as a result of the application of the Constitution by federal courts.
In free states, African Americans were prohibited from voting prior to the ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment.
Many slave codes were changed to grant enslaved workers new economic rights such as a five-day working week and a minimum wage.
African Americans’ efforts to resist or escape enslavement were met with new, even stricter, legal regulations on their personal and citizenship rights.

[Article 17]. Masters who are convicted of having permitted or tolerated such assemblies composed of slaves other than those belonging to them will be condemned... to pay for all the damage that will have been done to their neighbors by these said assemblies and a fine of 10 ecusFrench unit of currency for the first time and double for repeat offenses.”

q.s: Which of the following best describes a primary purpose of the poem?

o.l: To encourage African Americans to participate in the Civil Rights movement
To encourage African Americans to emigrate and move back to Africa
To encourage African Americans to take pride in their progress and to continue to move forward
To remind African Americans of their common ancestral heritage and cultural achievements

f.c:
Emancipation

 

Fling out your banners, your honors be bringing,
Strike every chord and let music be ringing!
Celebrate freely this day of all days.


Few are the years since that notable blessing,
Raised you from slaves to the powers of men.
Each year has seen you my brothers progressing,
Never to sink to that level again....

Press boldly forward nor waver, nor falter.
Blood has been freely poured out in your cause,
Lives sacrificed upon Liberty’s altar.
Press to the front, it were craven to pause....


Up! Men and brothers, be noble, be earnest!
Ripe is the time and success is assured;
Know that your fate was the hardest and sternest
When through those lash-ringing days you endured.


Never again shall the manacles1 gall2 you
Never again shall the whip stroke defame!
Nobles and Freemen, your destinies call you
Onward to honor, to glory and fame.

Source: Paul Laurence Dunbar, 1890

1:chains or shackles↩
2:to irritate↩

o.l: The poem was written to protest the passage of the Emancipation Proclamation.
The poem was written in the period after African American men had gained the right to vote.
The poem was written to urge African Americans to resist the draft at the start of the First World War.
The poem was written to protest the enactment of Black Codes in some states.

The Freedmen’s Bureau was established to help formerly enslaved people transition to citizenship.
Civil rights groups organized the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.
Millions of African American families relocated to northern and western states during the Great Migration.

q.s: Which of the following claims about the success of the Haitian Revolution is best supported by evidence in the excerpt?

o.l: It became a symbol of Black freedom and power.
It caused France to have continued economic prosperity.
It inspired the French Revolution to be based on similar ideals.
It was made possible by the contributions of local maroons.

f.c:
We...[who] in our name [as well as] in that of the people of Hayti, who have legally constituted us faithfully organs and interpreters of their will, in presence of the Supreme Being, before whom all mankind are equal, and who has scattered so many species of creatures on the surface of the earth for the purpose of manifesting his glory and his power by the diversity of his works, in the presence of all nature by whom we have been so unjustly and for so long a time considered as outcast children.

Do declare that the tenor of the present constitution is the free spontaneous and invariable expression of our hearts, and the general will of our constituents, and we submit it to the sanction of H.M. the Emperor Jacques Dessalines our deliverer, to receive its speedy and entire execution.
Preliminary Declaration.
Art. 1. The people inhabiting the island formerly called St. Domingo, hereby agree to form themselves into a free state sovereign and independent of any other power in the universe, under the name of empire of Hayti.
2. Slavery is forever abolished.
3. The Citizens of Hayti are brothers at home; equality in the eyes of the law is incontestably acknowledged, and there cannot exist any titles, advantages, or privileges, other than those necessarily resulting from the consideration and reward of services rendered to liberty and independence.
4. The law is the same to all, whether it punishes, or whether it protects.
 

Source: English translation of the Constitution of Haiti, published in the New York Evening Post, 1805

q.s: Which of the following best describes the main purpose of Haiti’s constitution?

o.l: To encourage the establishment of diplomatic relations with the United States
To inspire uprisings against enslavement in other places throughout the African diaspora
To establish Haiti as an independent Black republic committed to freedom and equality
To motivate former enslavers in Haiti to leave the country for the United States

f.c:
We...[who] in our name [as well as] in that of the people of Hayti, who have legally constituted us faithfully organs and interpreters of their will, in presence of the Supreme Being, before whom all mankind are equal, and who has scattered so many species of creatures on the surface of the earth for the purpose of manifesting his glory and his power by the diversity of his works, in the presence of all nature by whom we have been so unjustly and for so long a time considered as outcast children.

4. The law is the same to all, whether it punishes, or whether it protects.
 

Source: English translation of the Constitution of Haiti, published in the New York Evening Post, 1805

q.s: Which of the following best describes the significance of Haiti’s constitution within its historical context?

o.l: It reduced fears enslavers in the United States had about the spread of slave revolts.
It inspired other uprisings of enslaved people throughout the African diaspora.
It motivated Black women to bring attention to the gender discrimination they experienced.
It popularized the efforts of the American Colonization Society.

f.c:
We...[who] in our name [as well as] in that of the people of Hayti, who have legally constituted us faithfully organs and interpreters of their will, in presence of the Supreme Being, before whom all mankind are equal, and who has scattered so many species of creatures on the surface of the earth for the purpose of manifesting his glory and his power by the diversity of his works, in the presence of all nature by whom we have been so unjustly and for so long a time considered as outcast children.

Do declare that the tenor of the present constitution is the free spontaneous and invariable expression of our hearts, and the general will of our constituents, and we submit it to the sanction of H.M. the Emperor Jacques Dessalines our deliverer, to receive its speedy and entire execution.
Preliminary Declaration.
Art. 1. The people inhabiting the island formerly called St. Domingo, hereby agree to form themselves into a free state sovereign and independent of any other power in the universe, under the name of empire of Hayti.
2. Slavery is forever abolished.
3. The Citizens of Hayti are brothers at home; equality in the eyes of the law is incontestably acknowledged, and there cannot exist any titles, advantages, or privileges, other than those necessarily resulting from the consideration and reward of services rendered to liberty and independence.
4. The law is the same to all, whether it punishes, or whether it protects.
 

Source: English translation of the Constitution of Haiti, published in the New York Evening Post, 1805

q.s: The excerpt reflects the features that characterize African American Studies by

o.l: examining the development of ideas about Africa’s ongoing relationship with the African diaspora
using an interdisciplinary approach to analyze the history and culture of African Americans
clearing up misconceptions that characterize Africa as a place with an undocumented or unknowable history
using scholarly inquiry to affirm early Africa as a diverse continent with complex societies

f.c:
“The study of African American oratorypublic speaking is intricatelycomplexly interwoven with the study of history; and a central aspect of African American history is the persistent public discussions related to our American experience. Having to defend our humanity, to agitate for minimal rights, and to soothe the raw emotions of mistreated fellows, our speakers have been forced to develop articulate and effective speech behavior on the platformstage or pulpit. That a principal dimension of black history is encompassed by platform activities in the form of lectures, sermons, and agitationsprotests should [be understood] without question [by] the student familiar with history. 

Unable to read or write English and forbidden by law (in most states) to learn, the African in America early cultivated the natural fascination with nommo, the word, and demonstrated a singular appreciation for the subtleties, pleasures, and potentials of the spoken word, which has continued to enrich and embolden [the African American’s] history. Thus, in part because of strict antiliteracy laws during slavery, vocal communication became, for a much greater proportion of blacks than whites, the fundamental medium of communication.” 
 

Source: Molefi Kete Asante, “African American Orature and Context” in The Afrocentric Idea, 1998

The spoken word is an essential part of the history of the African American community.

q.s: Which of the following would best support the author’s claim in the passage that the end of the Civil War “offered little reason for jubilation” to enslaved African Americans living in the Choctaw and Chickasaw Nations?

o.l: Like other Indigenous nations, the Choctaw and Chickasaw kept their codified system of racial slavery until after the practice had been abolished in the rest of the United States.
The Choctaw and Chickasaw nations were forcibly removed from their ancestral lands and moved west of the Mississippi in the Trail of Tears.
As was the case with other Indigenous nations, the lands of the Choctaw and Chickasaw had historically served as destinations for African Americans seeking to escape from slavery.
As a result of centuries of coexistence, many African Americans in the pre–Civil War South had come to have partial Indigenous ancestry.

f.c:
“For the enslaved men and women in the Choctaw and Chickasaw Nations, the end of the Civil War offered little reason for jubilation.... Months after the war’s end and slavery’s demise in the United States, Choctaw and Chickasaw lawmakers...refused to contemplate the possibility of legally and socially redefining people of African descent as something other than slaves. Finally, in the spring of 1866, the Choctaw and Chickasaw Nations, despite having separate governments, entered a joint treaty with the United States...[in which] the issues of black people’s status and rights were tightly interwoven with matters of U.S. Indian policy—namely, the unrelenting drive to curb tribal sovereignty and claim the better part of Indian Territory for the United States....”

Source: Barbara Krauthamer, historian, Black Slaves, Indian Masters : Slavery, Emancipation, and Citizenship in the Native American South, book published in 2013

q.s: Which of the following claims could best be supported by the passage?

o.l: African American troops were unsuccessful in freeing people enslaved by Indigenous groups.
Lincoln’s wartime actions to free enslaved people had a limited effect.
Free African Americans were often at risk of being enslaved by members of Indigenous groups.

f.c:
“For the enslaved men and women in the Choctaw and Chickasaw Nations, the end of the Civil War offered little reason for jubilation.... Finally, in the spring of 1866, the Choctaw and Chickasaw Nations, despite having separate governments, entered a joint treaty with the United States...[in which] the issues of black people’s status and rights were tightly interwoven with matters of U.S. Indian policy—namely, the unrelenting drive to curb tribal sovereignty and claim the better part of Indian Territory for the United States....”

Source: Barbara Krauthamer, historian, Black Slaves, Indian Masters : Slavery, Emancipation, and Citizenship in the Native American South, book published in 2013

q.s: The source demonstrates which of the following historical developments in the African American community in the early twentieth century?

o.l: The promotion of equality through highlighting the dignity and determination of Black women
The highlighting of anti-Black violence through journalism
The challenging of racist stereotypes through the arts
The coordination of efforts to fight political discrimination

f.c:
“The [objective of the] Oklahoma State Federation of Negro Women's Clubs...[is to] raise to the highest plane the home, the moral, intellectual, and civil life of the race and to cultivate that spirit of general helpfulness, as expressed in its motto, ‘Lifting as We Climb.’...

This organization is promoting work along all lines of educational and civic improvement in many of the cities and towns of the state.... One club has a day nursery and lunch room for school children.... Another club furnished properly chaperoned weekly entertainments for the young people.

[The] Muskogee and El Reno clubs are promoting public libraries and hospitals. Many clubs all over the state are furnishing playgrounds for the children.”

Library of Congress

Source: Mrs. H. P. Jacobson, “Negro Women’s Club Work in Oklahoma,” The Tulsa Star, August 15, 1914

q.s: Which of the following describes an important similarity between the institution of slavery in Brazil and in the United States?

o.l: In both countries, enslaved people had relative autonomy compared to slavery in the rest of the world.
In both countries, the government reinforced the slave trade into the mid-1800s to grow the institution.
In both countries, the labor of enslaved people was primarily used for public works projects.
In both countries, private individuals exploited enslaved people for profit.

f.c:
A...planter...dined with us one day, and spoke with such freedom on slavery. With most men, he thinks the land can never be cultivated in the northern provinces by whites. The city slaves of Bahia, he said, are...shrewd and intelligent, they preserved their own language, and by that means organize clubs and mature schemes of revolution that their brethren of Pernambuco have repeatedly attempted to carry out. Some write Arabic fluently, and are vastly superior to most of their masters. In the interior, he remarked, the slaves are badly fed, worse clothed, and worked so hard that the average duration of their lives does not exceed six years. In some districts it reaches to eight, which the number that see ten years after leaving Africa is small indeed.
 

Source: Thomas Ewbank, Life in Brazil; or, A journal of a visit to the land of the cocoa and the palm, 1856

q.s:
Respond to parts A, B, C, and D.

 

  1. Describe one cause of the advance in Black political representation evident in the source. 

  2. Describe one specific example of Black political leadership before 2004. 

  3. Explain how the author’s life experience may have influenced his description of the United States. 

  4. Explain how economic growth in Black communities was hindered or promoted in the second half of the twentieth century.

f.c:
“My father was...born and raised in a small village in Kenya. He...went to school in a tin-roof shack.... Through hard work and perseverance my father got a scholarship to study in a magical place: America, which stood as a beacon of freedom and opportunity to so many who had come before.... I stand here today, grateful for the diversity of my heritage, aware that my parents’ dreams live on in my precious daughters. I stand here knowing that my story is part of the larger American story, that I owe a debt to all of those who came before me, and that, in no other country on earth, is my story even possible. Tonight, we gather to affirm the greatness of our nation, not because of the height of our skyscrapers, or the power of our military, or the size of our economy. Our pride is based on a very simple premise, summed up in a declaration made over two hundred years ago, ‘We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal. That they are endowed by their Creator with certain inalienable rights. That among these are life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.’”

Source: U.S. Senator Barack Obama, keynote address at the 2004 Democratic National Convention

q.s:
Respond to parts A, B, C, and D.

 

  1. Describe the treatment enslaved people experienced aboard ships like those referenced in the source. 

  2. Describe a broader historical context of ibn Seid’s autobiography that is not specifically addressed in the source.

  3. Explain how slave narratives help further understanding in the field of African American Studies. 

  4. Explain how the transatlantic slave trade destabilized West African societies.

f.c:
“My name is Omar ibn Seid. My birthplace was Fut Tûr, between the two rivers. I sought knowledge under the instruction of a Sheikh called Mohammed Seid, my own brother, and Sheikh Soleiman Kembeh, and Sheikh Gabriel Abdal. I continued my studies twenty-five years. Then there came to our place a large army, who killed many men, and took me, and brought me to the great sea, and sold me into the hands of the Christians, who bound me and sent me on board [a] great ship and we sailed upon the great sea a month and a half, when we came to a place called Charleston in the Christian language. There they sold me to a small, weak, and wicked man, called Johnson, a complete infidel, who had no fear of God at all.”

Source: The Autobiography of Omar ibn Seid, an Enslaved Muslim, 1831

q.s: Which of the following claims is made about “the New Negro” in the source?

o.l: Education and refinement defined the New Negro.
The New Negro had been disenfranchised.
Owning land (“property”) was essential to the New Negro.
The New Negro was focused on money rather than literature.

f.c:
“In marked contrast with their enslaved or disenfranchised ancestors, these New Negroes demanded that their rights as citizens be vouchsafedgranted by law. Significantly, these New Negroes were to be recognized by their ‘education, refinement, and money,’ with property rights strongly implied as the hallmark of those who may demand their political rights. ‘Property,’ in this sense, is only one of a list of ‘properties’ demanded of this New Negro. ‘Education’ and ‘refinement’—to speak properly was to be proper—would ensure one’s rights, along with the security of property. These terms come to bear, curiously, upon subsequent definitions. J. W. E. Bowen, in ‘An Appeal to the King’ later that same year, again defined the New Negro, but here in terms only of racial ‘consciousness’ and its relation to ‘civilization’: ‘the consciousness of a racial personality under the blaze of a new civilization.’ Bowen’s ‘New Negro’ leads directly to the [Harlem or New Negro] Renaissance, for it was above all through literature that both ‘a racial personality’ and ‘the blaze of a new civilization’ would manifest themselves. Bowen’s ‘New Negro’ would create a universal racial art.”

Source: Henry Louis Gates, Jr., “The New Negro and the Black Image: From Booker T. Washington to Alain Locke,” Harvard University National Humanities Center Fellow, 1988

q.s: Which of the following best supports the claim that the New Negro movement would create “a universal racial art”?

o.l: The global tour of the Fisk Jubilee Singers
The choir music of the African Methodist Episcopal Church
The jazz music of artists such as Duke Ellington
The spirituals performed at annual Juneteenth ceremonies

f.c:
“In marked contrast with their enslaved or disenfranchised ancestors, these New Negroes demanded that their rights as citizens be vouchsafedgranted by law. Significantly, these New Negroes were to be recognized by their ‘education, refinement, and money,’ with property rights strongly implied as the hallmark of those who may demand their political rights. ‘Property,’ in this sense, is only one of a list of ‘properties’ demanded of this New Negro. ‘Education’ and ‘refinement’—to speak properly was to be proper—would ensure one’s rights, along with the security of property. These terms come to bear, curiously, upon subsequent definitions. J. W. E. Bowen, in ‘An Appeal to the King’ later that same year, again defined the New Negro, but here in terms only of racial ‘consciousness’ and its relation to ‘civilization’: ‘the consciousness of a racial personality under the blaze of a new civilization.’ Bowen’s ‘New Negro’ leads directly to the [Harlem or New Negro] Renaissance, for it was above all through literature that both ‘a racial personality’ and ‘the blaze of a new civilization’ would manifest themselves. Bowen’s ‘New Negro’ would create a universal racial art.”

Source: Henry Louis Gates, Jr., “The New Negro and the Black Image: From Booker T. Washington to Alain Locke,” Harvard University National Humanities Center Fellow, 1988

q.s:
Respond to parts A, B, and C.

 

  1. Describe an aspect of Bantu or Swahili society that is not included in the source.

  2. Describe one way societies such as the ones described in the source challenge misconceptions about early Africa. 

  3. Formulate a claim about how political factors contributed to the fall of the city-states on the Swahili Coast.

f.c:
“The Swahili people number approximately half a million, inhabiting a string of small settlements along the East African coast, from Mogadishu in the north to Mozambique in the south.... They are believed to have descended from Bantu-speaking agriculturalists who lived in the area reaching roughly from Kenya’s Tana River in present-day Kenya to the Webi Shabelle region of Somalia. Although the Swahili people had long supplemented their farming with fishing, it is believed that around 500 C.E. they began to trade and migrate along the coast. Over the next three centuries, migrant groups moved south by ship, establishing settlements both on the coast and on adjacent islands.”

Source: Robert Fay, “Swahili People” in Africana: The Encyclopedia of the African and African American Experience, 2005

q.s: Which of the following best describes a connection between Source 1 and Source 2?

o.l: Both sources consider Africa as a place where humans are as wild as animals.
Both sources explore the influence of Africa on African American identity.
Both sources argue that African American writers must travel to Africa to write about it.
Both sources caution against using the influence of white writers to represent African American identities.

f.c:
Source 1

“While some writers, such as Langston Hughes, traveled to Africa..., many others never made the trip. Their efforts to claim African identity, therefore, were rooted more in imagination and reading knowledge than in actual facts. Indeed, some white writers influenced African American conceptions of Africa. Vachel Lindsay is one such case. His poems in the vein of “The Congo” influenced Langston Hughes’s poetic imagination. Hughes’s poems about hearing African drums (“Danse Africaine,” for example) echo Lindsay’s work. African American writers were also not immune to notions of dark Africa that Joseph Conrad popularized in Heart of Darkness (1902). That conception is apparent in Countee Cullen’s “Heritage,” which is a classic poem about Africa from a Harlem Renaissance writer. In this long meditation..., Africa emerges as a...continent where wild animals roam and where the humans portrayed are only slightly more tame than the animals.... 

Africa as the perceived dark continent and America as part of western civilization provides the generalized clash that shapes African American representations of Africa during the Harlem Renaissance. Africa becomes the space of license, the imaginative arena in which a speaker in a poem or a character in a text can shed the clothing of civilization and live a simpler, more natural, more uninhibited life.”

Source: Trudier Harris, “The Image of Africa in the Literature of the Harlem Renaissance,” 2024

 

Source 2

Danse Africaine

The low beating of the tom-toms, 

The slow beating of the tom-toms,      

        Low...slow 

        Slow...low — 

        Stirs your blood. 

                Dance!

A night-veiled girl 

        Whirls softly into a

        Circle of light. 

        Whirls softly...slowly, 

Like a wisp of smoke around the fire — 

        And the tom-toms beat, 

        And the tom-toms beat, 

And the low beating of the tom-toms 

        Stirs your blood.

Source: Langston Hughes, “Danse Africaine,” 1922

q.s: Explain how African Americans shaped the development of communities in Florida from the seventeenth century to the nineteenth century.
Canot’s recollections most likely represent the perspective of

o.l: a slave trader
an antislavery activist
a formerly enslaved person
an African ladino intermediary

f.c:
“From the beginning [of the voyage from West Africa to Cuba] there was manifest discontent among the slaves.... We had been at sea about three weeks...and there was so much merriment among the gangs [of enslaved people] that were allowed to come on deck, that my apprehensions of danger began gradually to wear away. Suddenly, however, one fair afternoon, a squallstorm broke forth from an almost cloudless sky; and as the boatswain’san officer on a ship whistle piped all hands to take in sail, a simultaneous rush was made by the confined slaves... and amid the confusion of the rising gale, they knocked down the guard and poured upon deck.... Meantime, the women in the cabin were not idle. Seconding the males, they rose in a body.... 

I saw that, between the squall...and the revolt...we would soon be in a desperate plight, unless I gave the order to shoot. Accordingly, I told my comrades to...fire at once. 

...The unharmed neither fled nor ceased brandishing their weapons.... But, being reinforced by the boatswain and carpenter, we took command of the hatches so effectually, that a dozen additional discharges... drove the refractoryrebels to their quarters below.”

Source: Theodore Canot, recollections of the transatlantic slave trade from the 1820s to the 1840s

The publication of slave narratives declined as many white Americans became less sympathetic to the stories of formerly enslaved people.

q.s: The increase in the popularity of jazz music was most directly caused by which of the following developments in the early 20th century?

o.l: The growth of African American artistic expression in the Harlem Renaissance
The growth of resistance to racial violence during the nadir
The rise of efforts to counter negative stereotypes about African Americans at the time
The rise in African American activism against segregation in the South

f.c:
“It was as though Ellington had taken the traditional instruments of Negro American music and modified them, extended their range, enriched their tonal possibilities. We were studying the classics then, working at harmony and the forms of symphonic music. And while we affirmed the voice of jazz and the blues despite all criticism from our teachers because they spoke to a large extent of what we felt of the life we lived most intimately, it was not until the discovery of Ellington that we had any hint that jazz possessed possibilities of a range of expressiveness comparable to that of classical European music. 

And then Ellington and the great orchestra came to town; came with their uniforms, their sophistication, their skills; their golden horns, their flights of controlled and disciplined fantasy; came with their art, their special sound.... They were news from the great wide world, an example and a goal.”

Source: Ralph Ellison, “Homage to Duke Ellington on His Birthday” from Going to the Territory, 1986

q.s: Which of the following best explains the presence of the flag hanging from the NAACP headquarters in Source 2?

o.l: African Americans established Black churches to promote leadership opportunities for Black activists, musicians, and political leaders.
African Americans began to advocate for themselves politically as racial violence and atrocities continued through the early twentieth century.
African Americans began to protest discrimination and segregation in education through Black Greek-letter organizations.
African Americans advocated for the rights of Black women during the Women’s Suffrage movement of the early twentieth century.

f.c:
Source 1

“[Considering the incident, Merriweather said,]...America was founded for the sake of liberty and the establishment of an asylum for all who were oppressed. And no land has more actively engaged in the suppression of liberty, or in keeping down those who were already oppressed. So that a white boy raised on all sorts of high falutin idealism finds himself when he grows up completely at sea. I confess...when I came to realize that all my wealth and all the combination of environment and position which has made life hitherto so beautiful and perfect, were founded quite specifically on the backs of broken, beaten slaves, I got a shock from which I think sometimes I’ll never recover. It’s robbed me of happiness forever.... [T]hat sort of extremeness seems to be inherent in the question of color. Either you concern yourself with it violently as the Southerner does and so let slip by all the other important issues of life; or you are indifferent and callous like the average Northerner and grow hardened to all sorts of atrocities; or you steep yourself in it like the sentimentalist—that’s my class—and find yourself paralyzed by the vastness of the problem.”

Source: Jessie Redmon Fauset, a novelist in the Harlem Renaissance, There is Confusion, 1924

 

Source 2

Library of Congress

q.s: Which of the following claims does Johnson make about the institution of slavery?

o.l: It drove up the cost of goods enslaved people needed in order to survive.
It provided wealth for enslavers and access to basic provisions for enslaved people.
It treated enslaved people inhumanely and prevented enslaved people from meeting their basic needs.

f.c:
“I look upon slavery as I do upon a deadly poison. The slaves are not contented nor happy in their lot.... The man I belonged to did not give us enough to eat. My feet were frostbitten on my way North, but I would rather have died on the way than to go back.

I have had to go through a great deal of affliction; I have been compelled to work when I was sick. I used to have rheumatism, and could not always do so much work as those who were well, —then I would sometimes be whipped. I have never seen a runaway that wanted to go back, —I have never heard of one.

The fear of being sold South had more influence in inducing me to leave than any other thing. Master used to say, that if we didn’t suit him, he would put us in his pocket quick—meaning he would sell us....

I have found good friends in Canada, but have been able to do no work on account of my frozen feet,—I lost two toes from my right foot. My determination is to go to work as soon as I am able....”

Source: William Johnson, formerly enslaved person, 1856

Being required to work while sick
The lack of sufficient food and supplies

I have had to go through a great deal of affliction; I have been compelled to work when I was sick. I used to have rheumatism, and could not always do so much work as those who were well, —then I would sometimes be whipped. I have never seen a runaway that wanted to go back, —I have never heard of one.

The fear of being sold South had more influence in inducing me to leave than any other thing. Master used to say, that if we didn’t suit him, he would put us in his pocket quick—meaning he would sell us....

q.s: Which of the following best describes Johnson’s purpose in writing “Lift Every Voice and Sing”?

o.l: Johnson wanted to illuminate the dehumanization African Americans endured under enslavement to highlight the nation’s tumultuous past.
Johnson sought to call attention to widespread anti-Black sentiment in the United States in order to further demands for federal civil rights legislation.
Johnson sought to celebrate the perseverance and contributions of African Americans after a long period of oppression.
Johnson wanted to highlight the struggles African Americans faced while indicating that these struggles were over.

f.c:
Lift Every Voice and Sing
 

Let our rejoicing rise 

High as the listening skies, 

Let it resound loud as the rolling sea.

Sing a song full of the faith that the dark past has taught us, 

Sing a song full of the hope that the present has brought us. 

Facing the rising sun of our new day begun, 

Let us march on till victory is won....
 

Have not our weary feet 

Come to the place for which our fathers sighed? 

We have come over a way that with tears has been watered, 

We have come, treading our path through the blood of the slaughtered,

Out from the gloomy past, 

Till now we stand at last.

Source: James Weldon Johnson, hymn set to music, originally written as a poem, 1900

q.s: In the source, Jefferson advocated most directly for the

o.l: repeal of Virginia laws that made slavery a condition passed down through the mother
gradual emancipation of enslaved people in the United States to prevent further insurrections
removal of enslaved people engaged in rebellion to locations outside the United States
immediate expulsion of the growing free Black population from the United States to the West Indies

f.c:
“DEAR SIR,

The course of things in the neighboring islands of the West Indies appears to have given a considerable impulse to the minds of the slaves in different parts of the US. A great disposition to insurgency has manifested itself among them, which, in one instance, in the state of Virginia broke out into actual insurrection.... The legislature of the state, at a subsequent meeting, took the subject into consideration, and have communicated to me...their wish that some place could be provided, out of the limits of the US to which slaves guilty of insurgency might be transported; and they have particularly looked to Africa as offering the most desirable receptacle. We might, for this purpose, enter into negotiations with the natives, on some part of the coast, to obtain a settlement, and, by establishing an African company combine with its commercial operations. But there being already such an establishment on that coast by the English Sierra Leone company...it would seem better, by incorporating our emigrants with theirs, to make one strong, rather than two weak colonies....

I pray you to accept assurances of my high consideration and respect.”

Source: Thomas Jefferson, letter to Rufus King, July 13, 1802

q.s: Which of the following might explain why Jefferson wrote this letter to Rufus King?

o.l: The overthrow of slavery on the island of Saint Domingue could serve as inspiration for further insurrections in the United States.
The escape of enslaved people from the North to sanctuary in Spanish Florida could negatively affect local businesses.
The expansion of maroon communities in Virginia and North Carolina could alienate and isolate African Americans.
The migration of enslaved people to free territories in Canada could be the onset of mass northern emigration.

f.c:
“DEAR SIR,

The course of things in the neighboring islands of the West Indies appears to have given a considerable impulse to the minds of the slaves in different parts of the US. A great disposition to insurgency has manifested itself among them, which, in one instance, in the state of Virginia broke out into actual insurrection.... The legislature of the state, at a subsequent meeting, took the subject into consideration, and have communicated to me...their wish that some place could be provided, out of the limits of the US to which slaves guilty of insurgency might be transported; and they have particularly looked to Africa as offering the most desirable receptacle. We might, for this purpose, enter into negotiations with the natives, on some part of the coast, to obtain a settlement, and, by establishing an African company combine with its commercial operations. But there being already such an establishment on that coast by the English Sierra Leone company...it would seem better, by incorporating our emigrants with theirs, to make one strong, rather than two weak colonies....

I pray you to accept assurances of my high consideration and respect.”

Source: Thomas Jefferson, letter to Rufus King, July 13, 1802

q.s: The influx of Afro-Caribbean immigrants described in the source was a consequence of which of the following?

o.l: The Caribbean Red Summer, which led Afro-Caribbeans to seek refuge from racial violence
The success of Spanish families moving North during the Great Migration
The decline of Caribbean economies during the First World War
The funds raised by African American community outreach to help Afro-Caribbeans immigrate to the United States

f.c:
“Before the World War there was a large exodus of Negroes from the British West Indiesislands of the Caribbean under British control to Harlem. They came to this Promised Land in steamersteamboat after steamer. These Negroes are well educated and clever and after settling here a while many of them built up prosperous businesses. Today many of them own their own stores and drive about in motor cars.

The newcomers in Harlem...[include] Porto RicanPuerto Rican Negroes.... They are arriving in ever increasing numbers, swelling the Negro population.... They are distinctly of a Spanish type and a...Spanish origin. The signs above shop doors are in Spanish, the books exhibited in store windows are in that language, and the food served in their restaurants is cooked to the Spanish taste.”

Source: “Come From West Indies,” article published in The Northwest Enterprise, newspaper, September 3, 1931

q.s:
Using the image, respond to parts A, B, and C.

 

  1. Describe one reason African American artists documented their subjects during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries as demonstrated by the image of the Garveyite family.

  2. Describe one specific example of an African American contribution to an artistic field, other than photography, during the nineteenth or twentieth century.

  3. Using a different specific example than used in part B, explain how African Americans used visual media or other artistic fields to advocate for social change in the mid-to-late twentieth century.

f.c:
• The black-and-white photograph is a formally posed indoor portrait of an African American family consisting of a man, a woman, and a boy.
  • The man stands on the left side of the photograph.
    • He is dressed in military uniform and holds a hat in his right hand.
    • He has a slight smile.
  • The woman is seated in the center of the photograph.
    • She wears a formal sleeveless dress with intricate embellishments, jewelry, glasses, and decorated shoes.
    • She has a slight smile.
  • The boy stands on the right side of the photograph.
    • He wears a dark-colored sailor suit with white stripes around his neck and wrists.
    • He is unsmiling.
    • A small dog sits at his feet.
  • The background includes a table with a vase of flowers, a wallpapered wall, and a curtained window beneath an arch.

James Augustus Joseph Van Der Zee (American, 1886-1983) Garveyite Family, Harlem (from "Eighteen Photographs"), negative 1924; printed 1974 silver-toned silver print image: 9 1/2 × 7 7/8 in. (24.1 × 20 cm) Williams College Museum of Art, Williamstown, MA: Museum purchase, Otis Family Acquisition Trust (M.2017.9.8)

q.s: Which of the following claims did the author make in this excerpt?

o.l: Ngola Arij was the legitimate ruler of Ndongo.
Queen Njinga had great respect for the Portuguese.
The Dutch pressured Queen Njinga into a military alliance.
Portugal’s defense of their African territory was very weak.

f.c:
“In 1641 a Dutch fleet composed of twenty-two warships with good land troops appeared in the port of Luanda. The Portuguese defended Luanda so badly that the town was taken, along with a goodly part of the kingdom.

Having learned of these advantageous events, Queen Njinga thought that the time had arrived for her to revenge herself against the Portuguese. She had always remembered in her heart how they had affronted her by proclaiming Ngola ArijDuring the conflict between Queen Njinga and the Portuguese, the Portuguese declared that Ngola Arij, an enemy of Njinga, was the legitimate king of Ndongo. the King of Ndongo. She sent the Dutch [her] ambassadors to congratulate them on their victories and to invite them to join their troops to hers so as to get rid of their common enemies once and for all.”

Source: Giovanni Cavazzi, an Italian-born Roman Catholic missionary in West Central Africa, “An Historical Description of Three Kingdoms: Congo, Matamba, and Angola,” 1687

q.s: Which of the following best describes the claim made by Mustakeem in the second paragraph of the excerpt?

o.l: African captives who were forced into slavery suffered because of a lack of community.
African captives on slave ships overcame linguistic differences to act against their enslavement.
Slave traders’ efforts to separate African captives often prevented collective action by the enslaved.
Revolts aboard slave ships were often unsuccessful because of African captives’ disorganization and lack of geographical knowledge.

f.c:
“Violent eruptions acted out by [enslaved people] were far from uncommon on the oceanic highway of the Atlantic. In 1769, after sales were finalized and 425 slaves were boarded in hollowed corners of the Liverpool vessel Unity, the commander Richard Norris directed his crew to make preparations to expedite sail toward Jamaica. Prior to their departure, Norris reported, ‘the Slaves made an Insurrection,’ pointing out ‘[it] was soon quelled....’ Archival records leave silent the number of people who rose in rebellion [and] the efforts used in their suppression.... With stories of black aggression criss-crossing the Atlantic and exposing audiences to the dangers sailors regularly confronted in the transport and management of slaves, Norris likely became familiar with these same maritime realities, preparing himself and his crew for a similar prospect of danger....

Ship revolts encapsulated a collective language of resistance. Sailors continually sought to prevent ‘chaining those together who speak the same language.’ Yet these divisive mechanisms often proved futile in thwarting collectivism among boarded captives. Forced to live altered lives as someone else’s property, they formulated beginning ideals of a community grounded upon a shared struggle of oppression. Unfamiliar with their geographical locations far from land out at sea, [enslaved people] adapted to their forced surroundings, routinely drawing upon the terrain of ships to reclaim their own versions of power and freedom. Those held captive were many times, in one scholar’s estimation, ‘unorganized, undisciplined, and united only in their insatiable desire for liberty.’”

Source: Sowande Mustakeem, historian, Slavery at Sea: Terror, Sex, and Sickness in the Middle Passage, 2016

q.s: Based on the excerpt, Mustakeem would most likely agree with which of the following claims?

o.l: Enslaved people did not have opportunities to resist slavery before arriving in the Americas.
Sailors generally had total power over the enslaved people being held on slave ships.
The actions of enslaved people influenced the preparations made aboard slave ships.
Little can be known about revolts by enslaved people because of the lack of archival records.

q.s: Which of the following best reflects the author’s reasoning about the rights of formerly enslaved people?

o.l: They had never reaped the benefits of their labor and should emigrate.
They should be allowed to purchase the land on which they had labored.
They should migrate North to gain an education following the end of the Civil War.
They had helped build the nation’s wealth through their labor and working of the land.

f.c:
“We now, as a people desires to be elevated, and we desires to do all we can to be educated, and we hope our friends will aid us all they can.... 

I may state to all our friends, and to all our enemies, that we has a right to the land where we are located...why? I tell you. Our wives, our children, our husbands, has been sold over and over again to purchase the lands we now locate upon; for that reason we have a divine right to the land.... 

And then didn’t we clear the land and raise the crops of corn, of cotton, of tobacco, of rice, of sugar, of everything? And then didn’t them large cities in the North grow up on the cotton and the sugars and the rice that we made? Yes! I appeal to the South and the North if I hasn’t spoken the words of truth. 

I say they have grown rich, and my people is poor.”

Source: Bayley Wyatt, speech by a freedman from Yorktown, Virginia, 1866

o.l: Congress passed laws that slowed the process of granting citizenship to formerly enslaved people.

Congress established the Freedmen’s Bureau to keep track of formerly enslaved people.
Federal law overturned state slave codes that limited the movement of African Americans throughout the South.

q.s: Explain how African Americans used art and literature as an expression of identity in the twentieth century.
Explain why critiques of colonialism developed across the African diaspora in the twentieth century.
Which of the following statements is true of the area of Africa included on the map?

o.l: The languages of West, Central, and Southern Africa originated in this area.
Some of the earliest complex, large-scale societies arose in this part of Africa.
The history of this region of Africa is largely undocumented and unknowable.
Kola tree cultivation originated in this region and then spread to the rest of Africa.

f.c:
• The map shows the Egyptian Empire and the following nearby geographic and political features:

    • Mediterranean Sea to the northwest

    • Anatolia to the north

    • Asia to the northeast

    • Arabia to the east

    • Africa to the west

  • From the Mediterranean Sea, the Egyptian Empire extends:

    • South along the Nile River through Nubia to Sudan

    • Northeast along the eastern coast of the Mediterranean Sea through Palestine, Phoenicia, and Syria

  • Egyptian trade routes over land are shown as follows:

    • For the portion of the empire along the Nile River:

      • Most land routes are a network that crosses and re-crosses the Nile River from Egypt in the north to Nubia in the south.

      • Two land routes go west and south, respectively, into Africa.

    • For the portion of the empire along the eastern coast of the Mediterranean Sea:

      • Most land routes are a network that passes from Palestine in the south to Syria in the north.

      • Two routes go eastward into Assyria and Babylonia in Asia, respectively.

    • One goes along the Nile River.

q.s: Slave narratives written by Black women often relied on which of the following to demonstrate the unique vulnerabilities experienced by their authors?

o.l: Examples of facing abuse and violence
Examples of working long hours in the fields on plantations
Examples of serving as leaders in wars
Examples of working as religious leaders on plantations

f.c:
“Oh dear! I cannot bear to think of that daywhen Mary (then aged 12) and her sisters were separated from their mother and sold to different enslavers in Bermuda, it is too much. It recalls the great grief that filled my heart, and the woeful thoughts that passed to and fro through my mind, whilst listening to the pitiful words of my poor mother, weeping for the loss of her children. I wish I could find words to tell you all I then felt and suffered. The great God above alone knows the thoughts of the poor slave's heart, and the bitter pains which follow such separations as these. All that we love taken away from us—Oh, it is sad, sad! and sore to be borne! I got no sleep that night for thinking of the morrow; and dear Miss Betseythe granddaughter of Mary’s current enslaver, to whom Mary had been a companion and servant was scarcely less distressed. She could not bear to part with her old playmates, and she cried sore and would not be pacified.”

Mary Prince, formerly enslaved Black woman from Bermuda, The History of Mary Prince, a West Indian Slave, book published in London, 1831

q.s: Which of the following best describes the most likely intended purpose of the source?

To criticize enslaved mothers who abandoned their children
To advance the political cause of abolition
To stress the importance of direct action to combat slavery

q.s: Which of the following goals most directly motivated the travel of the Africans noted in the excerpt?

o.l: Engaging in diplomacy on behalf of the Kingdom of Kongo
Protesting Kongo’s forced conversion to Christianity
Finding work as domestic laborers
Studying at Islamic universities

f.c:
“...Both [Portugal and Kongo] possessed general-purpose monies—gold and silver in Portugal and monetary cloth and nzimbucowrie shells shells in Kongo... The two countries...[evolved] a rather complex system of currency exchanges and credits. The nature of this working arrangement can be gleaned from a ‘letter of credit’ which King Afonso I of Kongo drew up for his brother Manuel, travelling to Rome as his ambassador in 1540. Afonso asked for a grant of 5,000 cruzadosPortuguese money, and in exchange, created a credit of 150 kofuunit of measure for cowrie shells of nzimbu for the King of Portugal in Kongo. Other such money matters in the mid-sixteenth century were handled by the Kongolese trade representative in the city of Lisbon, who for some fifteen years was António Vereira, a noble Kongolese resident there.”

Source: John Thornton, historian, “Early Kongo-Portuguese Relations: A New Interpretation,” History in Africa, 1981

q.s: Which of the following results occurred due to the relationship between Portugal and Kongo?

o.l: A growth in trans-Saharan trade
An increased population of Europeans in West Africa
The development of kinship networks in West Africa
A decline in the export of enslaved people from Africa

The movement of people and goods to and from the islands spread the Swahili language among the city-states of East Africa.
The plantations established on the islands became a model for the slave-based economy that developed in the Americas.

q.s: Which of the following best describes African American blues music?

o.l: It originated among African American communities in New Orleans and continues to evolve.
It was created mostly for economic gain as African Americans struggled to acquire job opportunities.
It emerged from slavery as African Americans sought forms of self-expression.
It was used by African Americans as the primary means to protest racism.

f.c:
“The blues insisted that the fate of the individual black man or woman, what happened in their “trivial” affairs, what took place within them—their yearnings, their problems, their frustrations, their dreams—were important, were worth taking note of and sharing in a song. Stressing individual expression and group coherence at one and the same time, the blues was an inward-looking music which insisted upon the meaningfulness of black lives. In these respects it was not only the more obviously angry work songs but the blues as well, that were subversive of the American racial order and proved to be an important portentsign of what was to come in a very few decades.”

Source: Lawrence Levine, Black Culture and Black Consciousness: Afro-American Thought from Slavery to Freedom, 1975

q.s: Which of the following best summarizes Levine’s major claim in this source?

o.l: African Americans created a variety of musical genres.
The blues was formed as a rejection of traditional African music styles.
African Americans used musical expression to counter the horrors of racism.
The blues was part of the racial order of the United States.

f.c:
“The blues insisted that the fate of the individual black man or woman, what happened in their “trivial” affairs, what took place within them—their yearnings, their problems, their frustrations, their dreams—were important, were worth taking note of and sharing in a song. Stressing individual expression and group coherence at one and the same time, the blues was an inward-looking music which insisted upon the meaningfulness of black lives. In these respects it was not only the more obviously angry work songs but the blues as well, that were subversive of the American racial order and proved to be an important portentsign of what was to come in a very few decades.”

Source: Lawrence Levine, Black Culture and Black Consciousness: Afro-American Thought from Slavery to Freedom, 1975

q.s: Which of the following best serves as evidence in support of Levine’s claim?

o.l: The blues originated in the South and traveled northward in the Great Migration.
The foundation of the blues was established on African musical traditions.
The radio contributed to the spread of African American musical genres.
The blues conveyed emotional themes of despair, hope, love, and loss.

f.c:

They embodied and articulated both the suffering and the hopes of enslaved African Americans.

Source 1

“[When I was a slave] I did not fully understand the deep meanings of those rude, and apparently incoherent songs. They were...loud, long and deep, breathing the prayer and complaint of souls boiling over with the bitterest anguish. Every tone was a testimony against slavery.... To those songs I trace my first understanding of the dehumanizing character of slavery. Those songs still follow me, to deepen my hatred of slavery and [strengthen] my sympathies for my brethren in bonds.”

q.s: Which of the following was a development in the history of slavery in Brazil?

o.l: Most people brought to Brazil from Africa were of the Islamic faith.
Enslaved Africans in Brazil generally did not work in plantation agriculture.
Enslaved people applied knowledge developed in Africa to rice cultivation in Brazil.
More enslaved Africans arrived in Brazil than in any other place in the Americas.

f.c:
“The abolitionist movement in Brazil was a struggle between classes within one nation.... 

Government leaders [in Brazil] thought that they had resolved the emancipation issue with [a law passed in 1871].... 

Although slave owners proclaimed their emancipationist sentiments...the radical abolitionists challenged these assertions [beginning in 1885].... The immediate abolitionist leaders held that [decrees that gradually emancipated enslaved people] were having little effect on the institution.

It was this move toward confrontational politics on the part of the abolitionists in the post-1885 period that finally saw the dismantling of slavery.... The army and the local police now refused to return fugitives, and mass exodus from plantations was becoming common in the most advanced plantation counties of [the capital city of] São Paulo.... When even members of the imperial family [ruling Brazil] were converted to a radical abolitionist position, there was little hope left for the slave owners. In May 1888, the government finally decreed immediate and totally uncompensated emancipation for all slaves. Thus ended the largest remaining slave regime in America, and with its destruction, African slavery was finally brought to an end in all the Americas.”

Source: Herbert S. Klein and Francisco Vidal Luna, historians, Slavery in Brazil, 2010

q.s: The petition in the excerpt was written from the perspective of

o.l: an Indigenous ruler
a Spanish slave trader
a free Black conquistador
an enslaved captive from Africa

f.c:
“I, Juan Garrido, black resident of [Mexico City], appear before Your Mercy and state that I am in need of making a probanzapetition to the perpetuity of the king, a report on how I served Your Majesty in the conquest and pacification of this New Spain, from the time when the Marqués del Valle [Cortés] entered it; and in his company I was present at all the invasions and conquests and pacifications which were carried out, always with the said Marqués, all of which I did at my own expense without being given either salary or allotment of natives or anything else. As I am married and a resident of this city, where I have always lived; and also as I went with the Marqués del Valle to discover the islands which are in that part of the southern sea [the Pacific] where there was much hunger and privation; and also as I went to discover and pacify the islands of San Juan de Buriquén de Puerto Rico; and also as I went on the pacification and conquest of the island of Cuba with the adelantadoa military governor of a Spanish colony Diego Velazquez; in all these ways for thirty years have I served and continue to serve Your Majesty—for these reasons stated above do I petition Your Mercy. And also because I was the first to have the inspiration to sow maize [corn] here in New Spain and to see if it took; I did this and experimented at my own expense.”

Source: Juan Garrido, petition to Emperor Charles V of Spain, 1538
