q.s: Which of the following best describes a historical context that connected the Africans discussed in Source 1 with the Spanish discussed in Source 2?

o.l: Spanish Florida was predominantly Catholic and many of the participants in the Stono Rebellion were from a largely Catholic region of Africa.
The griot tradition originated in Spain and spread to the region of Africa where many of the participants in the Stono rebellion originated.
Many enslaved people from the region near the Stono River were forced to relocate to Spanish Florida during the Second Middle Passage.
The American Colonization Society exiled free Black people from South Carolina to Spanish Florida for many years.

f.c:
Source 1 

“On the 9th day of September...[twenty] Angola negroes assembled...and one who was called Jemmy was their captain. They surprised a warehouse belonging to Mr. Hutchenson...they there killed Mr. Robert Bathurst, and Mr. Gibbs, plundered the house, and took a pretty many small arms and powder.... They then...marched southward...through Georgia to Augustine.... They increased every minute by new negroes coming to them, so that they were above sixty, some say a hundred, [when] they halted in a field, and set to dancing, singing and beating drums, to draw more negroes to them...but...the planters...pursued them and when they came up...charged them on foot.... About 30 escaped from the flight.... General Oglethorpe...immediately ordered a troop of rangers...to patrol through Georgia...and published a proclamation ordering all the constables...of Georgia to pursue and seize all negroes.... It is hoped these measures will prevent any negroes from getting down to the Spaniards.”

Source: Unknown author, a description of the Stono Rebellion, South Carolina, 1739, in the Colonial Records of the State of Georgia

 

Source 2 

“Mose was located...directly north of St. Augustine.... It was strategically significant. Governor Montiano surely considered the benefits of a northern outpost against anticipated British attacks. And who better to serve as an advanced warning system than grateful ex-slaves carrying Spanish arms? The freedmen understood their expected role, for, in a declaration to the king, they vowed to be ‘the most cruel enemies of the English’ and to risk their lives and spill their ‘last drop of blood in defense of the Great Crown of Spain and the Holy Faith.’ If the new homesteaders were diplomats, they were also pragmatistsperson who is practical and focused on a goal, and their own interests were clearly served by fighting those who would seek to return them to chattel slavery.”

Source: Jane Landers, historian, “Gracia Real de Santa Teresa de Mose: A Free Black Town in a Spanish Colony,” article published in the American Historical Review, 1990

The African cultural traditions that were common in Britain’s southern colonies influenced the culture of Spain’s colony in Florida.
Knowledge of the promise of freedom in Florida encouraged enslaved people in regions to the north to resist slavery.

o.l: The Spanish lost control of their last colony in the Americas.

f.c:
Source 1 

“On the 9th day of September...[twenty] Angola negroes assembled...and one who was called Jemmy was their captain. They surprised a warehouse belonging to Mr. Hutchenson...they there killed Mr. Robert Bathurst, and Mr. Gibbs, plundered the house, and took a pretty many small arms and powder.... They then...marched southward...through Georgia to Augustine.... They increased every minute by new negroes coming to them, so that they were above sixty, some say a hundred, [when] they halted in a field, and set to dancing, singing and beating drums, to draw more negroes to them...but...the planters...pursued them and when they came up...charged them on foot.... About 30 escaped from the flight.... General Oglethorpe...immediately ordered a troop of rangers...to patrol through Georgia...and published a proclamation ordering all the constables...of Georgia to pursue and seize all negroes.... It is hoped these measures will prevent any negroes from getting down to the Spaniards.”

Source: Unknown author, a description of the Stono Rebellion, South Carolina, 1739, in the Colonial Records of the State of Georgia

 

Source 2 

“Mose was located...directly north of St. Augustine.... It was strategically significant. Governor Montiano surely considered the benefits of a northern outpost against anticipated British attacks. And who better to serve as an advanced warning system than grateful ex-slaves carrying Spanish arms? The freedmen understood their expected role, for, in a declaration to the king, they vowed to be ‘the most cruel enemies of the English’ and to risk their lives and spill their ‘last drop of blood in defense of the Great Crown of Spain and the Holy Faith.’ If the new homesteaders were diplomats, they were also pragmatistsperson who is practical and focused on a goal, and their own interests were clearly served by fighting those who would seek to return them to chattel slavery.”

Source: Jane Landers, historian, “Gracia Real de Santa Teresa de Mose: A Free Black Town in a Spanish Colony,” article published in the American Historical Review, 1990

q.s: Which of the following statements best explains the presence of pendants such as the one in the image in the Kingdom of Kongo?

o.l: The Portuguese understood that the East African city-states were united by a shared religion and Bantu language.
King Nzinga a Nkuwu and his son Nzinga Mbemba voluntarily converted their kingdom to Roman Catholicism.
Queen Njinga expanded her military by offering religious sanctuary for those who escaped Portuguese enslavement and joined her forces.
Family groups were held together by extended kinship ties in which women served as spiritual leaders in many early West and Central African societies.

f.c:
• The pendant depicts Saint Anthony standing and wearing a Catholic monk’s habit.
  • In his right hand, Saint Anthony holds a cross.
  • In his left hand, Saint Anthony holds a small figure, possibly an infant.
  • The pendant’s sheen suggests it is made of metal.

Gift of Ernst Anspach, 1999. The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

o.l: By depicting a saint important in Portugal, the pendant indicates how the Kingdom of Kongo was forced to convert to Christianity and explains why enslaved people in the Americas rejected the faith.
The use of brass to manufacture the pendant highlights the role of the brass trade in initially attracting Europeans to West Africa, which became a major source of enslaved people in the Americas.
A pendant of a Roman Catholic saint created in the Kingdom of Kongo suggests that many West Central Africans were Christians before they arrived in the Americas as enslaved people.
A Christian pendant made by Africans provides evidence of the export of African manufactured goods to the Americas to support the veneration of ancestors by enslaved people.

q.s: Why is the author's perspective significant in understanding the Tulsa Race Massacre?

o.l: It offers a portrayal of both the perpetrators and the victims of the massacre.
It emphasizes the role of the author as a heroic figure who overcame adversity.
It allows for a comprehensive analysis of the social and economic factors leading to the massacre.
It provides a firsthand account of the impact and devastation experienced by those targeted.

f.c:
“I reached my office in safety; but I knew that that safety would be short-lived. I now knew the mob-spirit. I knew too that government and law and order has broken down. I knew that mob law had been substituted in all its fiendishness and barbarity. I knew that the mobbist cared nothing about the written law and the constitution and I also now knew that he had neither the patience nor the intelligence to distinguish between the good and the bad, the law abiding and the lawless in my race. From my office window, I could see planes circling in mid-air. They grew in number and hummed, darted and dipped low. I could hear something like hail falling upon the top of my office building. Down East Archer, I saw the old Mid-Way hotel on fire, burning from its top, and then another and another and another building began to burn from the top. “What, an attack from the air too?”, I asked myself. Lurid flames roared and belched and licked their forked tongues in the air. Smoke ascended from the sky in thick, black volumes and amid it all, the planes—now a dozen or more in number—still hummed and darted here and there with the agility of natural birds of the air.... 

For fully forty eight hours, the fires raged and burned everything in its path and it left nothing but ashes and burned safes and trunks and the like where once stood beautiful homes and business houses. And so proud, [rich], black Tulsa was destroyed by fire—that is its buildings and property; but its spirit was neither killed nor daunted.”

Collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, Gift from Tulsa Friends and John W. and Karen R. Franklin

Source: The Tulsa Race Riot and Three of Its Victims, unpublished manuscript, 1931

q.s: Which of the following statements most accurately explains the effect of the Tulsa Race Massacre of 1921?

o.l: It prevented many African American families from passing down wealth and property due to the destruction and loss incurred during the violence.
It led to the wave of racial violence incited by white supremacists across the country in the period known as the Red Summer.
It inspired Ida B. Wells to publish her findings that lynching aimed to instill fear in African Americans and discourage them from pursuing economic advancement.
It discouraged African American writers from publishing any accounts about racial violence in order to avoid retaliation from white supremacists.

q.s: The author’s reflection that “black Tulsa was destroyed by fire—that is its buildings and property; but its spirit was neither killed nor daunted” serves as evidence of which of the following claims?

o.l: The resilience of the African American community stayed strong despite the devastation inflicted by the Tulsa Race Massacre.
The Tulsa Race Massacre completely devastated the African American community in Tulsa, leaving no hope for recovery.
There was a lack of support and solidarity from neighboring communities during the Tulsa Race Massacre.
The African American community would easily recover from the devastation of the Tulsa Race Massacre.

q.s: Which of the following statements best describes the context of the author’s social activism, as outlined in the letter?

o.l: Religion inspired resistance to slavery in the form of rebellions.
Some free Black entrepreneurs established successful manufacturing businesses that became household names.
Free African Americans built community through religious institutions, including established and independent churches.
African Americans used spirituals and other religious artistic genres to articulate their hardships and hopes under enslavement.

f.c:
“It has been said by our enemies among the whites, that it is doing us harm to set us free: we cannot, they say, maintain ourselves decently and respectably.... To prove which, they bid us look around [at] the many poor [people] of...color with which this city [Philadelphia] abounds, [a city in which very many wealthy African Americans] live on the best, dress in the finest and most fashionable clothing...[and] have everything provided for the body without thought or care.... 

These men work hard...have money...and [believe they] must enjoy it in the way they have seen others do....

When I was first marriedThe author married a moderately well-off Afro-Caribbean barber resident in Philadelphia., I found myself precisely in this way. We had our parties and tea-drinkings; we must have the best wine and the best cake; our friends had it and we must give them the same they gave us.... But when it pleased the Lord to open my eyes, these things became a burden to me. I remembered [Christ] had said ‘When thou makest a feast call in the poor, the lame and the blind....’ It occurred to me that Christ had lived a self-denying life, and I began to think how I might deny myself, take up the cross and follow him, when dress presented itself to my view first. Now a pair of [fine] shoes cost one dollar and 50 cents: [I told myself that] a pair of [worse quality] will do just as well, and I shall have 50 cents for the poor. A fine muslin dress costs five dollars: I can buy a very good calico one for three and have two dollars to spare....

These things were very trifling in themselves, but oh! the peace of mind and the liberty I gained by [doing them].... I no longer felt disturbed as to whether my appearance was better than my neighbor or not, and I always had something for the poor.”

Source: Grace Bustill Douglass, free African American abolitionist, Society of Friends (Quaker) religious reformer, and women’s rights activist, letter to Rev. John Gloucester, African American religious leader, founder of the First African Presbyterian Church in Philadelphia, 1819

q.s: Douglass’s statement that, by embracing a “self-denying life,” she “no longer felt disturbed as to whether my appearance was better than my neighbor or not, and I always had something for the poor” best illustrates which of the following?

o.l: Many Black women supported the women’s suffrage movement in addition to the abolition of slavery.
Many Black women used their life experiences to highlight the connections between race and class in the African American community.
Many Black women emphasized their American identity by rejecting the term “African,” preferring the term “African American.”
Some Black women used political speeches and published pamphlets as vehicles for their political activism.

q.s:
Using the image, respond to parts A, B, and C.

 

  1. Describe one important cultural or political function of the structures in the image.
  2. Describe one economic, cultural, or social difference between Great Zimbabwe and another African empire in the same period.

f.c:
• The photograph shows walls of two different heights and a taller conical tower.

  • Each structure is similarly constructed of tightly fitted multicolored stone.

  • In the left foreground is a short wall.

  • In the background is a tall, curved stone wall that appears to be at least twice the height of the wall in the foreground.

  • In the center, in front of the taller wall, is a conical stone tower that appears to be significantly taller than the taller wall. A much smaller conical stone structure sits to the right of the base of the tower.

  • Trees grow on each side of the tower from the area between the two walls

Robin Smith/Getty Images

o.l: The migration from urban centers into rural locales increased African Americans’ access to agricultural education.

q.s:
Respond to parts A, B, and C.

  1. Describe one example of a migration of Afro-descended people prior to 1860.

  2. Describe one cause of a migration of Afro-descended people between 1900 and 1970.

  3. Explain how the migration of Afro-descended people to the United States influenced a social or cultural change in the twentieth century.
The technological innovations described in the excerpt most directly contributed to

o.l: the wealth and power of the Mali Empire
the conversion of Central Africa to Christianity
population growth in West and Central Africa
increased travel by African elites to Mediterranean port cities

f.c:
In Praise of the Ironsmith

Today this place is full of noise and jollitycelebration.
The guiding spirit that enables my husband to forgeto shape metal by heating makes him do wonders.
All those who lack hoes for weeding, come and buy!
Hoes and choppers are here in plenty.
My husband is a craftsman in iron,
Truly a wizard at forging hoes.
Ah, here they are! They have come eager to find hoes.
Ah, the iron itself is aglow, it is molten red with heat,
And the ore is ruddy and incandescent.
My husband is an expert in working iron,
A craftsman who sticks like wax to his trade.
On the day when the urge to forge comes upon him,
The bellowsa fan used to increase the heat of a fire do everything but speak.
The pile of slagwaste created when working with iron rises higher and higher.
Just look at what has been forged,
At the choppers, at the hoes, at the battle axes,
And here at the pile of hatchets, large and small.
Then look at the double-bladed knives and the adzes.
Merely to list them all seems like boasting.
As for fowlsbirds raised for meat or eggs and goats, they cover my yard.
They all come from the sale of tools and weapons.
Here is where you see me eating at ease with a spoon.

Source: Unknown author, Shona Praise Poetry

q.s: The information in the passage best supports which of the following arguments?

o.l: Plantation overseers’ interactions with enslaved African Americans were strictly controlled by plantation owners.
Enslaved African Americans of all genders performed a variety of domestic, agricultural, and skilled work.
The artisanal labor of skilled “mechanics” was more highly valued than the labor of any other group of enslaved workers.
Enslaved persons’ work on plantations in Mississippi was organized completely differently than it was in Alabama.

f.c:
[Describing a plantation in Mississippi] 


“There were 135 slaves, big and little, of which 67 went to field regularly—equal, the overseer thought, to 60 able-bodied hands. Besides the field-hands, there were 3 mechanics (blacksmith, carpenter and wheelwright), 2 seamstresses, 1 cook, 1 stable servant, 1 cattle-tender, 1 hog-tender, 1 teamsterA person who drives horse or cattle carts, 1 house servant (overseer’s cook), and one midwife and nurse.”...

 

[Describing a plantation in Alabama]


“Each overseer regulated the hours of work on his own plantation. I saw the negroes at work before sunrise and after sunset. At about eight o’clock they were allowed to stop for breakfast, and again about noon, to dine. The length of these rests was at the discretion of the overseer or drivers...

 

The plowing, both with single and double mule teams, was generally performed by women, and very well performed, too.... Twenty of them were plowing together, with double teams and heavy plows. They were superintended by a male negro driver, who carried a whip, which he frequently cracked at them, permitting no dawdling or delay... Throughout the SouthwestAt the time, the term referred mainly to the states of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Tennessee, and Kentucky the negroes, as a rule, appear to be worked much harder than in the eastern and northern slave States. I do not think they accomplish as much daily, as agricultural laborers at the North usually do, but they certainly labor much harder, and more unremittingly.”
 

Source: Frederick Law Olmsted, United States architect and journalist, A Journey in the Back Country in the Winter of 1853–4, book published in 1860

q.s: Based on the passage, Olmsted most likely would have agreed with which of the following claims regarding slavery in Mississippi and Alabama?

o.l: It was a benign institution and enslaved people were treated humanely.
It had become foundational to the economy of the region and had to be maintained as a “necessary evil.”
It was inefficient compared to the agricultural labor systems in use elsewhere in the United States.
It had fostered interdependence among the economies of the Southern and Northern states.

f.c:
[Describing a plantation in Mississippi] 


“There were 135 slaves, big and little, of which 67 went to field regularly—equal, the overseer thought, to 60 able-bodied hands. Besides the field-hands, there were 3 mechanics (blacksmith, carpenter and wheelwright), 2 seamstresses, 1 cook, 1 stable servant, 1 cattle-tender, 1 hog-tender, 1 teamsterA person who drives horse or cattle carts, 1 house servant (overseer’s cook), and one midwife and nurse.”...

 

[Describing a plantation in Alabama]


“Each overseer regulated the hours of work on his own plantation. I saw the negroes at work before sunrise and after sunset. At about eight o’clock they were allowed to stop for breakfast, and again about noon, to dine. The length of these rests was at the discretion of the overseer or drivers...

 

The plowing, both with single and double mule teams, was generally performed by women, and very well performed, too.... Twenty of them were plowing together, with double teams and heavy plows. They were superintended by a male negro driver, who carried a whip, which he frequently cracked at them, permitting no dawdling or delay... I do not think they accomplish as much daily, as agricultural laborers at the North usually do, but they certainly labor much harder, and more unremittingly.”
 

Source: Frederick Law Olmsted, United States architect and journalist, A Journey in the Back Country in the Winter of 1853–4, book published in 1860

q.s: Which of the following claims is made by Brown in the excerpt?

o.l: African elites attempted to halt the trade of enslaved people in Western Africa.
African states that traded with Europeans held a significant advantage over societies that did not.
Relations between African states were largely peaceful until the introduction of firearms by Europeans.
The enslavement of people in Africa did not begin until after European merchants traded weapons for captive people.

f.c:
“From the mid-sixteenth century, when African traders in the Senegambia and Angola first supplied slaves to the Europeans... the [Atlantic] trade expanded dramatically through the eighteenth century....European enterprise in the Americas flourished whenever and wherever enslaved African labor was most exploited. Slaves were the region’s...most vital factor in the production of goods and services....

Atlantic trade wasn’t the African elites’ only concern by any means, but as various merchants, middlemen, and enterprising renegades recognized the increasing scope of Atlantic opportunities, they found ways to turn the slave trade to their advantage. The process was dramatically demonstrated by the highly centralized states—such as Oyo, Dahomey, and Asante inland from the Gold and Slave Coasts [in West Africa]—that incorporated trade with Europeans into their wars of expansion. They valued firearms from Europe among the most useful commodities. Gold Coast traders had imported sizable numbers of guns beginning as early as the 1650s, but by 1730 an estimated 180,000 firearms a year were flooding into the Gold and Slave Coasts, facilitating the rise and reach of predatory slaving states. These slaving regimes engaged in regular campaigns to plunder stateless societies for captives or to raid weakened polities that could no longer protect their people. Captives could be retained to swell armies and enlarge retinues or be sold to Europeans for goods and more guns, which only deepened the spiraling vortex of violence. Such predatory slaving states proliferated and gathered strength in the eighteenth century, and the privations and chaos attending their local wars made ever more refugees available for capture and sale abroad.”

Source: Vincent Brown, historian, Tacky’s Revolt: The Story of an Atlantic Slave War, 2020

q.s: Which of the following is a piece of evidence used by Brown to support his argument about the highly centralized states discussed in the excerpt?

o.l: Atlantic trade was not the only focus of elites in West Africa.
European enterprise in the Americas depended on enslaved African labor.
Firearms began to arrive in the Gold and Slave Coasts of West Africa in large numbers by the eighteenth century.
African traders in the Senegambia first traded enslaved people with Europeans in the mid-sixteenth century.

f.c:
“From the mid-sixteenth century, when African traders in the Senegambia and Angola first supplied slaves to the Europeans... the [Atlantic] trade expanded dramatically through the eighteenth century....European enterprise in the Americas flourished whenever and wherever enslaved African labor was most exploited. Slaves were the region’s...most vital factor in the production of goods and services....

They valued firearms from Europe among the most useful commodities. Gold Coast traders had imported sizable numbers of guns beginning as early as the 1650s, but by 1730 an estimated 180,000 firearms a year were flooding into the Gold and Slave Coasts, facilitating the rise and reach of predatory slaving states. These slaving regimes engaged in regular campaigns to plunder stateless societies for captives or to raid weakened polities that could no longer protect their people. Captives could be retained to swell armies and enlarge retinues or be sold to Europeans for goods and more guns, which only deepened the spiraling vortex of violence. Such predatory slaving states proliferated and gathered strength in the eighteenth century, and the privations and chaos attending their local wars made ever more refugees available for capture and sale abroad.”

Source: Vincent Brown, historian, Tacky’s Revolt: The Story of an Atlantic Slave War, 2020

o.l: made European colonial powers significantly wealthier
increased violence between rival West African peoples
helped stateless societies to protect themselves from West African slaving regimes

q.s: The source could best be used as evidence for which of the following claims about the experience of African American voters during the later nineteenth century?

o.l: The political rights of African Americans were threatened by other citizens.
The Freedmen’s Bureau helped African American voters cast ballots during elections.
The Fifteenth Amendment fully protected the ability of African American voters to participate in elections.
The federal government prioritized protecting African American voters over reintegrating Southern states into the Union.

f.c:
“The conduct of the late election [of 1876] in Mississippi...put in question and jeopardy the sacred rights of the citizens; and the [congressional] investigation contemplated...has for its objective...the protection in all their purity and significance of the political rights of the people and the free institutions of the country.... 

The evidence in hand and accessible will show...that in many parts of the State corrupt and violent influences were brought to bear upon the registrars of voters, thus materially affecting the character of the voting or poll lists.... Threats and violence were practiced directly upon the masses of voters in such measures and strength as to produce grave apprehensions for their personal safety, and as to deter them from the exercise of their political franchises.... 

The sober American judgment must [prevail] in the South as elsewhere in the Republic, ...that differences of religion, nationality, or race can neither with safety nor propriety be permitted for a moment to enter into the [political] party contests of the day.”

Source: Speech by Blanche K. Bruce, United States senator from Mississippi, the first African American to serve a full term in the Senate, 1876

q.s: Blanche K. Bruce’s speech could best be used as evidence to support which of the following claims?

o.l: De jure segregation laws prevented African American politicians from attending sessions of their legislatures.
African American men who enlisted in the Union Army often promoted political equality.
African American political leaders demanded their Constitutional rights during Reconstruction.
Racial violence was ineffective in restricting the participation of African Americans in politics.

f.c:
“The conduct of the late election [of 1876] in Mississippi...put in question and jeopardy the sacred rights of the citizens; and the [congressional] investigation contemplated...has for its objective...the protection in all their purity and significance of the political rights of the people and the free institutions of the country.... 

The evidence in hand and accessible will show...that in many parts of the State corrupt and violent influences were brought to bear upon the registrars of voters, thus materially affecting the character of the voting or poll lists.... Threats and violence were practiced directly upon the masses of voters in such measures and strength as to produce grave apprehensions for their personal safety, and as to deter them from the exercise of their political franchises.... 

The sober American judgment must [prevail] in the South as elsewhere in the Republic, ...that differences of religion, nationality, or race can neither with safety nor propriety be permitted for a moment to enter into the [political] party contests of the day.”

Source: Speech by Blanche K. Bruce, United States senator from Mississippi, the first African American to serve a full term in the Senate, 1876

q.s: Which of the following statements best reflects a claim explaining government protections for African American rights after Reconstruction?

o.l: Governments were unwilling to uniformly enforce rights guaranteed to African Americans by the Constitution.
Constitutional amendments generally prevented state laws from infringing on African American’s civil rights.
African Americans were barred from access to rights such as entering into a legally binding marriage.
Federal actions enforced the right of African Americans to land confiscated from former Confederates.

f.c:
“The conduct of the late election [of 1876] in Mississippi...put in question and jeopardy the sacred rights of the citizens; and the [congressional] investigation contemplated...has for its objective...the protection in all their purity and significance of the political rights of the people and the free institutions of the country....

q.s: Which of the following factors contributed to the Bantu expansion?

o.l: Population declines in West and Central Africa
Military pressure from Xhosa populations
Trade opportunities in the desert of North Africa
Technological and agricultural innovations

f.c:
“We are sometimes asked ‘Do you speak African?’, as if there were but a single African language. A recent authority (Grimes (ed.) 1996) puts the number of African languages at 2,035: this number is not fixed, as some languages are still being ‘discovered’, while others with few speakers are being eliminated. Excluding languages introduced over the past two millennia or so, such as Arabic, Malagasy, Afrikaans, English, French, Spanish, and Portuguese, this figure of just over 2,000 breaks down into four large phyla: Niger-Congo 1,436 languages (including the Bantu family, which itself is often said to have 500 members), Afroasiatic 371, Nilo-Saharan 196 and Khoisan 35. A few Afroasiatic languages are spoken exclusively outside Africa, in the Middle East, which would reduce the figure for Africa somewhat. If we believe this figure of 2,000, then it represents nearly one-third of the world's languages.”

Source: Bernd Heine and Derek Nurse, African Languages, An Introduction, 2000

o.l: People in Northern Africa primarily speak Arabic because of the cultural connection to Islam.
Bantu linguistic family contains hundreds of languages that are spoken throughout West, Central, and Southern Africa today.
Because of an increase of trade with Europe, many Africans moved to Iberian port cities like Lisbon and Seville.
Due to the impacts of colonization and migration, today most African countries have unified their language.
